SENTENCES AND THEIR PERPLEXITY


1. thus the transformation of adam	smith's ideal entrepreneur into a mythological detective coincides	closely with the decline of the real entrepreneur in economic life	2473.2376244947345
2. driven	from the marketplace by the course of history our hero disguises	himself as a private detective	2122.5929989766087
3. the birth of the myth compensates	for the death of the ideal	643.7451046346652
4. even on the fictional level however	the contradictions which give rise to the mystery story are not fully	resolved	2585.031803409146
5. the individualism and public service of the private detective	both stem from his dedication to a personal code of conduct:	he enforces the law without being told to do so	3233.175606581426
6. the private eye is therefore	a moral man; but his morality rests upon that of his society	2118.230360897194
7. the basic premise of all mystery stories is that the distinction between	good and bad coincides with the distinction between legal and illegal	2325.2567697900154
8. unfortunately this assumption does not always hold good	251.0067451959745
9. as	capitalism in the 20th century has become increasingly dependent upon	force and violence for its survival the private detective is placed	in a serious dilemma	2751.336548548555
10. if he is good he may not be legal; if he is	legal he may not be good	2341.1858836306915
11. it is the gradual unfolding and deepening	of this contradiction which creates the inner dialectic of the evolution	of the mystery story	2172.4633977050908
12. with the advent of sir arthur	conan doyle's sherlock holmes the development of the modern private	detective begins	2360.4062254964606
13. sherlock holmes is not merely an individualist;	he is very close to being a mental case	1265.8021386265966
14. a brief list of the great	detective's little idiosyncrasies would provide dr freud with	ample food for thought	2358.7023810399623
15. holmes is addicted to the use of cocaine and	other refreshing stimulants; he is prone to semi-catatonic trances	induced by the playing of the vioiln; he is a recluse an incredible	egotist a confirmed misogynist	3774.8311520852358
16. holmes rebels against the social	conventions of his day not on moral but rather on aesthetic grounds	2109.0993844670534
17. his	eccentricity begins as a defense against boredom	167.58807925451114
18. it was in order	to avoid the stuffy routine of middle class life that holmes became	a detective in the first place	3263.3905909276664
19. as he informs watson my life is	spent in one long effort to escape from the commonplaces of existence	1724.7968949515798
20. these little problems help me to do so	250.52539239645085
21. holmes is a public servant	to be sure; but the society which he serves bores him to tears	1574.6212646132244
22. the curious relationship between holmes and scotland yard	provides an important clue to the deeper significance of his eccentric	behavior	2812.985476705974
23. although he is perfectly willing to cooperate with scotland	yard holmes has nothing but contempt for the intelligence and mentality	of the police	2321.0556746478837
24. they for their part are convinced that holmes	is too unorthodox and theoretical to make a good detective	2358.9153706040897
25. why do the police find holmes unorthodox	93.73203565030038
26. on the face of	it it is because he employs deductive techniques alien to official	police routine	2116.34283093417
27. another more interesting explanation is hinted at by	watson when he observes on several occasions that holmes would have	made a magnificent criminal	2331.257851650499
28. the great detective modestly agrees	22.306034218404672
29. watson's	insight is verified by the mysterious link between holmes	and his arch-opponent dr moriarty	1092.8205143316236
30. the two men resemble each other	closely in their cunning their egotism their relentlessness	1409.4583552840827
31. the	first series of sherlock holmes adventures ends with holmes and moriarty	grappling together on the edge of a cliff	1882.9141870199996
32. they are presumed	to have plunged to a common grave in this fatal embrace	1404.934404284781
33. linked to holmes	even in death moriarty represents the alter-ego of the great	detective the image of what our hero might have become were he not a	public servant	3105.420246796277
34. just as holmes the eccentric stands behind holmes the	detective so holmes the potential criminal lurks behind both	2363.4457743348403
35. in the modern english whodunnit this insinuation of	latent criminality in the detective himself has almost entirely disappeared	1562.4132503937249
36. hercule poirot and lord peter whimsey	have retained	holmes'	egotism but not his zest for life and eccentric habits	2580.068086205283
37. poirot and	his counterparts are perfectly respectable people; it is true that	they are also extremely dull	1408.8929262489257
38. their dedication to the status quo has	been affirmed at the expense of the fascinating but dangerous individualism	of a sherlock holmes	3271.253743172936
39. the latter's real descendents were unable	to take root in england; they fled from the victorian parlor	and made their way across the stormy atlantic	2594.6942806519573
40. in the american hardboiled	detective story of the '20s and '30s the spirit of the	mad genius from baker street lives on	3295.2444638768125
41. like holmes the	american private eye rejects the social conventions of his time	784.7029986962227
42. but	unlike holmes he feels his society to be not merely dull but also corrupt	1639.8639776381685
43. surrounded by crime and violence everywhere the hardboiled	private eye can retain his purity only through a life of self-imposed	isolation	2048.6130714859346
44. his alienation is far more acute than holmes'; he	is not an eccentric but rather an outcast	2119.1694172538364
45. with rex stout's nero	wolfe alienation is represented on a purely physical plane	792.8464629750698
46. wolfe	refuses to ever leave his own house and spends most of his time drinking	beer and playing with orchids	2798.6514313034386
47. more profound and more disturbing	however is the moral isolation of raymond chandler's philip marlowe	1100.6887616086035
48. in a society where everything is for sale marlowe is the only	man who cannot be bought	2133.7580157651178
49. his tough honesty condemns him to a solitary	and difficult existence	500.93228576026
50. beaten bruised and exhausted he pursues	the elusive killer through the demi-monde of high society and low	morals always alone always despised	3262.223789983984
51. in the end he gets his man but	no one seems to care; virtue is its own and only reward	1887.106178845575
52. a similar	tone of underlying futility and despair pervades the spy thrillers	of eric ambler and dominates the most famous of all american mystery	stories dashiell hammett's the maltese falcon	4813.404500009519
53. sam spade	joins forces with a band of adventurers in search of a priceless jeweled	statue of a falcon; but when the bird is found at last it turns	out to be a fake	3655.609553561785
54. now the detective must save his own skin by informing	on the girl he loves who is also the real murderer	3059.171045655373
55. for sam spade	neither crime nor virtue pays; moreover it is increasingly difficult	to distinguish between the two	1574.6408617747813
56. because the private eye	intends to save society in spite of himself he invariably finds himself	in trouble with the police	3039.7230106645793
57. the latter are either too stupid to	catch the killer or too corrupt to care	1102.1630394196534
58. in either case they do not	appreciate the private detective's zeal	754.1582800207691
59. perry mason and hamilton	burger nero wolfe and inspector cramer spend more time fighting	each other than they do in looking for the criminal	2467.694168927922
60. frequently enough	the police are themselves in league with the killer; dashiell	hammett's	red harvest provides a classic example of this theme	3261.4014098776056
61. but even when the police are honest they do not trust the private	eye	951.7500601412514
62. he is like phillip marlowe too alienated to be reliable	563.7949599980309
63. finally	in the maltese falcon among others the clash between detective	and police is carried to its logical conclusion: sam spade	becomes the chief murder suspect	2733.5706879040144
64. in order to exonerate himself he	is compelled to find the real criminal who happens to be his girl friend	2806.3605866075095
65. what was only a vague suspicion in the case of sherlock holmes	now appears as a direct accusation: the private eye is in danger of	turning into his opposite	3110.7843020813507
66. it is the growing contradiction	between individualism and public service in the mystery story which	creates this fatal dilemma	2584.9324300405588
67. by upholding his own personal code of behavior	the private detective has placed himself in opposition to a society	whose fabric is permeated with crime and corruption	2878.043360376461
68. that society	responds by condemning the private eye as a threat to the status quo	a potential criminal	2369.0440435548767
69. if the detective insists upon retaining his	personal standards he must now do so in conscious defiance of his society	1886.5644744780013
70. he must in short cease to be a detective and become a rebel	1191.7616969722724
71. on the other hand if he wishes to continue in his chosen profession	he must abandon his own code and sacrifice his precious individualism	2454.8385527336595
72. dashiell hammett resolved this contradiction by ceasing to write	mystery	stories and turning to other pursuits	1873.5890570885433
73. his successors have adopted	the opposite alternative	93.7007948875456
74. in order to save the mystery story they	have converted the private detective into an organization man	2125.2119138445805
75. the first of two possible variations on this theme is symbolized by	mickey spillane's mike hammer	1259.2077196502582
76. at first glance this hero seems	to be more rather than less of an individualist than any of his predecessors	2796.121122176939
77. for hammer nothing is forbidden	14.917631594459909
78. he kills when he pleases	takes his women where he finds them and always acts as judge jury	and executioner rolled into one	3513.024457735172
79. it will be shown that the objectives of the cooperative people in	an organization determine the type of network required because the	type of network functions according to the characteristics of the messages	enumerated in table 1	3951.8160993693855
80. great stress is placed on the role that	the monitoring of information sending plays in maintaining the effectiveness	of the network	3035.500661647282
81. by monitoring we mean some system of control	over the types of information sent from the various centers	1570.9901888644688
82. as a word of caution we should be aware that in actual practice no	message is purely one of the four types question command statement	or exclamation	4286.758848585546
83. for example suppose a man wearing a $200 watch driving	a 1959 rolls royce stops to ask a man on the sidewalk what	time is it	2722.43861157008
84. this sentence would have most of the characteristics	of a question but it has some of the characteristics of a statement	because the questioner has conveyed the fact that he has no faith in	his own timepiece or the one attached to his car	6818.656431236406
85. if the man on the	sidewalk is surprised at this question it has served as an exclamation	1415.4635804904135
86. also since the man questioned feels a strong compulsion to answer	the question	has assumed some measurable properties of a command	3045.294609852427
87. however for	convenience we will stick to the idea that information can be classified	according to table 1	1565.596072314896
88. on this basis certain extreme kinds of networks	will be discussed for illustrative purposes	1408.0195194702496
89. some special types of organization	presumably a cocktail party is expected to fulfill the host's desire	to get together a number of people who are inadequately acquainted	and thereby arrange for bringing the level of acquaintance up to adequacy	for future cooperative endeavors	4453.1545553969445
90. the party is usually in a room	small enough so that all guests are within sight and hearing of one another	3046.189257797613
91. the information is furnished by each of the guests is sent by	oral broadcasting over the air waves and is received by the ears	2474.9252767319394
92. since	the air is a continuum the network of communication remains intact	regardless of the positions or motions of the points	in the net	3712.7499263003506
93. as shown in figure 1 there is a connection for communication	between every pair of points	1262.2809987703472
94. this and other qualifications make	the cocktail party the most complete and most chaotic communication	system ever dreamed up	2591.2402383338904
95. all four types of message listed in table	1 are permitted although decorum and cocktail tradition require holding	the commands to a minimum while exclamations having complimentary	intonations are more than customarily encouraged	3559.402220005497
96. the completeness	of the connections provide that for n people there are f	lines of communication between the pairs which can become a large number	for a party of fifty guests	4978.442584711719
97. looking at the diagram we	see that f connection lines come in to each member	1089.0508588314246
98. thus the cocktail	party would appear to be the ideal system but there is one weakness	1879.159321954316
99. in spite of the dreams of the host for oneness in the group the	f incoming messages for each guest overload his receiving system beyond	comprehension if n exceeds about six	3320.2173430203998
100. the crowd consequently	breaks up into temporary groups ranging in size from two to six with	a half-life for the cluster ranging from three to twenty minutes	4304.800369918588
101. for the occasion on which everyone already knows everyone else	and the host wishes them to meet one or a few honored newcomers then	the open house system is advantageous because the honored guests	are fixed connective points and the drifting guests make and break connections	at the door	4911.656405359432
102. we consider a rural	community as an assemblage of inhabited dwellings whose configuration	is determined by the location and size of the arable land sites necessary	for family subsistence	4660.261589940177
103. we assume for this illustration that the	size of the land plots is so great that the distance between dwellings	is greater than the voice can carry and that most of the communication	is between nearest neighbors only as shown in figure 2	4476.01263779972
104. information	beyond nearest neighbor is carried second- third- and fourth-hand	as a distortable rumor	1413.1958170987425
105. in figure 2 the points in the network are	designated by a letter accompanied by a number	1417.4343033095927
106. the numbers indicate	the number of nearest neighbors	250.41720120303233
107. it will be noted that point f	has seven nearest neighbors h and e have six and p	has only one while the remaining points have intermediate numbers	2996.0196221969554
108. in any social system in which communications have an importance	comparable with that of production and other human factors a point	like f in figure 2 would be the dwelling	place for the community leader while e and h would	house the next most important citizens	7001.214602112654
109. a point like p gets	information directly from n but all information beyond n	is indirectly relayed through n	1713.3999248080243
110. the dweller at p is	last to hear about a new cure the slowest to announce to his neighbors	his urgent distresses the one who goes the farthest to trade and the	one with the greatest difficulty of all in putting over an idea or	getting people to join him in a cooperative effort	7812.689557511161
111. since the hazards	of poor communication are so great p can be justified as a habitable	site only on the basis of unusual productivity such as is made	available by a waterfall for milling purposes a mine or a sugar maple	camp	4420.571386423014
112. location theorists have given these matters much consideration	251.3565232928982
113. the networks for military communications	are one of the best examples of networks which not only must be	changed with the changes in objectives but also must be changed with the	addition of new machines of war	3937.853215420656
114. they also furnish proof that in	modern war message sending must be monitored	1175.6813552585568
115. without monitoring a	military hookup becomes a noisy party	260.23389224916787
116. the need for monitoring became	greater when radio was adopted for military signaling	1178.8755064711138
117. alexander the	great who used runners as message carriers did not have to worry about	having every officer in his command hear what he said and having	hundreds of them comment at once	3545.473114111011
118. as time has passed and science has	progressed the speed of military vehicles has increased the range of	missiles has been extended the use of target-hunting noses on the projectiles	has been adopted and the range and breadth of message sending	has increased	6694.41218115801
119. next to the old problem of the slowness of decision	making network structure seems to be paramount and without monitoring	no network has value	2452.7829757864683
120. on the parade ground the net may be similar	to that shown in figure 3	1638.134524943211
121. the monitoring is the highest and	most restrictive of any organization in existence	782.6959134455312
122. no questions statements	or explanations are permitted- only commands	397.0563002464661
123. commands go only	from an officer to the man of nearest lower rank	792.7457962446044
124. the same command	is repeated as many times as there are levels in rank from general to	corporal	2377.1396547826603
125. all orders originate with the officer of highest rank and	terminate with action of the men in the ranks	1734.878487569665
126. even the officer in charge	be it a captain or a general is restrained	by monitoring	1893.596421405482
127. this is done for simplicity of commands and to bring the	hidden redundancy up to where misunderstanding has almost zero possibility	2024.966955779701
128. the commands are specified by the military regulations; are	few in number briefly worded all different in sound; and are combinable	into sequences which permit any marching maneuver that could be	desired on a parade ground	5767.029482699645
129. this monitoring is necessary because on	a parade ground everyone can hear too much and without monitoring	a confused social event would develop	2330.3938051654945
130. with troops dispersed	on fields of battle rather than on the parade ground it may seem that	a certain amount of monitoring is automatically enforced by the lines	of communication	4817.389625099721
131. years ago this was true but with the replacement	of wires or runners by radio and radar these	restrictions have disappeared and now again too much is heard	2994.541658906461
132. in contrast to cocktail parties military organizations even	in the field are more formal	1428.2547004464097
133. in the extreme and oversimplified example	suggested in figure 3 the organization is more easily understood	and more predictable in behavior	2033.9985595323603
134. a military organization has an objective	chosen by the higher command	756.8163813330362
135. this objective is adhered to throughout	the duration of the action	504.85650823147927
136. the connective system or network	is tailored to meet the requirements of the objective and it is therefore	not surprising that a military body acting as a single coordinated	unit has a different communication network than a factory a college	or a rural village	6855.29738043579
137. the assumptions upon which the example	shown	in figure 3 is based are: one man can direct about six subordinates	if the subordinates are chosen carefully so that they do not	need too much personal coaching indoctrinating etc	4051.5677888739165
138. a message	runs too great a risk of being distorted if it is to be relayed more	than about six consecutive times	3264.789582870988
139. decisions of a general kind	are made by the central command	503.49138183803234
140. and all action of a physical kind	pertinent to the mission is relegated to the line of men on the lower	rank	3271.58533236703
141. these assumptions lead to an organization with one man at the	top six directly under him six under each of these and so on until	there are six levels of personnel	3333.0366005516653
142. the number of people acting as one	body by this scheme gives a surprisingly large army of f 55987	men	2813.1372947879
143. this organizational network would be of no avail if there	were no regulations pertaining to the types of message sent	1878.5814271224892
144. of types	of message listed in table 1 commands and statements are the only	ones sent through the vertical network shown in figure 3	3700.259235823474
145. a further	regulation is that commands always go down unaccompanied by statements	and statements always go up unaccompanied by commands	1899.9587571642119
146. questions	and particularly exclamations are usually channeled along informal	horizontal lines not indicated in figure 3 and seldom are carried	beyond the nearest neighbor	3680.7053217783564
147. it will readily be seen that	in this suggested network	greater emphasis on monitoring is implied than	is usually put into practice	2174.72888896237
148. furthermore the network in figure	3 is only the basic net through which other networks pertaining to logistics	and the like are interlaced	3495.8038957728045
149. not discussed here are some	military problems of modern times such as undersea warfare where the	surveillance sending transmitting and receiving are all so inadequate	that networks and decision making are not the bottlenecks	3662.657665910077
150. such	problems are of extreme interest as well as importance and are so much	like fighting in a rain forest or guerrilla warfare at night in tall	grass that we might have to re-examine primitive conflicts for what they	could teach	6444.476297580752
151. this is an unsolved	problem which probably has never been seriously investigated although	one frequently hears the comment that we have insufficient specialists	of the kind who can compete with the germans or swiss for example	in precision machinery and mathematics or the finns in geochemistry	4683.876393105873
152. we hear equally fervent concern over the belief that we have	not enough generalists who can see the over-all picture and combine	our national skills and knowledge for useful purposes	4834.598009088602
153. this problem	of the optimum balance in the relative numbers of generalists and	specialists can be investigated on a communicative network basis	2173.700624607919
154. since	the difficulty of drawing the net is great we will merely discuss	it	1415.8313668335509
155. first we realize that a pure specialist does not exist	374.6799225756334
156. but	for practical purposes we have people who can be considered as such	1178.806176376307
157. for example there are persons who are in physical science in the	field of mineralogy trained in crystallography who use only x-rays	applying only the powder technique of x-ray diffraction to clay	minerals only and who have spent the last fifteen years concentrating	on the montmorillonites; or persons in the social sciences in the	field of anthropology studying the lung capacity of seven andean	indians	5759.19361969943
158. so we see that a specialist is a man who knows more and more	about less and less as he develops as contrasted to the generalist	who knows less and less about more and more	5651.662303599811
159. american democratic thought pointed up the relation between the	protestant movement in this country and the development of a social	religion which he called the american democratic faith	2980.655214778274
160. those familiar	with his work will remember that he placed the incipience of the	democratic faith at around 1850	2590.0575961646427
161. and he describes it as a balanced polarity	between the notions of the free individual and what he called	the fundamental law	2178.3674676211263
162. i want to say more about gabriel's so-called	fundamental law	564.0736849313585
163. but first i want to quote him on the relationship	that he found between religion and politics in this country and	what happened to it	2581.128385770806
164. he points out that from the time of jackson on	through world war 1 evangelical protestantism was a dominant influence	in the social and political life of america	4471.363518968852
165. he terms this	early enthusiasm romantic christianity and concludes that its	similarity to democratic beliefs of that day is so great that the doctrine	of liberty seems but a secular version of its counterpart in evangelical	protestantism	3936.766135212194
166. let me quote him even more fully for his	analysis is important to my theme	1646.0590779639158
167. he says: beside the	protestant philosophy of progress as expressed in radical or conservative	millenarianism should be placed the doctrine of the democratic	faith which affirmed it to be the duty of the destiny of the united	states to assist in the creation of a better world by keeping lighted	the beacon of democracy	5192.958053940647
168. he specifies in the middle period	of the nineteenth century it was colored by christian supernaturalism	in the twentieth century it was affected by naturalism	3884.0798013490376
169. but in	every period it has been humanism	167.0279150708308
170. and let me add utopianism also	65.4994044250023
171. some fourteen or fifteen years ago in an essay i called	the leader follows- where	1104.44840255248
172. i used his polarity to illustrate	what i thought had happened to us in that form of liberalism we call	progressivism	3026.5612072561853
173. it seemed to me that the liberals had scrapped the	balanced polarity and reposed both liberty and the fundamental law	in the common man	2458.442454761682
174. that is to say gabriel's fundamental law had been	so much modified by this time that it was neither fundamental nor	law any more	3665.99896787991
175. it is a weakness of gabriel's analysis that he never	seems to realize that his so-called fundamental law had already been	cut loose from its foundations when it was adapted to democracy	3420.2141244921477
176. and	with progressivism the religion of humanity was replacing what gabriel	called christian supernaturalism	1401.9932315298415
177. and the common man was developing	mythic power or charisma on his own	789.0902256716274
178. during the decade	that followed the common man as that piece put it grew uncomfortable	as the voice of god and fled from behind saint woodrow	only to learn from science to his shocked relief that after all there	was no god he had to speak for and that he was just an animal anyhow-	that there was a chemical formula for him and that too much couldn't	be expected of him	0.30166232349522504
179. the socialism implicit in the slogan	of the roosevelt revolution freedom from want and fear seems a	far cry from the individualism of the first amendment to the constitution	or of the jacksonian frontier	3664.0304118054496
180. what had happened to the common	man	139.46534667606238
181. french egalitarianism had had only nominal influence	in this country before the days of popularism	1102.6690347969636
182. the riotous onrush	of industrialism after the war for southern independence and the general	secular drift to the religion of humanity however prepared	the way for a reception of the french revolution's socialistic offspring	of one sort of another	6200.361612362167
183. the first of which to find important place	in our federal government was the graduated income tax under wilson	1727.5595766003746
184. moreover the centralization of our economy during the 1920s the	dislocations of the depression the common ethos of materialism everywhere	all contributed in various ways to the face-lifting that replaced	mike fink and the great gatsby with the anonymous physiognomy	of the little people	6794.998977898897
185. however it is important to trace the	philosophy of the french revolution to its sources to understand the	common democratic origin of individualism and socialism and the influence	of the latter on the former	3664.635524047586
186. that john locke's philosophy of	the social contract fathered the american revolution with its declaration	of independence i believe we generally accept	3272.741278210148
187. yet after	rousseau had given the social contract a new twist with his notion	of the general will the same philosophy it may be said became	the idea source of the french revolution also	3673.6586097195163
188. the importance	of rousseau's twist has not always been clear to us however	1173.6548094019042
189. this	notion of the general will gave rise to the commune of paris in	the revolution and later brought napoleon to dictatorship	2184.6791582837177
190. and it	is clearly argued by lord percy of newcastle in his remarkable long	essay the heresy of democracy and in a more general way by	voegelin in his new science of politics that this same rousseauan	idea descending through european democracy is the source of	marx's theory of the dictatorship of the proletariat	7750.7782227153275
191. this is important	to understanding the position that doctrinaire liberals found themselves	in after world war 2 and our great democratic victory	that brought no peace	2727.672234449434
192. the long road that had taken liberals in	this country into the social religion of democracy into a worship of	man led logically to the marxist dream of a classless society under	a socialist state	5637.975263270049
193. and the ussr existed as the revolutionary	experiment in radical socialism the ultimate exemplar	945.3322589743445
194. and by the	time the war ended liberal leadership in this country was spiritually	marxist	1637.1069585077462
195. we will recall that the still confident liberals of	the truman administration gathered with other western utopians in	san francisco to set up the legal framework finally and at last to	rationalize war- to rationalize want and fear- out of the world:	the united nations	4596.411264459993
196. we of the liberal-led world got all set for peace	and rehabilitation	967.3283183428923
197. then suddenly we found ourselves in the middle	of another fight an irrational an indecent an undeclared and immoral	war with our strongest ally	2456.966980108922
198. during the next five years the leaders of the fair deal reluctantly	backed down from the optimistic expectations of the new deal	3269.289801984285
199. during	the next five years liberal leaders in the united states sank in	the cumulative confusion attendant upon and manifested in a negative	policy of containment- and the bitterest irony- enforced and enforceable	only by threat of a weapon that we felt the greatest distaste	for but could not abandon: the atom bomb	5147.53485649832
