414. the stepmother almost without exception has been presented	as a cruel ogress	962.7697078014687
415. children conditioned by this mistaken notion	have feared stepmothers while adults by their antagonistic attitudes	have made the role of the substitute parents a difficult one	2723.7686874068486
416. debate	is not likely to resolve the tensions and make the lot of the stepchild	a happier one	2364.5362246694785
417. research on the other hand has shown many stepmothers	to be eminently successful some far better than the real mothers	1881.200619484495
418. helen deutsch informed us	that in all cultures the term 'stepmother'	automatically evokes deprecatory implications a conclusion accepted	by many	2811.588679979027
419. will mere debate on that proposition even though it be	free and untrammeled remove the dross and leave a residue of refined	gold	2322.210089473658
420. that is questionable to say the least	140.78947281116874
421. research into several	cultures has proven her position to be a mistaken one	790.8641929948884
422. most	assuredly ideas are invaluable	22.23852096074889
423. but ideas just for the sake of having	them are not enough	637.966934338757
424. in the 1930's cures for the depression literally	flooded washington	560.0564288353394
425. for a time the president received hundreds	of them every day most of them worthless	1097.371406988492
426. ideas need to be	tested and not merely by argument and debate	964.271758787165
427. when some question arises	in the medical field concerning cancer for instance we do not	turn to free and open discussion as in a political campaign	2742.784424964783
428. we have	recourse to the scientifically-trained specialist in the laboratory	560.2240546778933
429. the	merits of the salk anti-polio vaccine were not established on the	forensic platform or in newspaper editorials but in the laboratory	and by tests in the field on thousands of children	3447.1968703274133
430. our presidential	campaigns provide much debate and argument	252.20725484139493
431. but is the result	new barnsful of tested knowledge on the basis of which we can with confidence	solve our domestic and international problems	2454.388233534206
432. man we are	told is endowed with reason and is capable of distinguishing good from	bad	1882.9938666223502
433. but what a super-herculean task it is to winnow anything of value	from the mud-beplastered arguments used so freely particularly since	such common use is made of cliches and stereotypes in themselves	declarations of intellectual bankruptcy	3842.282004598742
434. we are reminded however	that freedom of thought and discussion the unfettered exchange	of ideas is basic under our form of government	3266.1536779690805
435. assuredly in	our political campaigns there is freedom to think to examine any and	all issues and to speak without restraint	2015.591059747654
436. but	have the results been heartening	65.19303240462878
437. may we state with confidence that	in such an exhibition a republic will find its greatest security	1413.4373030728034
438. we must not forget to be sure that free discussion and debate	have produced beneficial results	1886.2880276497303
439. in truth we can say that this broke	the power of senator joseph mccarthy who was finally exposed	in full light to the american people	2582.197896637643
440. if he had been liquidated	in some way he would have become a martyr a rallying point for people	who shared his ideas	3479.9969437995896
441. debate in the political arena can be productive	of good	372.97583058771033
442. but it is a clumsy and wasteful process: it can produce	negative results but not much that is positive	2589.2783026212373
443. debate rid us of	mccarthy but did not give us much that is positive	934.2199406779021
444. it did something	to clear the ground but it erected no striking new structure; it	did not even provide the architect's plan for anything new	3887.895138497758
445. in the field of the natural sciences scientifically verified data are	quite readily available and any discussion can be shortened with good	results	2320.6522777807995
446. in the field of the social sciences a considerable fund of	tested knowledge has been accumulated that can be used to good advantage	3472.1599816472326
447. by no means would we discourage the production of ideas:	they provide raw materials with which to work; they provide stimulations	that lead to further production	2740.4695961788757
448. we would establish no censorship	22.226251423858294
449. the president's personality would have opened that office to him	374.2564447425615
450. and for the first time a representative of the highest office in the	land would have been liable to the charge that he had attempted to make	it a successorship by inheritance	5181.252287392317
451. it is testimony to the deep respect	in which mr eisenhower was held by members of all parties that	the moral considerations raised by his approach to the matter were	not explicitly to be broached	3734.02722476671
452. these began to be apparent in a	press conference held during the second illness in order that the consulting	specialists might clarify the president's condition for the	nation	4476.3734746158825
453. and if howard rutstein felt impelled thereafter to formulate	the ethics of the medical profession his article in the atlantic	monthly accomplished a good deal more	2731.364118034584
454. it forced us to fix the responsibility	for the position in which all medical commentators had been	placed	2350.1524496504576
455. the discussion of professional ethics inevitably reminded	us that in the historical perspective the president's decision will	finally clarify itself as a moral rather than a medical problem	2989.69959253336
456. because	the responsibility for resolving the issue lay with the president	rather than with his doctors nothing raises more surely for us	the difficulties simple goodness faces in dealing with complex moral problems	under political pressure	5771.448639832444
457. for the president had dealt with the	matter humbly in what he conceived as the democratic way	1423.9454774739645
458. but the	problem is one which gives us the measure of a man rather than a group	of men whether a group of doctors a group of party members assembled	at a dinner to give their opinion or the masses of the voters	6694.91704744273
459. any attempt to reconcile this statement of the central issue in	the campaign of 1956 with the nature of the man who could not conceive	it as the central issue will at least resolve our confusions about the	chaotic and misleading results of the earnestness of both doctors and	president in a situation which should never have arisen	5415.016586984355
460. it was a	response to the conflict between political pressure and the moral intuition	which resulted in attempts at prediction	2810.3042503685483
461. in no other situation	would a group of doctors struggling competently to improve the life	expectancy of a man beloved by the world be subjected to such merciless	and persistent questioning and before they were prepared to demonstrate	the kind of verbal precision which alone can clarify for mankind	the problems it faces	5135.661574438833
462. and though we can look back now and see their	errors we can look back also to the ultimate error	2843.582193925784
463. it recurred	in the press conferences: the president's remarks about his running	developed a singular tone one which we find in few statements	made by public individuals on such a matter	3355.2993950212576
464. the press conference became	a stage which betrayed the drift of his private thinking rather than	his convictions	2354.4753379947365
465. he commented- thoughtfully a reporter told us-	that it was not too important for the individual how he ends up	1864.3878807275591
466. he gave us a simile to explain his admission that even at the worst	period of his second illness it never occurred to him there was any	renewed question about his running: as in the battle of the bulge	he had no fears about the outcome until he read the american newspapers	7622.684969303407
467. yet the attitude that the fate of the presidency demands in such	a situation is quite distinct from the simple courage that can proceed	with battles to be fought regardless of the consequences	3558.4202941743924
468. in this	case others should not have had to raise the doubts and fears	1418.73132594764
469. the	presidency demands an incisive awareness of the larger implications	of the death of any incumbent	1250.054325853489
470. it is of the utmost importance to the	people of america and of the world how their governing president ends	up during the four years of his term	4461.280260445596
471. only when that term is	ended and he is a private citizen again can he be permitted the freedom	and the courage to discount the dangers of his death	3121.575613857778
472. ironically enough	in this instance such personal virtues were a luxury	750.1871239298629
473. at	the national and international level then what is the highest kind	of morality for the private citizen represents an instance of political	immorality	2462.362859105853
474. and we had the uneasy sense that the cleavage between the	moral and the political progressed amid the events which concern us	3266.6958790297795
475. for the tone of the editorials which greeted mr eisenhower's	original announcement of his running had been strangely disquieting	1718.1465699878718
476. neither the vibrant enthusiasm which bespeaks a people's intuitive	sense of the fitness of things at climactic moments nor the vital argumentation	betraying its sense that something significant has transpired	was in evidence	5324.521809478871
477. nothing testifies more clearly to that cleavage than	the peculiar editorial page appearing in a july issue of life magazine	the issue which also carried the second announcement of the	candidacy	3328.120462525755
478. the double editorial on two aspects of the u s	spirit was subtly calculated to suggest a moral sanction for gambles	great as well as small reflecting popular approval of this questionable	attitude toward the highest office in the land	6323.649563286068
479. the moral	creed and the will to risk live happily together if we	do not examine where the line is to be drawn	2325.87005656813
480. i may possibly be a	greater risk than is the normal person of my age the president had	said on february 29th of the election year ignoring the fact that	no one of his age had ever lived out another term	6451.993570777954
481. my doctors assure	me that this increased percentage of risk is not great	783.0125141536929
482. but by	the time the risk was doubled events had dismissed from his mind both	increased percentages and a previously stated intention of considering	carefully anything more serious than a bout of influenza	5355.874627021254
483. only infrequently	did the situation color his thinking	166.72819050097226
484. ironically no president	we have had would have regretted more than president eisenhower the	possibility to which his own words in the press conference held at	the beginning of august testified: that unable as he was himself	to say his running was best for the country unconsciously he had placed	his party before his nation	7882.664023840317
485. so it is that we relive his opening	statement in the first television address with the dramatic immediacy	of the present	2025.74415497651
486. no consideration of risk urges itself upon him	now: for this is what the mind does with the ideas on which it has not	properly focussed	4109.424869321478
487. yet with a mind less shallow if less sharp than	some of the fortune-happy syndicates which back him he feels what	he cannot formulate; and we watch him amid the overtones which suggest	he could never in any conscience urge a risk upon the voters	4609.374545424706
488. moving	as he is into the phase of the campaign which demands conviction of	him he adopts a position that is morally indefensible	3473.430263533474
489. he ascribes	to the mercy of god the peace which this personal matter- the assurance	that he can physically sustain the burden of the office longer	than any individual in the history of our nation has been able to do-	has brought him	4468.735885334254
490. what is simply an opinion formed in defiance of the	laws of human probability whether or not it is later confirmed has	become by september of the election year a firm conviction	5143.634265237067
491. as	a means of silencing a discussion which ought to have taken place the	statement is an effective one: we sympathize with the universal confusion	which gives rise to such convictions	3339.915201833007
492. but it is also the climax	to one of the absorbing chapters in our current political history	2120.9352273925915
493. in assigning to god the responsibility which he learned could	not rest with his doctors eisenhower gave evidence of that weakening	of the moral intuition which was to characterize his administration	in the years to follow	3830.8381717920192
494. in any other man this reassurance to the electorate	would have caused us a profound moral shock	2112.7578312695923
495. about this man we	had to think twice	166.9873150854212
496. we knew that it was as reassurance the ironic	fruit of a deeply moral nature	1644.4863732234542
497. but the fact remains that even the unconscious	acceptance of himself as a man of destiny divinely protected	must be censored in any man who evades the responsibility for his major	decisions and thus for imposing his will on the people	4290.2605245680825
498. and in the	context of drifting personal utterances we have examined there was	occasional evidence of the origin of all such evasions	3247.025862688732
499. when the possibility	that he had not given reconsideration to so weighty a decision	seemed	to disconcert his questioners mr eisenhower was known to	make his characteristic statement to the press that he was not going	to talk about the matter any more	4437.3732111643785
500. thinking had stopped; it was not	to be resumed	387.0084196940246
501. the portrait that had developed fragmentarily	but consistently was the portrait of a man to whom serious thinking	is alien enough that the making of a decision inhibits when it does not	forestall any ability to review the decision in the light of new evidence	4595.4895497244615
502. this does not mean that the decision to run for office should	inevitably have been revoked	1879.7611791485483
503. instead it means that the thinking in	which decision issues has the power to determine the morality of the	decision as in this instance the pressure for renewed practical or legislative	attention to the constitutional problems the decision had uncovered	might have done	4473.838645675913
504. drifting through a third illness apparently	without any provision for the handling of a major national emergency	other than a talk with the vice-president eisenhower revealed the singularly	static quality of his thinking	5325.58934835243
505. despite three warnings no	sense of moral urgency impelled him to distinguish his situation and	thus his responsibilities from wilson's	1888.6685762640325
506. by contrast the	energetic reaction of the leader to the full demands his decision imposes	upon him strengthens the moral intuition and gives us the measure	of the man	4658.754781515643
507. only by means of an intensive preoccupation with the detailed	considerations following from any decision can he ensure attention	to the practical details to be dealt with if the implications of immorality	in the major decision are effectively to be checked	4294.033353344758
508. in the	incessant struggle with recalcitrant political fact he learns to focus	the essence of a problem in the significant detail and to articulate	the distinctions which clarify the detail as significant with what	is sometimes astounding rapidity	6083.43574384361
509. like lincoln he can distinguish	his relation to god from the constitutional responsibilities a questionable	decision exacts of him	1731.2013844607718
510. like roosevelt he can distinguish an	attitude toward a russian leader he may share with a host of americans	from the responsibilities diplomatic convention may impose upon him	4477.489369423596
511. he chooses to subordinate one to the other sometimes reluctantly	accepting criticism for the lesser immoralities facts breed	1580.3411934465266
512. the very	nature of a choice so grounded in distinction and fact leads to the	valid convictions which become force of will in the manifest leader	4092.6031281715927
513. the capacity for making the distinctions of which diplomacy is compact	and the facility with language which can render them into validity	in the eyes of other men are the leader's means for transforming the	moral intuition into moral leadership	4236.034850192516
514. the making of distinctions	like the perception of the great distinctions made is an inordinately	difficult business	2145.2413982704106
515. lincoln's slow progress towards the several	marking his achievement is even now unrecognizable as such and loosely	interpreted as the alternation of inconsistency with vision	2618.4832884304815
516. but	because it is the function of the mind to turn the one into the other	by means of the capacities with which words endow it we do not unwisely	examine the type of distinction in the sphere of politics on which	decisions hang	6815.4606237059
517. only recently and perhaps because a television debate	can so effectively dramatize president kennedy's extraordinary	mastery of detail have the abilities on which the capacity for making	distinctions depend begun to be clearly discernible at the level of	politics	4141.749599963439
518. in his recent evaluation of kennedy's potentialities for	leadership walter lippmann has cited the precision of his mind	his immense command of factual detail and his instinct for	the crucial point as impressive in the extreme; and it is surely	clear that the first of these is the result of the way in which the	individual's command of language interacts with the other two	8543.000425656084
519. for this change is not a change from one positive position to another	but a change from order and truth to disorder and negation	2471.185461341147
520. the	liberal-conservative	division we might observe in passing is not of itself	directly involved in a private interest conflict nor even in struggle	between ruling groups	4099.734788132495
521. rather it is rooted in a difference of response	to the threat of social disintegration	1091.4502733374784
522. the division is not between	those who wish to preserve what they have and those who want change	2318.0399000313273
523. rather it is a division established by two absolutely different ways	of thought with regard to man's life in society	1875.9313766606342
524. these ways are	absolutely irreconcilable because they offer two different recipes for	man's redemption from chaos	1878.0703658973725
525. the civilizational crisis the	third type of change raises the question what are we to do	1256.1958304279847
526. on the most primitive level	22.135705667643883
527. for the answer cannot be derived from any	socially cohesive element in the disrupting community	1092.2759384882172
528. there is no	socially existential answer to the question	390.7259442584965
529. for the truth formerly experienced	by the community no longer has existential status in the community	nor does any answer elaborated by philosophers or theoriticians	2590.3264893562673
530. in this phase of change no idea has social acceptance and so none	has ontological status in the community	2589.484973158723
531. an interregnum ensues in which	not men but ideas compete for existence	638.5561388165694
532. if we examine the	three types of change from the point of view of their internal structure	we find an additional profound difference between the third and the	first two one that accounts for the notable difference between the	responses they evoke	6570.979666201788
533. the first two types of change occur within the	inward and immanent structure of the society	1255.8427385620712
534. the first involves a simple	shift of interests in the society	757.1783357186976
535. the second involves something	deeper but its characteristic form focuses on a shift in policy for	the community not in the truth on which the community rests	2862.321727753792
536. thus in	both types attention is focused on the community itself and its phenomenological	life	1652.5734467921266
537. the third type however wrenches attention from	the life of action and interests in the community and focuses it on the	ground of being on which the community depends for its existence	3433.9509492983575
538. voegelin	has analyzed this experience in the case of the stable healthy	community	1171.420885204627
539. there the community faced with the need to formulate policy	on the level of absolute justice can find the answer to its problem	in the absolute truth which it holds as partially experienced	3540.6836492844923
540. this	however cannot be done by a community whose very experience of truth	is confused and incoherent: it has no absolute standard and consequently	cannot distinguish the absolute from the contingent	5016.755476077229
541. it has	lost its ground of being and floats in a mist of appearances	938.530609275798
542. relativism	and equality are its characteristic diseases	140.0901065214353
543. precisely at the moment	when it has lost its vision the mind of the community turns out	from itself in a search for the ontological standard whereby it can measure	itself	3325.1824476677307
544. for paradigmatic history breaks rather than unfolds	precisely when the movement is from order to disorder and not from	one order to a new order	3908.3737999818695
545. the liberal-conservative split to define	it further derives from a basic difference concerning the existential	status of standard sought and about the spiritual experience that leads	to its identification	3118.391705446958
546. when disruptive change has penetrated	to the third level of social order the process of disruption rapidly	reaches a point of no return	3474.272251237602
547. indeed it is probable that this point	is reached the moment the third level of change begins	1407.3344776616104
548. at that point	we reach the closed historical situation: the situation in	which man is no longer free to return to a status quo ante	3899.7344679277703
549. at that	point men become aware of the mystery of history called variously fate	or destiny or providence and feel themselves	caught helplessly in the writhing of a disrupted society	3239.636026437886
550. the reasons	for this experience are rooted in the metaphysical characteristics of	such a change	1643.1628999473596
551. of all forms of being society or community	has the greatest element of determinability	944.0658039147199
552. its ontological status is	itself most tenuous because apart from individual men who are its matter	tradition the form of society exists only as a shared	perception of truth	4682.374176964584
553. the ontological status of society thus is constituted	by the psychological-intellectual-volitional status of society's	members	1098.7954901730989
554. the content of that psychological status determines	ultimately the content of civilization	962.9572245060741
555. those social civilizational	factors not rooted in the human spirit of the group ultimately cease	to exist	1416.2325117578343
556. civilization itself- tradition- falls out of existence	when the human spirit itself becomes confused	1404.193012286998
557. civilization is what	man has made of himself	166.61065118981787
558. its massive contours are rooted in the simple	need of man since he is always incomplete to complete himself	2579.344521755548
559. it is not enough for man to be an ontological esse	497.8090605151427
560. he needs existential	completion he needs that is to move in the direction of completion	1634.7594771533497
561. and the direction of that movement is determined by his perception	of the truth about himself	1251.207746421787
562. he must consequently exist as a	self-perceived substantive developing agent or he does not exist as	man	2134.479988575091
563. thus it is no mystical intuition but an analyzable conception	to say that man and his tradition can fall out of existence	2167.804863374471
564. this	happens at the moment man loses the perception of moral substance	in himself of a nature that in maritain's words is perceived as	a locus of intelligible necessities	4645.786208204097
565. an existentialist is a man	who perceives himself only as esse as existence without substance	1095.820135774932
566. thus human perception and human volition is the immanent	cause of all social change and this most truly when the change reaches	the civilizational level	3888.1562401516885
567. thus with regard to the loss of tradition	in the change from order to disorder the metaphysics of change works	itself out as a disruption of the individual soul a change in which man	continues as an objective ontological existent but no longer as a	man	4689.621240323232
568. further change is a form of motion it occurs as the act	of a being in potency insofar as it is in potency and has not yet reached	the terminus of the change	5331.513607095062
569. with regard to the change we are examining	the question is at what point does the change become irreversible	1724.4097957831327
570. a number of considerations suggest that this occurs early in	the process	957.3805021048305
571. change involves the displacement of form	43.70440485417869
572. this means that	the inception of change itself can begin only when the factors conducive	to change have already become more powerful than those anchoring	the existent form in being	4828.1574007326435
573. if the existent form is to be retained new	factors that reinforce it must be introduced into the situation	1725.9234003957044
574. in	the case of social decay form is displaced simply by the process of	dissolution with no form at the terminus of the process	3689.7677335419407
575. now in the	mere fact of the beginning of such displacement we have prima-facie evidence	of the ontological weakness of the fading form	2315.9239020436053
576. and when we consider	the tenuous hold tradition has on existence any weakening of that	hold constitutes a crisis of existence	3051.5047863461564
577. the retention of a tradition	confronted with such a crisis necessitates the introduction of new	spiritual forces into the situation	1890.585580732812
578. however the crisis occurs precisely	as a weakening of spiritual forces	753.665640778429
579. it would seem therefore that	in a civilizational crisis man cannot save himself	787.0516342775413
580. the emergence	of the crisis itself would seem to constitute a warranty for the victory	of disorder	2133.5769816818834
581. and it would seem that history is a witness to this	truth	640.2884012057318
582. as a further characterization of the liberal conservative	split we may observe that it involves differences in the formula for	escaping inevitabilities in history	3667.5449449651096
583. these differences in turn derive	from prior differences concerning the friendly or hostile character	of change	1256.7342480433244
584. anxiety and deep insecurity	are the characteristic responses evoked by the crisis in tradition	1419.9708859882762
585. to experience them it is not necessary for a people to be actively	aware of what is happening to it	1870.8942046712727
586. the process of erosion need only	undermine the tradition and a series of consequences begin unfolding	within the individual while in institutions a quiet but deep transformation	of processes occurs	4827.387810104777
587. within the individual the reaction has been	called various names all however pointing to the same basic experience	1569.3526547026722
588. weil identifies it as being rootless guardini as being	placeless riesman as being lonely	1430.5305347602502
589. others call it alienation	and mean by that no simple economic experience	but a deep spiritual sense of dislocation	1728.8089299061835
590. within institutions	there is a marked decline of the process of persuasion and the substitution	of a force-fear process which masquerades as the earlier one	of persuasion	4308.195285567063
591. we note the use of rhetoric as a weapon the manipulation	of the masses by propaganda the mobilization of effort and	resources	2185.8036363275874
592. within this context of spontaneous and unanalyzed	responses to the experience of civilizational crisis two basic organizations	of response are observable: reaction and ideological progressivism	3904.8446209617714
593. these responses are explicable in terms of characteristics inherent	in the crisis	640.0634489817587
594. both are predictably destined to fail	65.05752903599154
595. the	response of reaction is dominated by a concern for what is vanishing	791.0959096982245
596. its essence lies in its attempt to recover previous order through	the repression of disruptive forces	1883.8464899358594
597. to this end political authority	is called upon to exercise its negative and coercive powers	1097.5503263460491
598. the implicit	assumption of this response is that history is reversible	745.8912762971898
599. seemingly	order is perceived as a kind of subsistent entity now covered by	adventitious accretions	1097.8453507204306
600. the problem is to remove the accretions and	thereby uncover the order that was always there	1869.208710475709
601. such a response of	course misses the point that in crisis order is going out of existence	1402.1197696075792
602. moreover its posture of stubborn but simple resistance is doomed	to failure because of the metaphysical weakness of the existent form of	order once the activation of change has reached visible proportions	5155.497812362513
603. the most reaction can achieve is stasis and a stasis that can be maintained	only by the expenditure of an effort which ultimately exhausts	itself	2607.4303273249216
604. despite the hopelessness of the response it is explicable	in terms of the crisis of tradition itself	2114.4209602428605
605. since a civilizational	crisis involves also a crisis in private interests and in the ruling	class reaction is normally found among those who feel themselves	to be among the ruling class	3356.502772959671
606. their great error is to mingle the responses	typical of each of the three types of change	2116.508059312105
607. since civilizational	change is the most difficult to perceive and analyze it seldom is	given adequate attention	1409.754569161522
608. and the anxiety it generates is misinterpreted	as anxiety over private interest and threatened social status	1902.1170583558396
609. the basic truth in the reactionary response is to be found in its	realistic assumption of the primacy of the real over the ideational	2463.506642924761
610. but this truth is distorted by its extreme application: the assumption	of the separate existence of tradition	2119.670596397842
611. the reactionary misses	the point that tradition exists ontologically only in the form of	psychological-intellectual	relations	1259.284632783963
612. reactionary theories for this reason	usually assume some form of organismic theory	962.2013735690027
613. in its defensive	formulations the theory will attack conscious change on the grounds of	the independent existence of the community	1876.983138230385
614. in its dynamic form it	visualizes the community as the embodiment of an ontological force-	the race for instance which unfolds in history	3486.9277190250637
615. in both cases the	individual tends to be treated as an instrument of the organic reality	1256.5539977482235
616. when the reactionary response is thus bolstered by an intellectual	defense the characteristics of that defense are explicable only	in terms of the basic attitudes of unanalyzed reaction	4475.615683222666
617. reaction is	rooted in a perception of tradition as a whole	504.76942087567966
618. it is a total situation	that is defended: the good old days	957.8226682122158
619. there is no selectivity;	even the questionable features of the past are defended	792.6651259663222
620. the point	is that the reactionary for whatever motive perceives himself to	have been part or a partner of something that extended beyond himself	something which consequently he was not able to accept or reject	on the basis of subjective preference	6427.001254555382
621. the reactionary is confused about	the existential status of a decaying tradition but he does perceive	the unity tradition had when it was healthy	2475.996814285677
622. all of which brings up another problem in the use of psychoanalytic	insight in a literary work	2121.9089731626573
623. is the oedipus complex the clinical	syndrome material for a tragedy	502.14445723697156
624. if we remove ourselves for a moment	from our time and our infatuation with mental disease isn't there	something absurd about a hero in a novel who is defeated by his infantile	neurosis	5329.844957355907
625. i am not making a clinical judgment here for such	personal tragedies are real and are commonplace in the analyst's	consulting room but literature makes a different claim upon our sympathies	than tragedy in life	3780.2029859128706
626. a man in a novel who is defeated in his childhood	and condemned by unconscious forces within him to tiredly repeat	his earliest failure in love only makes us a little weary of man;	his tragedy seems unworthy and trivial	6326.167889930412
627. now we can argue that	the irresistible fate of oedipus rex was nothing more than the irresistible	unconscious longings of oedipus projected outward but this	externalization of unconscious conflict makes all the difference between	a story and a clinical case history	4306.66432740368
628. we can also argue that the	three brothers karamazov and smerdyakov were the external representatives	of an internal conflict within one man dostoevsky a conflict	having to	do with father-murder and the wish to possess the father's woman	6090.833083067157
629. but	a novel in which one man karamazov explored the divisions within	his personality would scarcely merit publication in the psychoanalytic	quarterly	2178.4359846601374
630. it is a mistake to look upon the oedipus of	oedipus complex as a literary descendant of oedipus rex	2600.2050255891986
631. whatever	the psychological truth in the oedipus myth an oedipus who is drawn	to his fate by irresistible external forces can carry the symbol of	humanity and its archaic crime and the incest that is unknowing renews	the mystery of the eternal dream of childhood and absorbs us in the	secret	5036.853354669121
632. but a modern oedipus who is doomed because he cannot oppose	his own childhood is only pathetic and for renouncing the mystery	in favor of psychological truth he gives up the claim on our sympathies	5659.219542195029
633. i am suggesting that a case-history approach to the oedipus	complex is a blind alley for a storyteller	1585.471719948618
634. the best gifts of the novelist	will be wasted on the reader who is insulated against any surprises	the novelist may have in store for him	4081.406183269726
635. incest is still a durable	theme but if it wants to get written about it will have to find ways	to surprise the emotions and there is no better way to do this than	that of concealment and symbolic representation	4194.485551213671
636. and the best way to	conceal and disguise the elements of an incest story is not to set out	to write an incest story	3664.6422368255
637. which brings to mind another lawrence story	and some interesting comparisons in the treatment of the oedipal	theme	1578.9505134828291
638. the rocking horse winner is also a story about	a boy's love for his mother	1662.670456231114
639. if i now risk some comparisons with	sons and lovers let it be clear that i am not comparing the two	works or judging their merits; i am only singling out differences	in treatment of a theme and the resultant effects	4304.236206424132
640. the rocking horse	winner is a fantasy with extraordinary power to disturb the	reader- but we do not know why	2828.590184846069
641. it is the story of the hopeless love	of a little boy for his cold and vain mother	1566.4036660482413
642. there are ghostly scenes	in which the little boy on his rocking horse rocks madly toward the	climax that will magically give him the name of the winning horse	4664.561174218547
643. the	child grows rich on his winnings and conspires with his uncle to make	secret gifts of his money to his mother	2174.5957004241454
644. the story ends in the child's	illness and delirium brought on by the feverish compulsion to	ride his horse to win for his mother	3681.8694206780588
645. the child dies with his mourning	mother at his bedside	373.8157623014503
646. i had read the story many times without	asking myself why it affected me or caring why it did	2572.8768916012564
647. but on one	occasion when i encountered a similar fantasy in a little boy who was	my patient i began to understand the uncanny effects of this story	2970.790197774113
648. it was of course a little boy's fantasy of winning his mother to	himself and replacing the father who could not give her the things she	wanted- a classical oedipal fantasy if you like- but if it were	only this the story would be banal	6924.2553419060905
649. why does the story affect us	43.345035026183744
650. how	does the rocking exert its uncanny effect upon the reader	754.7708560551432
651. the	rocking is actually felt in the story a terrible and ominous rhythm that	prophesies the tragedy	1411.9506185766616
652. the rocking i realized is the single element	in the story that carries the erotic message the unspoken and	unconscious undercurrent that would mar the innocence of a child's fantasy	and disturb the effects of the work if it were made explicit	6597.530429822766
653. the	rocking has the ambiguous function of keeping the erotic undercurrent	silent and making it present; it conceals and yet is suggestive;	a perfect symbol	2600.509148211411
654. and if we understand the rocking as an erotic symbol	we can also see how well it serves as the symbol of impending tragedy	3696.866937267787
655. for this love of the boy for his mother is a hopeless and forbidden	love doomed by its nature	1734.6932772528712
656. we are also struck by the fact	that this story of a boy's love for his mother does not offend while	the incestuous love of the man paul morel sometimes repels	4990.992930775527
657. it's	easy to see why	14.853991900733533
658. this love belongs to childhood; we accord it	its place there and in lawrence's treatment we are given the innocent	fantasy of a child in fact the form in which oedipal love is expressed	in childhood	5774.694222679235
659. and when the child dies in lawrence's story	in a delirium that is somehow brought on by his mania to win and to make	his mother rich the manifest absurdity of such a disease and such	a death does not enter into our thoughts at all	4678.935966041096
660. we have so completely	entered the child's fantasy that his illness and his death are the	plausible and the necessary conclusion	3054.492178995754
661. i am sure that none	of the effects of this story were consciously employed by lawrence to	describe an oedipal fantasy in childhood	2300.9402228922554
662. it is most probable that	freud and the oedipus complex never entered his head in the writing	of this story	2813.8460082694833
663. he was simply writing a story that wanted to be told	and in the writing a childhood fantasy of his own emerged	2172.5822347518756
664. he would not	have cared why it emerged he only wanted to capture a memory to play	with it again in his imagination and somehow to fix and hold in the	story the disturbing emotions that accompanied the fantasy	6184.084443127303
665. in	our own time we have seen that the novelist's debt to psychoanalysis	has increased but that the novel itself has not profited much from	this marriage	2861.8234045791232
666. ortega's hope that modern psychology might yet bring	forth a last flowering of the novel has only been partially fulfilled	2831.119226386311
667. the young writer seems intimidated by psychological knowledge; he	has lost confidence in his own eyes and in the validity of his own psychological	insights	2592.4305032472566
668. he borrows the insights of psychology to improve	his impaired vision but cannot bring to his work the distinctive vision	that should be a novelist's own	4091.852709761416
669. he has been seduced by the marvels	of the unconscious and has lost interest in studying the surfaces	of character	1885.7516512941536
670. if many of the characters in contemporary novels appear	to be the bloodless relations of characters in a case history it is	because the novelist is often forgetful today that those things that	we call character manifest themselves in surface behavior that the ego	is still the executive agency of personality and that all we know of	personality must be discerned through the ego	8528.39845830461
671. the novelist who has	been badly baptized in psychoanalysis often gives us the impression that	since all men must have an oedipus complex all men must have the	same faces	3211.206887873398
672. i have argued that oedipus of the oedipus	complex has a doubtful future as a tragic figure in literature	2602.134538075071
673. but a	writer who has a taste for irony and who sees incest in all its modern	dimensions can let his imagination work on the disturbing joke in the	incest myth the joke that strikes right at the center of man's humanness	4375.832989812627
674. moral dread is seen as the other face of desire and here psychoanalysis	delivers to the writer a magnificent irony and a moral problem	of great complexity	4318.368863695194
675. there is probably some significance	in the fact that two of the best incest stories i have encountered	in recent years are burlesques of the incest myth	2851.512095646201
676. the ancient types	are reassembled in gloom and foreboding to be irresistibly drawn to their	destinies but the myth fails before the modern truth; the oracle	speaks false and the dream speaks true	5330.133254148963
677. in both the farmer's tale	in ralph ellison's invisible man and in thomas mann's the	holy sinner the incest hero rises above the myth by accepting	the wish as motive; the heroic act is the casting off of pretense	4133.441273226893
678. thomas mann wrote the holy sinner in 1951	249.80870849519593
679. it was conceived	as a leave-taking a kind of melancholy gathering-in of the myths	of the west bevor die nacht sinkt eine lange nacht vielleicht	und ein tiefes vergessen	3126.474040593251
680. he chose a medieval legend of	incest gregorius vom stein and freely borrowed and parodied other	myths of the west mixing themes language peoples and times in a master	myth in which the old forms continually renew themselves as in his	previous treatment of joseph	6898.260838913213
681. but the holy sinner is	not simply a retelling of old stories for an old man's entertainment	1420.7183836877534
682. mann understood better than most men the incest comedy at the center	of the myth and the psychological truth in which dread is shown as	the other face as longing was for him just the kind of deep and complicated	joke he liked to tell	6934.209772561267
683. and when he retold the legend of gregorius	he interpolated a modern version in which the medieval players speak	contemporary thoughts in archaic language; while they move through	the pageantry of the ancient incest myth and cover themselves through	not-knowing they reveal the unconscious motive in seeking each other	and in the last scene make an extraordinary confession of guilt in the	twentieth-century manner	5706.706968972858
684. grigorss is the child of an incestuous	union between a royal brother and sister the twins sibylla and	wiligis	2590.8205995245944
685. he is born in secrecy after the death of his father and cast	adrift soon after birth	1413.3151298891341
686. the infant is discovered by a fisherman who	brings him home to rear him	1410.9404661171038
687. an ivory tablet in the infant's cask	recounts the story of his sinful origins and is preserved for the child	by the monks of a monastery in the fishing village	3228.9015778076346
688. grigorss at	seventeen learns his story and goes forth as a knight to uncover his	origins	1885.2935632446138
689. his sailing vessel is guided by fate to the shores of his own	country at a time when sibylla's domain is overrun by the armies	of one of her rejected suitors	3324.3766188122368
690. grigorss overcomes the suitor in battle	delivers the city from its oppressors and marries sibylla who had	fallen in love with the beautiful knight the moment she saw him	4665.190345806534
691. sibylla is pregnant with their second child when she finds the ivory	tablet concealed by her husband and the identities of mother and son	are revealed	2734.0643659315174
692. grigorss goes off to do penance on a rock for seventeen	years	964.6574953047318
693. at the end of this period two pious christians in rome receive	the revelation which leads them to seek the next pope on the rock	2589.0740724971447
694. grigorss comes to rome and becomes a great and beloved pope	755.4011091260957
695. in	the last pages of the book sibylla comes to rome to seek an audience	with the great pope and to give her confession	2461.6195439402786
696. mother and son recognize	each other and in mann's version of this legend make a remarkable	confession of guilt to each other the confession of unconscious	motive and unconscious knowledge of their true identities from the	time they had first set eyes on each other	6913.301765654904
697. in recollection he has said: natural or man-made objects kept coming	into my head but i would suppress them sternly	1896.2921969986194
698. moreover	he organized the movement of his forms within his rigorously shaped space	into highly complex equilibriums; and used gradations of color	value as well as sharply contrasting elementary colors	4825.152232904045
699. the worthy	mondrian seeing these pictures said in a tone of kindly reproof:	but you are really an artist of the naturalistic tradition!	helion did not realize it at the time but it was true	3741.317456695285
700. his	monumental abstraction made up of smooth metallic non-objects	acting upon each other with great tension won helion much	acclaim during the 'thirties	3465.3387618575375
701. the play of novel lighting effects also	entered into these compositions whose controlled power and varied	activity made them well worth meditating	2187.619401867418
702. as helion's work	showed more and more nostalgia for the world of man and nature the pure	abstractionists expressed some disapproval; but leger arp lipchitz	and alexander calder at the time gave him their blessing	5660.136827550423
703. his	canvases nowadays bore titles frankly declaring them to be figures	in space or blue figure or pink figure; and	they had heads and feet	2599.756878794104
704. exhibited in shows in london in	1935 and in new york the following year the new more elaborated	abstracts were much favored in the circles of the modernists as three-dimentional	dramas of great intellectual coherence	5618.182929872824
705. at this period	the thirty-year old helion was ranked as one of the mature leaders	of the modern movement according to herbert read and in the	direct line of descent from cezanne seurat gris and leger	3853.9648979894737
706. in	america meyer schapiro observed that unlike the mondrian school	helion sought a return path to the fullness of nature within the	framework of abstract art	4107.006588370952
707. it is notable that at this time	he was writing with admiration of cimabue's and poussin's way	of filling space	1865.5556914324964
708. abstract art was still the right path for him; but	he	held instead of continuing as an art of reduction it must grow	must make a place for the contributions of the raphaels and poussins	as well as for those of the early cubists and mondrian	7028.368437650742
709. later	helion wrote of this phase: for years i built for myself	a subtle instrument of relationships- colors and forms without a name	2312.2086521278534
710. i played on it my secret songs unexplained passionate and peaceful	749.7213440332004
711. but his own work was evolving further	94.47265803634835
712. the extreme limitations	he sensed in all current abstract art made that seem to him increasingly	arid and cold	2576.8072457279904
713. he was engaged in constant experiments that	searched for new directions	499.0191432115606
714. where would it all lead	22.176880685693376
715. he himself	did not know as he said in 1935	373.58534263844024
716. but he was afraid of the future-	he would in fact welcome a way back to social integration a functional	art of some kind	3690.275552550568
717. during the 1920's the abstractionists	the german bauhaus group of industrial designers and the new	architects all had the dream of some well ordered utopia or welfare	state in which their neat and logical constructions might find their	proper place	4220.312019375247
718. but whereas the postwar american abstractionists seem	to helion to be determined to escape from the real world or simply	to rebel against it the ordered abstractions which he and his	associates of the 1930's were painting embodied the hope of improving	things	6681.3154821618255
719. we were possessed by visions of a new civilization	to come very pure and elevated he has said in fact some ideal	form of socialism such as we had dreamed of since the war of 1914-1918	3869.762532517047
720. instead of this the 1930's witnessed a tragic economic	depression the rise of fascist dictators in europe the wasting	civil war in spain	3484.5481904995904
721. very much the political man helion felt himself	deeply affected by the increasingly pessimistic atmosphere of france	and all europe whose foundations seemed to him more and more shaky	3101.4483199393567
722. in 1936 he decided to migrate to america	250.90276478434993
723. the rooseveltian america	was a haven of liberalism and progress and seemed to him to constitute	the last best hope for civilization	2190.4738071073402
724. helion also hoped that	america's mastery of technology and industrial efficiency would be	accompanied by the production of new and beautiful art works	3477.3843571753323
725. i arrived	in the united states with the idea of establishing myself there	more or less permanently and finding inspiration for new compositions	2327.1362152040647
726. in new york he was well received by what was then only	a small brave band of non-figurative artists including alexander calder	george k l morris de kooning holty and a few others	5302.654005691472
727. after a year in a studio on sheridan square having married an	american girl who was a native of virginia helion moved to a village	in the blue ridge mountains where he produced some of the most	imposing of his abstract canvases	4382.443735442953
728. the darkening world scene	at the time of the munich pact continued to trouble his mind even in	his remote virginia studio	3275.3994901851556
729. fear possessed me and the certainty	of war he has related	503.7028272768004
730. i truly smelled blood death heaps of	corpses everywhere	389.2435237736223

732. i knew i was carrying	on with abstraction to its very end- for me he said of the two	years' output in virginia	3473.290998410579

735. he had taken out first papers	for american citizenship; but after war came to europe he decided	to return to france arriving there in january 1940	2712.527259534153
736. i hated	the war he said but thought i ought to go because i was perhaps	one of those who hadn't done enough to prevent it	4059.8871501594354
737. in june 1940 sergeant helion with a company of reserve troops waiting	to go into battle was sketching the hills south of the loire	river when the war suddenly rolled in upon him	3554.172149294553
738. its first apparition	was a long gloomy column of refugees riding in farm wagons or pushing	prams	2119.928468577266
739. his company then carried out a confused retreating movement	until it was surrounded by the germans a few days before france capitulated	2167.287963689404
740. after a sort of death march during four days without food	helion and his comrades were shipped by cattle-car to a labor camp	at an estate farm in east germany	4819.283701206065
741. a year later they were removed to	a stalag in the harbor of stettin	934.509568340827

744. it was then i knew that they were	making war against man the individual within!- who questioned	things when given orders	3026.5742617645406

746. in secret he also	acted as a member of the prisoners' central committee which plotted	sabotage planned a few escapes and maintained a hidden control over	the wretched french slave-laborers	4839.651122808622
747. in the stalag helion	came to know and love his comrades most of them plain folk who in	their extremity showed true courage and ran great risks to help each	other	3325.4063125003245
748. how much they esteemed him is shown by the fact that their underground	committee selected him as one of the few who would be helped	to escape	4287.495927225367

750. every morning	contingents of prisoners would be sent out to labor in nearby factories	1396.379423499781

757. riding trains hitching hikes on trucks	across germany slipping through guarded frontiers with the help of	secret guides he eventually reached vichy france and by the winter	of 1943 was back in virginia	3531.212750295058
758. he wrote:   to escape from	a prison camp required a very special state of mind; not only loathing	of captivity but a faith a hope that is even stronger	4676.614765508953

778. important as was mr o'donnell's essay his thesis is	so restricting as to deny faulkner the stature which he obviously has	3054.3566554928357

792. it is to say rather i believe that he has brought to bear	on the history the traditions and the lore of his region a critical	skeptical mind- the same mind which has made of him an inveterate	experimenter in literary form and technique	6841.6090519745
793. he has employed from	his section rich immediate materials which in a loose sense can be termed	southern	1574.13012190181
794. the fact that he has cast over those materials the light	of a skeptical mind does not make him any the less southern i rather	think for the south has been no more solid than other regions except	in the political and related areas where patronage and force and	intimidation and fear may produce a surface uniformity	8085.831877521472
795. some of us might	be inclined to argue in fact that an independence of mind and action	and an intolerance of regimentation either mental or physical	are particularly southern traits	3233.1981549434704

800. besides showing no inclination apparently to absent himself from his	native region even for short periods and in addition writing a shelf	of books set in the region he has handled in those books an astonishingly	complete list of matters which have been important in the south	during the past hundred years	7616.659319756238
801. it is more difficult with faulkner	than with most authors to say what is the extent and what is	the source of his knowledge	2459.4351528870075

803. his denials of extensive	reading notwithstanding it is no doubt safe to assume that he	has spent time schooling himself in southern history and that he has	gained some acquaintance with the chief literary authors who have lived	in the south or have written about the south	4756.599637634405
804. to believe otherwise	would be unrealistic	65.31325198754135

812. the planter	aristocracy has appeared in literature at least since john pendleton	kennedy published swallow-barn in 1832 and in his genial portrait	of frank meriwether presiding over his plantation dominion initiated	the most persistent tradition of southern literature	6059.194740321236
813. the thoroughgoing	idealization of the planter society did not come however	until after the civil war when southern writers were eager to defend	a way of life which had been destroyed	3316.179196716119
814. as they looked with nostalgia	to a society which had been swept away they were probably no more	than half-conscious that they painted in colors which had never existed	4646.284097642169
815. their books found no less willing readers outside than inside the	south even while memories of the war were still sharp	2021.6000499415732
816. the tradition	reached its apex perhaps in the works of thomas nelson page toward	the end of the century and reappeared undiminished as late as 1934	in the best-selling novel so red the rose by stark young	5933.206694234944

824. the chief literary antecedents of the snopes clan appeared in the	realistic humorous writing which originated in the south and the	southwest in the three decades before the civil war	4853.771715882063
825. these narratives	of coarse action and crude language appeared first in local newspapers	as a rule and later found their way between book covers though	rarely into the planters' libraries beside the morocco-bound volumes	of horace mr addison mr pope and sir walter scott	4541.972530406919

827. william	gilmore simms sturdy realist that he was pleaded for a natural	robustness such as he	found in his favorites the great elizabethans	to vivify the pale writings being produced around him	3468.1810346784064
828. simms admired	the raucous tales emanating from the backwoods but he had himself social	affiliations which would not allow him to approve them fully	3692.150435793429

834. one of the early humorists already mentioned	thomas bangs thorpe can be used to illustrate another point	where faulkner touches authentic southern materials and also earlier	literary treatment of those materials	5005.5246774706775
835. thorpe came to louisiana from	the east as a young man prepared to find in the new country the setting	of romantic adventure and idealized beauty	2735.3634903236007

909. copernicus did not question it ptolemy could not	165.99381545993543
910. given the conceptual	context within which ancient thought thrived how could anyone have	questioned this principle	1883.3704977123148

913. not only did constellations like draco cepheus and cassiopeia	spin circles around the pole but stars which were not circumpolar	rose and set at the same place on the horizon each night	3452.757223392681
914. nor did	a constellation's stars vary in brightness during the course of their	nocturnal flights	1644.720613770045

916. moreover the sun's	path over earth described a segment of a great circle; this was	clear from the contour of the shadow traced by a gnomon before and after	noon	4854.053160323113
917. as early as the 6th century bc the earth	was seen to be spherical	945.8626947499167

924. or angular	0.30041514999999996

928. by distinguishing superlunary	and sublunary existence and reinforcing this with	the four-element physics of empedocles aristotle came to speak of	the stars as perfect bodies which moved in only a perfect way viz	in a perfect circle	5913.6808413210765
929. now what is perfect motion	14.77206552851776
930. it must	apparently be motion without termini	140.22419450828085
931. because motion which begins and	ends at discrete places would be incomplete	639.4974990795765
932. circular motion however since it is eternal and perfectly continuous	lacks termini	961.2168081435248
933. it is never motion towards something	43.698103901194635
934. only imcomplete	imperfect things move towards what they lack	389.4485327347477
935. perfect complete	entities if they move at all do not move towards what they lack	1090.3838475283983
936. they move only in accordance with what is in their natures	749.7333181076009
937. thus circular	motion is itself one of the essential characteristics of completely	perfect celestial existence	1100.5684171640892
938. to return now to the four-element	physics a mixture of muddy frothy water will when standing in	a jar separate out with earth at the bottom water on top and the	air on top of that	5761.406972254642
939. a candle alight in the air directs its flame and	smoke upwards	642.4376285450659
940. this gives a clue to the cosmical order of elements	560.5423151271864
941. thus earth has fallen to the center of the universe	374.6616559879046
942. it is covered	with water air is atop of that	557.126860526789

949. being less encumbered by material embodiments they partake	more of what is divine	786.0544212279922
950. their motion will be eternal and perfect	140.20260750550196
951. let us re-examine the publicized contrasts between ptolemaic	and copernican astronomy	504.2278004350319
952. bluntly there never was a ptolemaic system	of astronomy	391.4579792753924
953. copernicus' achievement was to have invented	systematic astronomy	167.2164317926217
954. the almagest and the hypotheses outline	ptolemy's conception of his own task as the provision of computational	tables independent calculating devices for the prediction	of future planetary perturbations	4492.4110313305355

961. his problem concerns	longitudes latitudes and angular velocities	167.26651165752745
962. the distances of these	points of light is a problem he cannot master beyond crude conjectures	as to the orderings of the planetary orbits viewed outward from earth	4518.0930742797145

967. so when textbooks like that	of baker set out drawings of the 'ptolemaic system' complete	with earth in the center and the seven heavenly bodies epicyclically arranged	on their several deferents we have nothing but a misleading 20th-century	idea of what never existed historically	4543.053533086577
968. it is	the chief merit in copernicus' work that all his planetary calculations	are interdependent	1636.2534040299709
969. he cannot eg compute the retrograde	arc traveled by mars without also making suppositions about the	earth's own motion	1734.2889177474947
970. he cannot describe eclipses without entertaining	some form of	a three-body problem	964.836391927812
971. in ptolemaic terms however eclipses	and retrograde motion were phenomena simpliciter to be explained	directly as possible resultants of epicyclical combinations	2031.3938443532538
972. in a	systematic astronomy like that of copernicus retrogradations become	part of the conceptual structure of the system; they are no longer	a puzzling aspect of intricately variable local planetary motions	4975.716796909652
973. another contrast stressed when discussing ptolemaic vs	copernican astronomy turns on the idea of simplicity	1093.8848619536288
974. it is often	stated that copernican astronomy is 'simpler' than ptolemaic	757.1247226380125
975. some even say that this is the reason for the ultimate acceptance of	the former	1097.5696226845462
976. thus margenau remarks: a large number of unrelated	epicycles was needed to explain the observations but otherwise the	ptolemaic system served well and with quantitative precision	4075.9618478795114
977. copernicus	by placing the sun at the center of the planetary universe	was able to reduce the number of epicycles from eighty-three to seventeen	2452.9221281241403
978. historical records indicate that copernicus was unaware of the	fundamental aspects of his so-called 'revolution' unaware perhaps	of its historical importance he rested content with having produced	a simpler scheme for prediction	5129.701974937927
979. as an illustration of the principle	of simplicity the heliocentric discovery has a peculiar appeal because	it allows simplicity to be arithmetized; it involves a reduction	in the number of epicycles from eighty-three to seventeen	3739.8382585647146
980. without careful qualification this can be misleading	140.49889367347913
981. if in any one	calculation ptolemy had had to invoke 83 epicycles all at once	while copernicus never required more than one third this number then	ptolemaic astronomy would be simpler	than copernican	3548.0861821119047
982. but no single planetary problem ever required	of ptolemy more than six epicycles at one time	1872.014665818755
983. this of course results	from the non-systematic 'cellular' character of ptolemaic	theory	646.6033743566588
984. calculations within the copernican framework always raised questions	about planetary configurations	754.7520761032717
985. these could be met only by considering	the dynamical elements of several planets at one time	1263.2167614933073
986. this	is more ambitious than ptolemy is ever required to be when he faces	his isolated problems	2112.9177492644158
987. thus in no ordinary sense of 'simplicity'	is the ptolemaic theory simpler than the copernican	1107.0203845594392
988. the latter required	juggling several elements simultaneously	140.5256553309213
989. this was not simpler	but much more difficult than exercises within ptolemy's astronomy	791.2408129955198
990. analogously anyone who argues that einstein's theory of	gravitation is simpler than newton's must say rather more to explain	how it is that the latter is mastered by student-physicists while	the former can be managed only by accomplished experts	6172.57783824909
991. in a sense einstein's theory is simpler than newton's	and there is a corresponding sense in which copernicus' theory	is simpler than ptolemy's	2340.0127489572415
992. but 'simplicity' here refers to	systematic simplicity	139.9093698565926
993. the number of primitive ideas in systematically-simple	theories is reduced to a minimum	793.6572330778687
994. the axioms required to	make the theoretical machinery operate are set out tersely and powerfully	so that all permissible operations within the theory can be traced	rigorously back to these axioms rules and primitive notions	5652.507256379606
995. this	characterizes euclid's formulation of geometry but not ptolemy's	astronomy	373.8683813307294
996. there are in the almagest no rules for determining	in advance whether a new epicycle will be required for dealing with	abberations in lunar solar or planetary behavior	4477.992796970745
997. the strongest	appeal of the copernican formulation consisted in just this: ideally	the justification for dealing with special problems in particular	ways is completely set out in the basic 'rules' of the theory	3550.0786742255646
998. the	lower-level hypotheses are never 'ad hoc' never introduced ex	post facto just to sweep up within the theory some recalcitrant datum	3281.9472984904023
999. copernicus to an extent unachieved by ptolemy approximated to	euclid's vision	498.6278561767992
1000. de revolutionibus is not just a collection of	facts and techniques	755.8426496378868
1001. it is an organized system of these things	166.7118884511222
1002. solving	astronomical problems requires for copernicus not a random search	of unrelated tables but a regular employment of the rules defining	the entire discipline	3684.045349638503
1003. hence noting the simplicity achieved	in copernicus' formulation does not provide another reason for	the acceptance of de revolutionibus another reason beyond its	systematic superiority	2577.7468763101388
1004. it provides exactly the same reason	65.0409454999414
1005. 1543 ad is often venerated as the birthday of the scientific	revolution	643.6641581736433
1006. it is really the funeral day of scholastic science	392.2195596217831
1007. granted	the cosmological philosophical and cultural reverberations	initiated by the de revolutionibus were felt with increasing violence	during the 300 years to follow	2322.992435480633
1008. but considered within technical	astronomy a different pattern can be traced	757.0331393169362

1010. what in the	almagest draws his fire	140.41636414869168
1011. geocentricism per se	0.20041515
1012. no	0.30041514999999996
1013. the	formal displacement of the geocentric principle far from being copernicus'	primary concern was introduced only to resolve what seemed	to him intolerable in orthodox astronomy namely the 'unphysical'	triplication of centric reference-points: one center from which	the planet's distances were calculated another around which planetary	velocities were computed and still a third center from	which the observations originated	5474.770201818256
1014. this arrangement was for copernicus	literally monstrous: with the ptolemaists it is as though	an artist were to gather the hands feet head and other members	for his images from divers models each part excellently drawn but not	related to a single body; and since they in no way match each other	the result would be a monster rather than a man	8412.03606876537
1015. copernicus	required a systematically integrated physically intelligible astronomy	167.80596034438076
1016. his objective was essentially to repair those aspects of orthodox	astronomy responsible for its deficiencies in achieving these ends	2587.194247727558
1017. that such deficiencies existed within ptolemy's theory was not	discovered de novo by copernicus	941.4199847170578
1018. the critical rigorous examinations	of nicholas of cusa and nicholas of oresme provided the context	for nicholas copernicus' own work	2820.538059750398

2022. impressive as this enumeration is it barely hints at the diverse	perceptions of jews collectively or individually that have been	attested by their gentile environment	3889.9097502823242

2029. the conventional image of a particular time	and place is not necessarily congruent with the image of the facts as	established over the years by scholarly and scientific research	3126.877381839678
2030. conventional	images of jews have this in common with all perceptions of	a configuration in which one feature is held constant: images can be	both true and false	4456.083142362551
2031. the genuinely interesting question then	becomes: what factors determine the degree of realism or distortion	in conventional images of jews	1880.1203775350525
2032. the working test of the facts	must always be the best available description obtainable from scholars	and scientists who have applied their methods of investigation	to relevant situations	4480.3920864239035
2033. granted such functional images are subject	to human error; they are self-correcting in the sense that they	are subject to disciplined procedures that check and recheck against	error	2975.9908666890997

2064. my reply is that i associate myself with	all those who affirm that gentile-jewish relations should contribute	to the theory and practice of human dignity	3892.0816443777317

2066. within this frame of	reference policies appropriate to claims advanced in the name of the	jews depend upon which jewish identity is involved as well as upon	the nature of the claim the characteristics of the claimant the justifications	proposed and the predispositions of the community decision	makers who are called upon to act	7784.0949572886675

2872. one is greece is not yet suffering	from overpopulation	390.5176917691372
2873. the public may still find pleasure in public	places	261.00476705184434
2874. the other is that the charge for cabanas and parasols though	modest from an american point of view still is a little high for	many athenians	4104.845789115148
2875. we were struck by the notable absence of banana skins	and beer cans but just so that we wouldn't go overboard on greek	refinement perfection was side-stepped by a couple of braying portable	radios	3640.2870594984875

2877. a good deal of english was spoken on the beach most educated greeks	learn it in childhood and there were also american wives and	children of our overseas servicemen	3090.0183464837946
2878. for a delightful drive out	of athens i should recommend sounion at the end of the attic peninsula	2346.6701993647266
2879. the road a comparatively new one is very good winding along	inlets coves and bays of deep and brilliant blue	1887.7830123014107
2880. i suppose the	day will inevitably come when the area will be encrusted with developments	but at present it is deserted and seductive	3470.546853714084
2881. three beneficial	hurdles to progress are the lack of water electricity and telephones	787.5200214836485

2883. gaunt scaffoldings adjoined the ruins	and on the ground segments of columns two and a half to three feet	in thickness were being fitted with sections cunningly chiseled to	match exactly the fluting and proportion of the original	4035.9524325389657
2884. later they	would be hoisted into place	141.8339324471685
2885. there is a mediocre restaurant at	sounion and i fed a thin little grecian cat and gave it two saucers	of water- there was no milk- which it lapped up as though it were	nectar	3751.87846729008
2886. i think its thirst had never been assuaged before	392.0451660344726
2887. norton	and i dined one night in a sea-food restaurant in piraeus right	on the water's edge	1426.5082559385655
2888. to enter it you go down five or six steps	from the road	1204.5163863317503

2890. this restaurant	too had a cat a dusty thin little creature	752.3091004569632
2891. how can	a cat be thin in a fish restaurant	374.03471940553493
2892. but this one was	4.409337810600458
2893. when offered	a morsel it glanced right and left and winced obviously frightened	and expecting a kick but too hungry not to snatch the tidbit	2601.8185976879513
2894. greece	was one of the highlights of our trip but beginning in greece and continuing	around the world throughout southeast asia the treatment of	animals was horrifying ranging from callous indifference to active	cruelty	5504.731173294901
2895. this of course was not true of the educated and sophisticated	people we met who loved their pets but kindness is not a basic human	instinct	2720.798431416033

2897. his english was limited and the	little he knew he found irritating	645.1672420603774
2898. a particularly galling phrase was	ok panyotis we have time at our disposal	1173.5280207669996
2899. this he	claimed was the favorite refrain of the english	374.6300828520399
2900. they would be lolling	under a tree sipping ouzo relishing the leisurely life assuring	him that the day was yet young	3059.4504321026366
2901. let him become honest and they discard him	168.157715138924

2904. to exonerate the legislature	and thereby extricate himself from a sticky situation pike took another	course and made it appear that the legislature had been bilked	4076.2342968958937

2907. the game	is not worth the ammunition it would cost	375.6485608800482

2911. so persistent were these attacks	that in march of the following year woodruff was finally moved	to action and pike was to learn his first lesson in frontier politics	the subtle art of diversion	3643.377413534103
2912. to attack pike directly would	gain woodruff little for as a penniless newcomer pike had nothing	to lose	2361.716714637031
2913. by this time woodruff had accurately measured pike as a	man of great personal pride a man who would fly into a towering rage	if his integrity were questioned and who would be anxious to avenge himself	3941.7478196504317
2914. pike's honor would now come under attack but not by woodruff	himself	957.045470525913
2915. the charges would be made in the gazette by an anonymous	correspondent and pike would be so busy trying to track down the	illusive character assassin that he would forget about harassing woodruff	3561.6069571612124

2917. the anonymous	correspondent did not resort to innuendoes	166.75226327467476
2918. he called pike a thief	22.284045066572457
2919. he said pike had stolen mules from harris during the santa fe	expedition; he accused pike of continuing his sticky-fingered career	in arkansas with the theft of some otter skins in van buren	3557.5053940256303
2920. the	charges caught pike off balance coming as they did from an unexpected	quarter	1411.8555363508563

2924. without further inquiry pike jumped to the conclusion	that robinson was guilty and following the honorable route that	would	eventually lead to the dueling ground sent a message to robinson	through his friends demanding that he either confirm or deny his complicity	6578.545061016803
2925. to pike silence was tantamount to an	admission of guilt and he determined to get robinson onto the dueling	ground at all costs	2321.871650725373
2926. on april 11th he wrote an open letter in the	advocate making it known to the world that jas w robinson	is by his own admission a base liar and a slanderer	5209.868582577897

2929. and pike never did	find out if robinson was really responsible for the vale letter	1094.8801664016587
2930. woodruff's strategy had been immensely successful	65.39899191591556
2931. it	took pike a long time to realize what woodruff had done and it had	a profound effect on him	1883.9566890844712
2932. once he learned a lesson he never forgot it	392.0356441215789
2933. in the next few months of comparative silence pike waited patiently	until conditions were perfect for a new attack and then displaying	a remarkable grasp of the subtleties of political infighting gained	from his first bout with woodruff he used these changed conditions	to excellent advantage	4670.206487163202
2934. shortly after the vale incident	a rift began to develop between william woodruff and governor pope	1886.7735611909823
2935. one-armed gruff frugally honest governor pope had been the	ideal man to assume office in arkansas after the disgraceful antics of	political bosses like crittenden and he ruled the state with an iron	fist tolerating no nonsense	3969.3317628666287
2936. woodruff had supported him all the way	both as a chief executive and as a man	1901.718769741295
2937. besides being political allies	they were also friends	166.34741428368844
2938. this warm relationship came to an abrupt	end in june of 1834 when the national congress appropriated $3000	for compiling and printing the laws of arkansas territory and	taking note of the recent wave of corruption in the legislature left	it to the governor to award the contract	7241.714424439937
2939. woodruff wanted this	political windfall very badly and everyone assumed that he would get	it because he was a close friend of the governor and his stanchest supporter	2994.3121763874897
2940. after all woodruff owned a competent printing plant and was	the logical man for the job	1885.3490604911053
2941. but because the governor was determined	that friendship should not influence him one way or the other he looked	for a printer with a knowledge of the law	and awarded the contract to a lawyer named john steele who	had started a newspaper in helena the year before	4837.966228027261
2942. considering the governor's act a personal rebuff he aired	his feelings in the gazette on august 26 1834: we think	the governor treated us rather shabbily to say the least of it	5175.70727657798
2943. h	it is but justice to mr steele for us to add that in the above	remarks nothing is intended to his disparagement either as a lawyer	or as a printer	3335.7137814010603

2946. as summer cooled into fall and winter	even so the relationship between the two men continued to grow colder	by the day and by december of 1834 it was icy	4855.699877041525
2947. it was at this point	that pike decided to capitalize on the bad feelings between the two	men	1569.225996319187

2949. from his first bout with the	canny woodruff pike had learned that it was better not to attack him	directly so harping on the theme that the cost of printing was too	high he condemned the governor for permitting such a state of affairs	to exist	4679.636362045129

2952. the governor	was not used to having his integrity questioned and he promptly	passed the charges on to woodruff demanding that woodruff answer them	3668.082337304694
2953. if woodruff could not furnish a strong explanation the governor	insisted that he lower his prices in accord with the scale printed in	the advocate	2606.2892703716043
2954. woodruff was now impaled on the horns of a dilemma	566.0431454305499
