2956. as a consequence he did neither	65.24082913201723
2957. very angry at woodruff	the governor used his personal influence to have the printing contract	withdrawn from the gazette and awarded to the lowest bidder which	by a strange coincidence happened to be pike's advocate	3778.050024627641
2958. and for the moment at least the governor now found himself allied with	the head of the crittenden faction he had formerly opposed and pike	was credited with a clear triumph over woodruff	5332.846589022038
2959. but in	the	confused atmosphere of frontier politics alliances were as quickly	broken as they were formed and as pike came to favor with the governor	of the territory the governor fell out of favor with the president	of the united states	4374.131078557499
2960. on january 28 1835 andrew jackson removed	pope from office and elevated territorial secretary william	s fulton to the position	2832.075069723188
2961. fulton was a very close friend of jackson	and had been his private secretary for a number of years in the	old days	2325.568181767816

2964. after all pike was an established poet and his work	had been published in the respectable periodicals of that center of	american culture boston	3703.028461559951
2965. his accomplishments and the fact that he	was resident did much to offset the unkind words travelers used to	describe little rock after a visit there	2724.634608561902
2966. for some reason none of	them were impressed with the territorial capital	956.4839021372863

2968. little rock is a vile detestable	place h	254.113760822301

2970. pike enjoyed his	new social position tremendously and cultivated in himself those traits	necessary to its preservation	2118.2475024137066

2973. his artistic accomplishments guaranteed him entry into	any social gathering	372.7732492883236
2974. he composed songs and set them to music and	sang them in a soft melodious voice and when his audience had had enough	of music he would discourse on politics or tell stories of his western	adventures guaranteed to excite the emotions of men and women alike	7140.666919916517

2976. by 1834	the art of oratory had reached a very high level in the united states	as a literary form	2842.356007497906
2977. the orator of this period in order to earn a	reputation had to pay close attention to the formal composition of his	speech judging how it would appear in print as well as the effect	it would have on the audience that heard it	4534.595436941647
2978. very soon after his	arrival in little rock pike had joined one of the most influential	organizations in town the little rock debating society and it	was with this group that he made his debut as an orator being invited	to deliver the annual fourth of july address the club sponsored every	year	7721.808308055637
2979. samuel gorton founder of warwick was styled by the historian	samuel greene arnold one of the most remarkable men who ever lived	2166.7471963003863
2980. a biographer called him the premature john the baptist of	new england transcendentalism	1185.4159924220662
2981. the historian charles francis	adams called him a crude and half-crazy thinker	646.3437374829268

2984. nathaniel morton stated he was deeply leavened	with blasphemous and familistical opinions	958.4296959356454
2985. he was thrown	out more or less from boston plymouth pocasset newport and providence	945.9087262615112

2987. he was universally	beloved by his neighbours and the indians who esteemed him	not only as a friend but one high in communion with god in heaven	2875.1003953461573
2988. gorton sometimes signed himself a professor of the mysteries of	christ	752.0233853703797
2989. there is plenty more to recommend gorton the facts	of whose life are given in the life and times of samuel gorton	by adelos gorton	2587.838089608876
2990. he fought like a fiend for the helpless and	oppressed worked for the abolition of slavery helped the quakers	and indians and worked against the prosecution of witches	4484.585986617803
2991. he defied	the boston hierarchy and after they sent a small army to get him	he befuddled the court including john cotton with one of the most	complicated religious discourses ever heard	3438.24794458419
2992. samuel gorton was	born at gorton england near the present city of manchester about	1592	1640.5877740797005
2993. although he did not attend any celebrated schools or universities	he was a master of greek and hebrew and could read the bible	in the original	2742.5108360967492
2994. he worked as a clothier in london but was greatly	concerned with religion	1185.700599894107
2995. gorton left england he said	to enjoy libertie of conscience in respect to faith towards god	and for no other end	2027.030226698429
2996. with his wife and three or more children he	arrived in boston in march 1637 and soon found it was no place for	anyone looking for liberty of conscience	4649.074449175596
2997. roger williams had recently	been thrown out and anne hutchinson and her antinomians were slugging	it out with the powers-that-be	1870.3988817032646
2998. gorton and his family moved to	plymouth	140.31847049015897
2999. soon he was in trouble there for defending a woman	who was accused of smiling in church	1401.8897407857453
3000. she was ellen aldridge a widow	of good repute who was employed by gorton's wife and lived with	the family	2801.6054073282885
3001. the report was:   it had been whispered privately	that she had smiled in the congregation and the governor prence	sent to knoe her business and command after punishment as the bench	see fit her departure and also anyone who brought her to the place	from which she came	4832.220493577532
3002. gorton said they were preparing to deport	her as a vagabond and to escape the shame she fled to the woods for	several days returning at night	4282.466241494165
3003. he advised the poor woman not to	appear in court as what she was charged with was not in violation of	law	2161.603663674077
3004. gorton appeared for her however and what he told the magistrates	must have been plenty for he was charged with deluding the court	fined and told to leave the colony within fourteen days	5304.90089352848
3005. he left in	a storm for pocasset december 4 1638	377.817581539155
3006. his wife was in delicate health	and nursing an infant with measles	963.2879984218123
3007. the unconquerable mrs	hutchinson was residing at pocasset after having been excommunicated	by the boston church and thrown out of the colony	2189.2173582636688
3008. one can imagine	that with her and gorton there it was no place for anyone with	weak nerves	2341.44694188839
3009. william coddington who was running the colony felt constrained	to move seven miles south where with others- as mentioned	above- he founded newport	2327.3486220878312
3010. when in march 1640 the two towns	were united under coddington gorton claimed the union was irregular	and illegally constituted and that it had never been sanctioned by the	majority of freeholders	5149.71787057622
3011. then he became involved in a ruckus	remarkably similar to the one in plymouth	945.9199174509009
3012. a cow owned by an old woman	trespassed on gorton's land	753.2908892439482

3014. the old woman complained	to the deputy governor who ordered the servant brought before	the court	1886.7777113934767
3015. gorton reverted to his plymouth tactics refused to let	her go and appeared himself before the portsmouth grand jury	1729.228653656764
3016. during	the trial he told off the jury called them just asses and	called a freeman a saucy boy and jack-an-apes	3050.500759798793
3017. he was jailed	and banished	14.772574705058947
3018. gorton then moved to providence and soon put the	town in a turmoil	1182.831035780157
3019. he held that no group of colonists could set up	or maintain a government without royal sanction	1425.173149310287
3020. since rhode island	at that time did not have such sanction his opinion was not popular	1869.0592694155214
3021. roger williams wrote his friend winthrop as follows:   master	gorton having foully abused high and low at aquidneck is now	bewitching and bemaddening poor providence both with his unclean and	foul censures of all the ministers of this country	and also denying all visible	and external ordinances in depth of familism: almost all suck in	his poison as at first they did at aquidneck	5697.915750250496
3022. some few and myself withstand	his inhabitation and town privileges without confession and	reformation of his uncivil and inhuman practices at portsmouth; yet	the tide is too strong against us and i fear	it will force me to little patience a little isle next	to your prudence	7104.358635704595
3023. williams also stated: our peace was like	the peace of a man who hath the tertian ague	1416.619449277797
3024. providence finally	managed to get gorton out of the town and he and some friends	bought land at pawtuxet on the west side of narragansett bay five	miles south but still within the jurisdiction of the providence colony	6070.569626450561

3026. up to now gorton had been looking	for trouble and now that he was trying to get away from it trouble	started looking for him	3878.981816261362
3027. upon intelligence that the formidable	agitator was to favor them with his presence the benighted inhabitants	of pawtuxet alas gave their allegiance to massachusetts and asked	that colony to expel the newcomers	3446.6161669019843
3028. as it was the custom of that alert	colony to take over the property of persons asking for protection	this was an act roughly equivalent to throwing open the door to a pack	of wolves and saying come and get it	6426.03675030177
3029. gorton and company	however promptly bought land from miantonomi a few miles south	of pawtuxet extending from the present gaspee point south to warwick	neck and twenty miles inland	3115.8558039779336

3032. if gorton wanted peace and quiet	for his complicated meditations this is where he should have had it	2363.9904664614783

3034. pomham and soconoco	a couple of minor sachems	under miantonomi declared that they had never assented to the sale	of land to gorton and had never received anything for it	4818.726132239275
3035. following	the glorious lead of the heroes of pawtuxet they also submitted themselves	to the protection of massachusetts	1564.5212341823658
3036. one historical authority	presents laborious and circuitous testimony tending to arouse suspicion	that massachusetts was behind the clouds settling down on the embattled	gorton	3692.920374529976
3037. however the general court at boston ordered	the purchasers of shawomet to appear before them to answer the sachems'	claim	1877.5165236713503
3038. the purchasers rejected the order in two letters written	in vigorous terms	961.5523621152394
3039. then massachusetts switched to its standard tactics	93.1378984393933
3040. it pointed out twenty-six instances of blasphemy in the letters	and ordered the writers to submit or force of arms would be used	3488.478602523791
3041. the	next week forty soldiers were sent to get the miscreants	495.28772863229153
3042. the latter	tried to arbitrate through a delegation from providence which offer	was declined by the invaders	2121.0000633283007
3043. the commissioners at boston wrote	the victims to see their misdeeds and repent or they should look upon	them as men prepared for slaughter	2469.9594220748895

3045. the men fortified a blockhouse	and got ready to fight but meanwhile appealed to the king and	again tried to arbitrate	2030.7003903824436
3046. gorton evidently still had plenty to learn	about massachusetts but he was learning fast	1419.835107530511
3047. governor winthrop wrote:	you may do well to take notice that besides the title	to land between the english and the indians there there are twelve	of the english that have subscribed their names to horrible and detestable	blasphemies who are rather to be judged as blasphemous than	they should delude us by winning time under pretence of arbitration	5449.611817414368
3048. the attack started on october 2 1643 and the gortonists held	out for a day and a night	2366.3824613287943
3049. the attackers sent for more soldiers and	the defenders to save bloodshed surrendered under the promise that	they would be treated as neighbors	2316.4129937210428
3050. promptly their livestock was taken	and according to gorton the soldiers were ordered to knock down anyone	who should utter a word of insolence and run through anyone who	might step out of line	5440.705447060796
3051. when the captives arrived in boston	the chaplain of their captors went to prayers in the open streets	that the people might take notice what they had done in a holy manner	and in the name of the lord	4123.42675985129
3052. gorton and ten of his friends	were thrown in jail	559.6488635224947

3054. the magistrates were determined to compel them	140.23811193925772

3273. there are	some people intelligent people who seem to be untouched by the sea	of wonder in which we are immersed and in which we spend our lives	2966.1252332000977

3275. this is a straightforward denial of the spiritual world and	a vigorous defense of pure materialism	1265.7387000253702
3276. his inability to wonder vitiates	his argument	140.85571198597046
3277. the subject of immortality brings to mind a	vivid incident which took place in 1929 at montreux in switzerland	1733.1973206880255
3278. criticism is as old as literary art and we can set the stage for	our study of three moderns if we see how certain critics in the past	have dealt with the ethical aspects of literature	5804.504522035277
3279. i have chosen five	contrasting pairs ten men in all and they are arranged in roughly	chronological order	1569.2818267233752
3280. such a list must naturally be selective and the	treatment of each man is brief for i am interested only in their general	ideas on the moral measure of literature	4837.564546935018
3281. altogether the list	will give us considerable variety in attitudes and some typical ones	for these critics range all the way from censors to those who consider	art above ethics all the way from plato to poe	3945.80168885086
3282. and most of the	great periods are represented because we will compare plato and aristotle	from the golden age of greece; stephen gosson and sir philip	sidney from renaissance england; dr johnson and william	hazlitt of the eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries in england;	and james russell lowell and edgar allan poe of nineteenth	century american letters	8074.247502334324
3283. plato and aristotle	agree on some vital literary issues	263.16764347595984
3284. they both measure literature	by moral standards and in their political writings both allow for	censorship but the differences between them are also significant	3682.843234158509
3285. while	aristotle censors literature only for the young plato would banish	all poets from his ideal state	1425.3801615255857
3286. even more important in his poetics	aristotle differs somewhat from plato when he moves in the	direction of treating literature as a unique thing separate and apart	from its causes and its effects	5340.576339584497
3287. all through the republic	plato attends to the way art relates to the general life and ultimately	to a good life for his citizens	2460.5287265923953
3288. in short he is constantly concerned	with the ethical effects	562.654812015617
3289. when he discusses the subject matter	of poetry he asks what moral effect the scenes will have	1416.427791545602
3290. when he	turns briefly to literary style in the third book he again looks to	the effect on the audience	2834.991412507229
3291. he explains that his citizens must not	be corrupted by any of the misrepresentations of the gods or heroes that	one finds in much poetry and he observes that all these pantomimic	gentlemen will be sent to another state	4113.287363047945
3292. only those story tellers	will remain who can imitate the style of the virtuous	1415.087499225166
3293. plato is at times just as suspicious of the poets themselves as he	is of their work	1423.5969413176692
3294. when he discusses tyrants in the eighth book of	the republic he pictures the poets as willing to praise the worst	rulers	3280.960070767327
3295. but the most fundamental objection he has to poets appears	in the tenth book and it is derived from his doctrine of ideal forms	2472.4866399711836
3296. in plato's mind there is an irresolvable conflict between the	poet and the philosopher because the poet imitates only particular objects	and is incapable of rising to the first level of abstraction much	less the highest level of ideal forms	6332.508453037292
3297. true reality of course is	the ideal and the poet knows nothing of this; only the philosopher	knows the truth	1903.1982750325853
3298. poets moreover dwell on human passions	65.20141561022648
3299. and	with this point about the passions we encounter plato's dualism	502.53737016328176
3300. the same sort of thinking plays so large a part in both babbitt and	more that we must examine it in some detail	3478.9800947157732
3301. plato feels that man	has two competing aspects his rational faculty and his irrational	945.0426061551605
3302. we can be virtuous only if we control our lower natures the passions	in this case and strengthen our rational side; and poetry with all	its emphasis on the passions encourages the audience to give way to	emotion	6061.785193137082
3303. for this reason then poetry tends to weaken the power of	control the reason because it tempts one to indulge his passions and	even the best of men he maintains may be corrupted by this subtle	influence	3927.915113232362
3304. plato's attitude toward poetry has always been something	of an enigma because he is so completely sensitive to its charm	2839.6745159654956
3305. his whole objection indeed seems to rise out of a deep conviction	that the poets do have great power to influence but plato seldom	pays any attention to what might be called the poem itself	3735.8210024255886
3306. he is	rather concerned with the effect on society and he wants the poets	to join his fight for justice	2813.047413853254
3307. he wants them to use their great power	to strengthen man's rational side to teach virtue and to encourage	religion	1880.619474244435
3308. while plato finally allows a few acceptable hymns	to the gods and famous men still he clearly leaves the way open for	further discussion of the issue	4284.862612790239
3309. he even calls upon the poets to defend	the muse and to show that poetry may contribute to virtue	1720.40744603261
3310. he says:	we	may further grant to those of her poetry's defenders	who are lovers of poetry and yet not poets the permission to	speak in prose on her behalf: let them show not only that she is pleasant	but also useful to states and to human life and we will listen	in a kindly spirit; for if this can be proved we shall surely be the	gainers- i mean if there is a use in poetry as well as a delight	0.30166232349522504
3311. when we turn to aristotle's ideas on the moral measure	of literature it is at once apparent that he is at times equally concerned	about the influence of the art	3215.019730180135
3312. in the ideal state for instance	he argues that the young citizens should hear only the most carefully	selected tales and stories	3304.8639840509777
3313. for this reason he would banish indecent	pictures and speeches from the stage; and the young people should	not even be permitted to see comedies till they are old enough to	drink strong wine and sit at the public tables	4242.204100110817
3314. by the time they reach	that age however aristotle no longer worries about the evil influence	of comedies	2344.979916878945
3315. in aristotle's analysis of tragedy in the	poetics we find an attempt to isolate the art to consider only	those things proper to it to discover how it differs from other arts	and to deal with the effects peculiar to it	4290.55232995526
3316. he assures us early	in the poetics that all art is imitation and that all imitation	gives pleasure but he distinguishes between art in general and	poetic art on the basis of the means manner and the objects of the	imitation	6454.872759860077
3317. once the poetic arts are separated from the other forms	he lays down his famous definition of tragedy which sets up standards	and so lends direction to the remainder of the work	3446.4327557745573
3318. a tragedy by	his definition is an imitation of an action that is serious of a certain	magnitude and complete in itself	3283.1186568504236
3319. it should have a dramatic form	with pleasing language and it should portray incidents which so arouse	pity and fear that it purges these emotions in the audience	3000.1917381718226
3320. any	tragedy he maintains has six elements: plot character and thought	diction and melody	and spectacle	1886.3079821937706
3321. throughout the rest of	the poetics aristotle continues to discuss the characteristics	of these six	parts and their interrelationship and he refers frequently to the	standards suggested by his definition of tragedy	3457.9957061947134
3322. aristotle's	method in the poetics then does suggest that we should isolate	the work	1417.5458902054797
3323. the chicago contingent of modern critics follow aristotle	so far in this direction that it is hard to see how they can compare	one poem with another for the purpose of evaluation	3418.081662522497
3324. but there are	however several features of aristotle's approach which open the	way for the moral measure of literature	2584.845760711034
3325. for one thing aristotle mentions	that plays may corrupt the audience	503.27328445229443
3326. in addition his definition	of a tragedy invites our attention because a serious and important	action may very well be one that tests the moral fiber of the author	or of the characters	5318.758216362701
3327. and there is one other point in the poetics that	invites moral evaluation: aristotle's notion that the distinctive	function of tragedy is to purge one's emotions by arousing pity	and fear	3332.867745137801
3328. he rejects certain plots because they do not contribute to	that end	951.2183276244929
3329. the point is that an ethical critic with an assist from freud	can seize on this theory to argue that tragedy provides us with	a harmless outlet for our hostile urges	3340.4358527801596
3330. in his study samuel johnson	joseph wood krutch takes this line when he says that what aristotle	really means by his theory of catharsis is that our evil passions	may be so purged by the dramatic ritual that it is less likely	that we shall indulge them through our own acts	7483.128434134534
3331. in krutch's view	this is one way to show how literature may be moral in effect without	employing the explicit methods of a moralist	2461.7242609119494
3332. and we can add that	krutch's interpretation of purgation is also one answer to plato's	fear that poetry will encourage our passions	3266.7953052898824
3333. if krutch is correct	tragedy may have quite the opposite effect	500.45571599725355
3334. it may allay our passions	and so restore the rule of reason	962.6954259288866
3335. or in more freudian terms	the experience may serve to sublimate our destructive urges and strengthen	the ego and superego	1880.1137270104668
3336. the second half of	the sixteenth century in england was the setting for a violent and long	controversy over the moral quality of renaissance literature especially	the drama	4469.518294749348
3337. no one suggested that the ethical effects of the art	were irrelevant	637.5735292979094
3338. both sides agreed that the theater must stand a moral	test but they could not agree on whether the poets were a good or	a bad influence	4298.541965127797
3339. both sides claimed that plato and aristotle supported	their cause	370.98718069924155
3340. those who wanted to close the theaters for example	pointed to plato's republic and those who wished to keep them	open called on the plato of the ion to testify in their behalf	5308.181219635618
3341. the most famous document that comes out of this dispute is perhaps	sir philip sidney's an apologie for poetrie published	in 1595	2174.741174359456
3342. many students of literature know that classical defense	250.13371832263297
3343. what is not so well known however and what is quite important for	understanding the issues of this early quarrel is the kind of attack	on literature that sidney was answering	3312.4600995578758
3344. for this reason then i want	to describe first two examples of the puritanical attacks: stephen	gosson's the school of abuse 1579 and his later playes	confuted published in 1582	4811.061919914971
3345. second we will see how sidney	answered the charges for while sidney's essay was not specifically	a reply to gosson his arguments do support the new theater	2859.5665291881674
3346. according to william ringler's study stephen gosson the theater	business in london had become a thriving enterprise by 1577 and	in the opinion of many a thoroughly bad business	4683.292695130354
3347. aroused by what	they considered an evil influence some members of the clergy joined	by city authorities merchants and master craftsmen began the attack	on the plays and the actors for what they called the abuses of the	art but by 1582 some of them began to denounce the whole idea of	acting	5132.993130792123
3348. although this kind of wholesale objection came at first from	some men who were not technically puritans still once the puritans	gained power they climaxed the affair by passing the infamous ordinance	of 1642 which decreed that all public stage-plays shall cease	and be forborne	6915.967705821415
3349. with that act of parliament the opponents of the	stage won the day and for more than two decades after that england	had no legitimate public drama	2871.053153586991
3350. in the early days of this controversy	over the theater one of the interested parties stephen gosson	published a little tract in which he objected mildly to the abuses	of art rather than the art itself	5773.321800015111
3351. but his opposition hardened and	by 1579 in the school of abuse he was ready to banish all players	1722.1530021483784
3352. he advises women to beware of those places which in sorrows	cheere you and beguile you in mirth	2358.378165834514
3353. he does not really approve	of levity and laughter but sex is the deadly sin	1105.9187229011336
3354. he warns that	a single glance can lead us into temptation for looking eies have	lyking hartes and lyking hartes may burne in lust	3703.852394779272
3355. but it would not be very satisfactory to leave our conclusions	at the point just reached	1251.8670199488174
3356. fortunately it is possible to be somewhat	more concrete and factual in diagnosing the involvement of values in	education	2563.378332920074
3357. for this purpose we now draw upon data from sociological and	psychological studies of students in american colleges and universities	and particularly from the cornell values studies	2867.2367725799127
3358. in the latter	research program	information is available for 2758 cornell students	surveyed in 1950 and for 1571 students surveyed in 1952	3270.4643451945617
3359. of the	latter sample 944 persons had been studied two years earlier; hence	changes in attitudes and values can be analyzed for identical individuals	at two points in time	3102.0051812712322
3360. in addition the 1952 study collected	comparable data from 4585 students at ten other colleges and universities	scattered across the country: dartmouth harvard yale wesleyan	north carolina fisk texas university of california at	los angeles wayne and michigan	6051.941871102271
3361. we find in the first	place that the students overwhelmingly approve of higher education	positively evaluate the job their own institution is doing do not	accept most of the criticisms levelled against higher education in the	public prints and on the whole approve of the way their university	deals with value-problems and value inculcation	5219.994448740193
3362. it is not our impression	that these evaluations are naively uncritical resultants of blissful	ignorance; rather the generality of these students find their	university experience congenial to their own sense of values	5153.406634180769
3363. students	are approximately equally divided between those who regard	vocational preparation as the primary goal of an ideal education and those	who chose a general liberal education	2864.691783192872
3364. other conceivable goals	such as character-education and social adjustment are of secondary	importance to them	1649.3548611924339
3365. the ideal of a liberal education impresses itself	upon the students more and more as they move through college	1738.4963928746242
3366. even	in such technical curricula as engineering the senior is much more	likely than the freshman to choose as an ideal liberal education over	specific vocational preparation	4320.231342483865
3367. in the university milieu of scholarship	and research of social diversity of new ideas and varied and	wide-ranging interests socialization into a campus culture apparently	means heightened appreciation of the idea of a liberal education	in the arts and sciences	4207.081954604643
3368. students' choices of ideal	educational goals are not arbitrary or whimsical	754.3022486224984
3369. there is a clear	relationship between their educational evaluations and their basic	pattern of general values	1251.6219890582274
3370. the selective and directional qualities of	basic value-orientations are clearly evident in these data: the	success-oriented	students choose vocational preparation the other-directed	choose goals of social adjustment	the intellectuals choose a liberal arts emphasis	5505.08000633198
3371. the same patterned consistency shows itself in occupational choices	261.64440327673327
3372. there is impressive consistency between specific occupational	preferences and the student's basic conception of what is for him a	good way of life	3474.740321851785
3373. and contrary to many popular assertions the goal-values	chosen do not seem to us to be primarily oriented to materialistic	success nor to mere conformity	2589.301076244876
3374. our students want occupations	that permit them to use their talents and training to be creative	and original to work with and to help other people	4077.253973952292
3375. they also want	money prestige and security	93.82375533034133
3376. but they are optimistic about their	prospects in these regards; they set limits to their aspirations-	few aspire to millions of dollars or to imperial power and	glory	4455.7841795618515
3377. within the fixed frame of these aspirations they can afford	to place a high value on the expressive and people-oriented aspects of	occupation and to minimize the instrumental-reward values of power	prestige and wealth	3653.894575082007
3378. occupational choices are also useful-	and interesting- in bringing out clearly that values do not constitute	the only component in goals and aspirations	3477.482211709703
3379. for there is also the	face of reality in the form of the individual's perceptions	of	his own abilities and interests of the objective possibilities open	to him of the familial and other social pressures to which he is exposed	4235.847103867014
3380. we find reluctant recruits whose values are not in line with	their expected occupation's characteristics	1638.2521064287967
3381. students develop occupational	images- not always accurate or detailed- and they try to	fit their values to the presumed characteristics of the imagined occupation	2450.837921370953
3382. the purely cognitive or informational problems are often acute	392.05956743208765
3383. furthermore many reluctant recruits are yielding to social demands	or compromising in the face of their own limitations of opportunity	or of ability and performance	2602.789278254132
3384. thus many a creativity-oriented aspirant	for a career in architecture drama or journalism resigns himself	to a real estate business; many a people-oriented student who dreams	of the md decides to enter his father's advertising agency;	and many a hopeful incipient business executive decides it were	better to teach the theory of business administration than to practice	it	8147.237565254662
3385. the old ideal of the independent entrepreneur is extant- but	so is the recognition that the main chance may be in a corporate bureaucracy	2466.594757697077
3386. in their views on dating courtship sex and family	life our students prefer what they are expected to prefer	2589.6128514464917
3387. for them	in the grim words of a once-popular song love and marriage go together	like a horse and carriage	1906.0464661459632
3388. their expressed standards concerning	sex roles desirable age for marriage characteristics of an ideal mate	number of children desired are congruent with the values and stereotypes	of the preceding generation- minus compulsive rebellion	5339.225635701501
3389. they	even accept the double standard of sex morality in a double sense	ie both sexes agree that standards for men differ from standards	for women and women apply to both sexes a standard different from	that held by men	4225.809260973581
3390. conservatism and traditionalism	seem implied by what has just been said	754.4950581209937
3391. but these terms are treacherous	14.811548145411098
3392. in the field of political values it is certainly true that	students are not radical not rebels against their parents or their peers	3474.7490727430063
3393. and as they go through college the students tend to bring their	political position in line with that prevalent in the social groups	to which they belong	2845.673108591732
3394. yet they have accepted most of the extant welfare	state provisions for health security and the regulation of	economic affairs and they overwhelmingly approve of the traditional	liberalism of the bill of rights	5318.573606018377
3395. when their faith in civil	liberties is tested against strong pressures of social expediency in specific	issues eg suppression of dangerous ideas many waver	and give in	2854.2844533955094
3396. the students who are most willing to acquiesce in the	suppression of civil liberties are also those who are most likely to	be prejudiced against minority groups to be conformist and traditionalistic	in general social attitudes and to lack a basic faith in people	6777.145803652789
3397. as one looks at the existing evidence one finds a correlation	although only a slight one between high grades and libertarian	values	2200.305779307909
3398. but the correlation is substantial only among upperclassmen	252.93465729671317
3399. in other words as students go through college those who are	most successful academically tend to become more committed to a bill	of rights orientation	2590.9605163036294
3400. college in gross- just the general experience-	may have varying effects but the the students who are successful	emerge with strengthened and clarified democratic values	3891.3823411008284
3401. this finding is consistent also with the fact that student leaders are	more likely to be supporters of the values implicit in civil liberties	than the other students	2979.262708060019
3402. there is now substantial evidence	from several major studies of college students that the experience of	the college years results in a certain selective homogenization of	attitudes and values	4673.2784265590835
3403. detached from their prior statuses and social	groups and exposed to the pervasive stimuli of the university milieu	the students tend to assimilate a new common culture to converge	toward norms characteristic of their own particular campus	3945.9051569851376
3404. furthermore	in certain respects there are norms common to colleges and universities	across the country	1642.3962851780525
3405. for instance college-educated people consistently	show up in study after study as more often than others supporters	of the bill of rights and other democratic rights and liberties	2986.159721892925
3406. the interesting thing in this connection is that the norms upon which	students tend to converge include toleration of diversity	2797.5242465359424
3407. to the extent that our sampling of the orientations of american college	students in the years 1950 and 1952 may be representative of our	culture- and still valid in 1959- we are disposed to question the	summary characterization of the current generation as silent beat	apathetic or as a mass of other-directed conformists who are guided	solely by social radar without benefit of inner gyroscopes	5737.2653838527085
3408. our data	indicate that these students of today do basically accept the existing	institutions of the society and in the face of the realities of complex	and large-scale economic and political problems make a wary and	ambivalent delegation of trust to those who occupy positions of legitimized	responsibility for coping with such collective concerns	7778.273151108883
3409. in	a real sense they are admittedly conservative but their conservatism	incorporates a traditionalized embodiment of the original radicalism	of 1776	2039.724569904798
3410. although we have no measures of its strength or intensity	the heritage of the doctrine of inalienable rights is retained	2822.8318497428245
3411. as they move through the college years our young men and women are socialized	into a broadly similar culture at the level of personal	behavior	2609.8629698309546
3412. in this sense also they are surely conformists	250.2016908234936
3413. it is	even true that some among them use the sheer fact of conformity- everyone	does it- as a criterion for conduct	2168.9810989199623
3414. but the extent of	ethical robotism is easily overestimated	389.9460915137297
3415. few students are really so	faceless in the not-so-lonely crowd of the swelling population in our	institutions of higher learning	1878.204436648656
3416. and it may be well to recall that to	say	conformity is in part another way of saying orderly human	society	3005.8368071706122
3417. in the field of religious beliefs and values the	college students seem to faithfully reflect the surrounding culture	1574.3991532688767
3418. their commitments are for the most part couched in a familiar idiom	959.7629420388148

3423. these personal and social goals often overshadow the	goals of intellectual clarity and spiritual transcendence	1091.698339610489
3424. the cult	of adjustment does exist	65.71425052137364
3425. it exists alongside the acceptance of	traditional forms of organized religion		261.5310726006138
3426. still another segment of the student population consists	of those who seek in what they regard as religion intellectual clarity	rational belief and ethical guidance and reinforcement	4249.590236272327
3427. our first impression of the data was that the students were surprisingly	orthodox and religiously involved	1252.8337837197619

3431. nor are optimistic and socially-oriented themes at	all rare in the distinctive religious history of this country	1404.1247088217829
3432. kluckhohn recently has summarized evidence regarding changes in values	during a period of years primarily 1935-1955 but extending much farther	back in some instances	3672.6178917814045

3434. although	he questions the extent and nature of the alleged revival of religion	and the alleged increase in conformity and thinks that hedonistic	present-time orientation does not have the meaning usually attributed	to it he does conclude that americans increasingly enjoy leisure	without guilt do not stress achievement so much as formerly are more	accepting of group harmony as a goal more tolerant of diversity and	aware of other cultures	0.30166232349522504
3435. from new jersey morgan hastened to the headquarters of washington	at whitemarsh pennsylvania arriving there on november 18th	1553.241521456698
3436. there was much sickness in the corps and the men were in addition	without the clothing shoes and blankets needed for the winter weather	3682.6534173229275
3437. morgan himself had sciatica again	14.900910923313564
3438. even on his tough constitution	the exposure and strenuous activity were beginning to tell in earnest	1885.0765337411303

3440. in order to prevent this washington hastened	to dispatch several units to reinforce the fort including a force	under the marquis de lafayette containing some 160 of morgan's	riflemen all who were fit for duty at this time the rest having no shoes	6687.719789650386

3450. morgan immediately	disposed his troops for action and found he had not long to wait	1649.1934142545233
3451. a body of redcoats were seen marching down a nearby slope a tempting	target for the riflemen who threw a volley into their ranks and messed	up the smart formation considerably	3344.54769313029

3612. the first time i went there he asked me to bring him water from	flagler's well- water that reminded him of his first days in the	mountains- and before i came the next time i filled a five-gallon	jug for him and brought it to the hospital	7124.34505371914
3613. i don't think he ever	got to drink any of it	497.6037314937178
3614. the jug stayed at the hospital and the	water- what can happen to water	1412.5628365482755
3615. - it evaporated disappeared and	came back to the earth as rain- maybe for another well or another	stream or another alfred alpert	1457.7519895800428
3616. mr banks was always called banks the butcher until he left	town and the shop passed over to meltzer the scholar who then became	automatically meltzer the butcher	4466.07989402312
3617. meltzer was a boarder with the	banks family	167.43072499697882
3618. he came to fleischmanns directly from the boat that	brought him to america from russia	1664.42110203991
3619. he was a learned man and a very	gentle soul	378.47666951582585
3620. he was filled with knowledge of the bible and the talmud	754.3080654945871
3621. he knew the whyfores and the wherefores but he was weak very weak	on the therefores	1253.5894422068625
3622. banks the butcher took meltzer the scholar	as an apprentice and he made it very clear that a man of learning must	be able to do more than just quote the commentaries of the talmud in	order to live	6211.321720355476
3623. so meltzer learned a new trade from banks who supplied	the town and the hotels with meat	1417.234099171945
3624. banks had a family-	a wife a daughter and a son	757.732768325042
3625. the daughter lilly was a very good	friend of mine and i always had hopes that someday she and meltzer would	find each other	2465.8276288788475
3626. they lived in the same house and it didn't seem	to be such a hard	thing to do but the sad realities of lilly's life	and the fact that meltzer didn't love her never satisfied my wishful	thinking	6053.017954096633
3627. banks the butcher was a hard master and a hard	father a man who didn't seem to know the difference between the living	flesh of his family and the hanging carcasses of his stock in trade	3850.8653940413997
3628. he treated both with equal indifference and with equal contempt;	perhaps he was a little more sympathetic to the sides of beef that	hung silently from his hooks	4447.370978116665

3631. and lilly's whole family seemed	to be an apology for mr banks	637.1920170822467

3634. every chance i got i left the hotel to	visit lilly	754.8059964047201

3636. she had to clean the glass on the	display cases in the butcher shop help her brother scrub the cutting	tables with wire brushes mop the floors put down new sawdust on the	floors and help check the outgoing orders	6342.355905183472
3637. when these chores were	finished only then was she allowed whatever freedom she could find	1098.3048771016022
3638. i helped lilly in the store	65.06859971300572
3639. to me it was a game to her it	was the deadly seriousness of life	1094.9368070876612
3640. i wanted to help so that we could	find time to play	956.300401471212
3641. and lilly allowed me to help so that she could	have her few little hours of escape	1400.619102485602
3642. when the work was finished	we would walk	251.5055310018808
3643. the road past the butcher shop took us along the side	of a stream	944.9691956846469
3644. it ran north away from the town and the people through	woods and past the nothingness of a graveyard	2602.9574100280415
3645. lilly preferred	the loneliness of that walk	93.27313402259975
3646. i would have liked the town and the	busyness of its people but i always followed lilly into the peace of	the silent and unstaring road	4116.735554743607
3647. it wasn't hard to understand	14.828730013549324
3648. to me lilly was a fine and lovely girl	394.5757277188196
3649. to people who didn't know	her she was a gawky badly dressed kid whose arms were too long whose	legs were a little too bony	2593.750703450186

3655. when we	went for our walks lilly's brother would come along every once in	a while	1255.6911003305645

3658. karl played well	and his favorite song was a schubert lullaby	758.0748757026843

3665. the turn of the century or to be more precise the two decades	preceeding and following it marks a great change in the history of	early english scholarship	2988.008353972799
3666. at the bottom of this change were great strides	forward in the technical equipment and technical standards of the	historian	2806.7274994418954
3667. in archaeology for example the contributions of frederick	haverfield and reginald smith to the various volumes of the victoria	county histories raised the discipline from the status of an	antiquarian pastime to that of the most valuable single tool of the	early english historian	4533.409841130745
3668. and with the publication of e t leeds'	archaeology of the anglo-saxon settlements the student	was presented with an organized synthesis of the archaeological data	then known	4280.058062519136
3669. what was true for archaeology was also true of place-name	studies	500.40805389676336
3670. the value of place-names in the reconstruction of early	english history had long been recognized	1640.7761613867922
3671. place-names in fact	had been extensively utilized for this purpose from the time of camden	onwards	1258.9220500720571
3672. without a precise knowledge of germanic philology however	it is debatable whether their use was not more often a source of confusion	and error than anything else	4281.227362399903
3673. even in the nineteenth century	such accomplished philologists as kemble and guest were led into what	now seem ludicrous errors because of their failure to recognize that	modern forms of place names are not necessarily the result of logical	philological development	4275.085839144465
3674. it was therefore not until the publication	of jh round's the settlement of the south and east	saxons and wh stevenson's dr guest and the english	conquest of south britain that a scientific basis for place-name	studies was established	6183.256762913987
3675. diplomatic is another area for	which the dawn of the twentieth century marks the beginning of modern	standards of scholarship	1881.0326271546487
3676. although because of the important achievements	of nineteenth century scholars in the field of textual criticism	the advance is not so striking as it was in the case of archaeology	and place-names the editorial principles laid down by stevenson in	his great edition of asser and in his crawford charters were a	distinct improvement upon those of his predecessors and remain unimproved	upon today	8543.092624266395
3677. in sum it can be said that the techniques and	standards of present day have their origin at the turn of the century	2331.108850484984
3678. and it is this particularly the establishment of archaeology and	place-name studies on a scientific basis which are immediately pertinent	to the saxon shore	3694.3184346843736
3679. almost inevitably the first result	of this technological revolution was a reaction against the methods and	in many cases the conclusions of the oxford school of stubbs freeman	and green regarding the nature of the anglo-saxon	conquest of britain	4131.018162361007
3680. even before the century was out the tide of	reaction had set in	1179.7145061590156
3681. charles plummer in the introduction and notes to	his splendid edition of bede voiced some early doubts concerning the	elaborate superstructure they raised up over the slim foundations	afforded by the traditional narratives of the conquest	3864.4602445637515
3682. it was plummer	in fact who coined the much quoted remark: mr green	indeed writes as if he had been present at the landing of the saxons	and had watched every step of their subsequent progress	5813.5645343930355
3683. sir henry	howorth writing in 1898 put himself firmly in the lappenburg-kemble	tradition by attacking the veracity of the west saxon annals	2176.0094628821143
3684. early in the present century w h stevenson continued	the attack with a savage article against guest	2130.806309300079
3685. following him in varying	degrees of scepticism were tw shore hm chadwick	thomas hodgkin and f g beck	1564.9760727666987
3686. by 1913 ferdinand lot	could begin an article subtitled la conquete de la grande-bretagne	par les saxons with the words il est difficile aujourd	'hui d'entretenir des illusions sur la valeur du recit traditionnel	de la conquete de la grande-bretagne h	6456.053651448884
3687. it is also worthy	of note that lot cited both kemble and lappenberg with favor in	that article	1565.9236133004647
3688. it would seem that the wheel had turned full circle	562.130932596476
3689. in fact modern scholarly opinion in the main has not retreated	all the way back to the destructive scepticism of the first half of the	nineteenth century	2868.4760402161273
3690. although one meets with occasional extremists like	zachrisson or very recently arthur wade-evans the majority of	scholars have taken a middle position between the extremes of scepticism	and gullibility	4668.001021039735
3691. most now admit that bede gildas nennius and	the anglo-saxon chronicles cannot be the infallible guides to early	english history that guest freeman and green thought them to be	3080.6900115128756
3692. as rh hodgkin has remarked: the critical methods of	the nineteenth century shattered most of this picturesque narrative	2364.40796650786
3693. on	the other hand the consensus of opinion is that used with caution	and in conjunction with other types of evidence the native sources still	provide a valid rough outline for the english settlement of southern	britain	3941.3510131549556
3694. as sir charles oman once said it is no longer fashionable	to declare that we can say nothing certain about old english	origins	3497.475672353548
3695. therefore in one way kemble and lappenberg	have been vindicated	374.33530491813156
3696. their conclusions concerning the untrustworthiness	of the west saxon annals the confused chronology of bede the	unreliability of the early positions of the anglo-saxon genealogies	and the mythological elements contained in nennius are now mostly accepted	5791.1126023213865
3697. nevertheless in another way modern historians still labor in	the vineyard of the oxford school	1093.9760674293411
3698. for it is their catastrophic concept	of the anglo-saxon invasions rather than kemble's gradualist	approach which dominates the field	2596.8587632006297
3699. despite the rejection of the traditional	accounts on many points of detail as late as 1948 it was still	possible to postulate a massive and comparatively sudden	influx of germans as the type of invasions	3762.1887629094454
3700. at	this point of course the issue has become complicated by a development	unforeseen by lappenberg and kemble	2367.5172003002735
3701. they however much they were	in disagreement with the late victorians over the method by which	britain was germanized agreed with them that the end result was the	complete extinction of the previous celtic population and civilization	3940.7024093271743
3702. but beginning for all practical purposes with frederick seebohm's	english village community scholars have had to reckon	with a theory involving institutional and agrarian continuity between	roman and anglo-saxon times which is completely at odds with the reigning	concept of the anglo-saxon invasions	6688.876548754646
3703. against seebohm formidable	foes have taken the field notably f w maitland whose	domesday book and beyond was written expressly for this purpose	and sir paul vinogradoff whose the growth of the manor had	a similar aim	3946.7145157958817
3704. largely due to their efforts the catastrophic invasion-theory	has maintained its position although seebohm has always found	supporters	2375.3569979849353
3705. hl gray in his english field systems and	zachrisson's romans kelts and saxons defended in part the	seebohm thesis while at the present time hpr finberg and	gordon copley seem to fall into the celtic survivalist camp	3947.441767477877
3706. this	is nevertheless a minority view	65.78973380009026
3707. most scholars while willing to accept	a survival of celtic art forms and a considerable proportion	of the celtic population reject any institutional legacy from	pre-anglo-saxon britain	2848.639434447538
3708. therefore it is plain that the	clear distinctions of the nineteenth century are no longer with us	2124.263582077319
3709. in the main stream of historical thinking is a group of scholars hm	chadwick rh hodgkin sir frank stenton et al	who are in varying degrees sceptical of the native traditions of the conquest	but who defend the catastrophic type of invasion suggested by	them	4609.787846947116
3710. they in effect have compromised the opposing positions of the	nineteenth century	963.9885704148974
3711. on the other side are the celtic survivalists who	have taken a tack divergent from both these schools of nineteenth century	thought	2189.741562286527
3712. as a group they should be favorable to a concept of gradual	germanic infiltration although the specialist nature of much of	their work eg seebohm gray and finberg tends to obscure	their sympathies	5319.8580490364
3713. those who do have occasion to deal with the invasions	in a more general way like tw shore and arthur wade-evans	are on the side of a gradual and often peaceful germanic penetration	into britain	3784.0702670155924
3714. wade-evans in fact denies that there were any anglo-saxon	invasions at all other than a minor jutish foray in ad	514	3022.8170253060584
3715. now omitting for a moment some recent developments	we can say the saxon shore hypothesis of lappenberg and kemble has	undergone virtual eclipse in this century	2736.951754572321
3716. it is no longer possible	to say that a sceptical attitude towards the received accounts of the	invasions almost automatically produces a shore occupied by interpretation	4115.9064334476525
3717. everyone is more or less sceptical and virtually no one has	been willing to accept lappenberg or kemble's position on that	point	2186.907853173141
3718. one reason is of course that the new scepticism has been willing	to maintain the general picture of the invasions as portrayed in	the traditional sources	4099.011092854979
3719. the few scholars who have adopted the shore	occupied by interpretation howorth shore and wade-evans	have all been celtic survivalists	1880.7932062632299
3720. moreover they have done so in rather	special circumstances	392.3399883068454
3721. the primary reason for the abandonment	of the shore occupied by thesis has been the assimilation and	accumulation of archaeological evidence the most striking feature	of early english studies in this century	3440.7603252408835
3722. again omitting recent developments	et	leeds' dictum of 1913 has stood unchallenged: so far	as archaeology is concerned there is not the least warrant for the	second of these theories	4839.609672058935
3723. even earlier haverfield	had come to the same conclusion	261.96996340249194
3724. what they meant was that there	was no evidence to show that the south and east coasts of britain received	germanic settlers conspicuously earlier than some other parts of	england	4830.868725893879
3725. that is there was no trace of anglo-saxons in britain	as early as the late third century to which time the archaeological	evidence for the erection of the saxon shore forts was beginning to	point	3755.7532663645047
3726. in the face of a clear judgment from archaeology therefore it	became impossible for a time for scholars to re-adopt the shore settled	by theory	3905.8586305371914
3727. in recent years however a wind of change	seems to be blowing through early english historical circles	1407.7719507416653
3728. the	great increase in the amount of archaeological activity and therefore	information in the years immediately preceeding and following the second	world war has brought to light data which has changed the complection	of the saxon shore dispute	6069.394416846462
3729. where there were none fifteen years	ago several scholars currently are edging their way cautiously towards	the acceptance of the shore occupied by position	2475.5635095932525
3730. we must	therefore have a look at the new archaeological material and re-examine	the literary and place-name evidence which bears upon the problem	3480.2128101044786
3731. what exactly are we trying to prove	93.72818667005455
3732. we know that the	saxon shore was a phenonenon of late roman defensive policy; in	other words its existence belongs to the period of roman britain	4085.8550355065645
3733. so	whenever the romans finally withdrew from the island the saxon shore	disappeared in the first decade of the fifth century	2055.083935616449
3734. we also know	that the saxon shore as reflected in the notitia was created	as a part of the theodosian reorganization of britain		2352.763927243492
3735. my argument is that there was no saxon shore prior to that	time even though the forts had been in existence since the time of carausius	2714.6001268610717
3736. therefore what we must prove or disprove is that there were	saxons in the broad sense in which we must construe the word in	the area of the saxon shore at the time it was called the saxon shore	6171.545574997793
3737. that is we must find saxons in east anglia kent sussex and	hampshire in the last half of the fourth century	2022.2029083378904
3738. the problem	in other words is strictly a chronological one	568.5560595329229
3739. in gaul the saxon	element on its saxon shore was plainly visible because there the	saxons were an intrusive element in the population	2309.8186726336517
3740. in britain obviously	the archaeological and place-name characteristics of the saxon	shore region are bound to be saxon	2346.281400037483
3741. it is a matter of trying to	sort out an earlier fourth-century saxon element from the later fifth-century	mainstream of anglo-saxon invasions	2178.327404377228
3742. this naturally will	be difficult to do since both the archaeological and place-name evidence	in this period with some fortunate exceptions is insufficient	for precise chronological purposes	4272.014080176042
3743. it might be well to consider	the literary evidence first because it can provide us with an answer	to one important question; namely is the idea that there were saxon	mercenaries in england at all reasonable	3837.984035702516
3744. to do so something was necessary beyond volunteering because there was	little glamour or romance in the european war; it meant instead	hardship dirt and death	4077.325668766919
3745. baker gave leonard wood credit for	the initiation of the draft of soldiers; from the general's idea	a chain reaction occurred	2031.7008567159824
3746. wood took the proposal to chief of staff	hugh l scott who passed it on to baker a month before the actual	declaration of war against germany	4253.712350802347
3747. the secretary of war gave	his assent after studying the history of the draft in the american	civil war as well as the british volunteer system in world war 1	3220.16891602819
3748. he concluded that selective service would not only prevent the disorganization	of essential war industries but would avoid the undesirable	moral effects of the british reliance on enlistment only- where	the feeling of the people was whipped into a frenzy by girls pinning	white feathers on reluctant young men orators preaching hate of the	germans and newspapers exaggerating enemy outrages to make men enlist	out of motives of revenge and retaliation	0.30166232349522504
3749. baker took the plan	to wilson who said: baker this is plainly right on any ground	1249.04159498342
3750. start to prepare the necessary legislation so that if i am obliged	to go to congress the bills will be ready for immediate consideration	3700.1847657188796
3751. the result was that by secret agreement draft machinery was actually	ready long before the country knew that the device was to take	the place of the volunteering method which theodore roosevelt favored	3532.2759047238565
3752. before the draft act was passed baker had confidentially briefed	governors sheriffs and prospective draft board members on the administration	of the measure- and the confidence was kept so well that	only one newspaper learned what was going on	6217.72526185358
3753. it was baker working	through provost marshal enoch crowder and major hugh s	johnson who arranged for a secret printing by the	million of selective service blanks- again before the act was passed-	until corridors in the government printing office were full	and the basement of the washington post office was stacked to the ceiling	5261.243588330044
3754. general crowder proposed that regular army officers select	the draftees in cities and towns throughout the nation; it was baker	who thought of lessening the shock which conscription always brings	to a country by substituting greetings from your neighbors for	the recruiting sergeant and registration in familiar voting places	rather than at military installations	7772.024658669316
3755. even so the draft act	encountered rough sledding in its progress through the congress	938.9014016568326
3756. democratic	speaker champ clark saw little difference between a conscript	and a convict	1181.655588736537
3757. democrat stanley h dent chairman of the	house military affairs committee declined to introduce the bill	1253.016653593492
3758. democratic floor leader claude kitchin would have no part of the	measure	965.0934881454237
3759. in the judgment of chief of staff scott it was ironic that	the draft policy of a democratic president aimed at germany had	to be pushed through the house of representatives by the ranking minority	member of the military affairs committee- a republican jew	born in germany! he was julius kahn for whom the chief of staff	thought no honor could be too great	5686.687394426056
3760. after kahn's death in 1924	scott wrote: may he rest in peace with the eternal gratitude	of his adopted country	2799.119521252748
3761. in spite of powerful opposition the	draft act finally passed congress on may 17 1917	1096.8257368289733
3762. in early june	ten million young men registered by name and number	967.4003127708027
3763. the day passed	without incident in spite of the warning of senator james a reed	of missouri: baker you will have the streets of our american	cities running with blood on registration day	3545.5533321339053
3764. on july 20 the	first drawing of numbers occurred in the senate office building before	a distinguished group of congressmen and high army officers	3695.7866822268707
3765. secretary	of war baker blindfolded put his hand into a large glass	bowl and drew the initial number of those to be called	2313.6849059257383
3766. a man in mississippi wired: thanks for drawing 258- that's	me	752.4282072315834
3767. he was the first of 2800000 called to the army through the	selective service system	1097.2701591851746
3768. it was one thing to call men to the	colors; it was another to house feed and train them	2573.224421151714
3769. the existing	army posts were wholly inadequate	92.87479996435972
3770. in a matter of months the war	department built thirty-two camps each one accommodating fifty thousand	men- sixteen were under canvas in the south and sixteen with frame	structures in the north	5145.73202745445
3771. it was a gargantuan task; a typical	cantonment in the north had twelve hundred buildings an electric-sewer-water	system and twenty-five miles of roads	2332.660157934399
3772. at camp taylor in kentucky	a barracks was built in an hour and a half from timber that had	been standing in mississippi forests one week before	4291.386318250181
3773. the total	operation	was a construction project comparable in magnitude with the panama	canal but in 1917 time was in short supply; in three months	the army spent three-quarters as much as had been expended on the big	ditch in ten years	4381.415312666821
3774. in later years josephus danielswas	to	claim that world war 1 was the first in american history in which	there was great concern for both the health and morals of our soldiers	5144.595000047842
3775. it was the first american war in which the death rate from disease	was lower than that from battle due to the provision of trained	medical personnel compulsory	vaccination rigorous camp sanitation and adequate hospital	facilities	3865.086711882837
3776. to the middle of september 1918 there had been fewer than	10000 deaths from disease in the new army	2595.0159257331597
3777. this enviable record	would have been maintained but for a great and unexpected disaster which	struck	the world with murderous stealth	2047.4084851887953
3778. it was the influenza pandemic	of 1918-19	140.3151744589346
3779. the malady was popularly known as the spanish flu	from the alleged locale of its origin	1269.2675114342658
3780. the world-wide total of deaths	from spanish flu was around twenty million; in the united	states 300000 succumbed to it	2815.4547225229517
3781. in mid-september 1918 the influenza-pneumonia	pandemic swept through every american military camp; during	the eight-week blitz attack 25000 soldiers died from the disease	and the death rate increased almost	fifty times to 4 per week per 1000 men	4042.664595416808
3782. in spite of this catastrophe	the final mortality figure from disease in the american army	during world war 1 was 15 per 1000 per year contrasted with	110 per 1000 per year in the mexican war and 65 in the american civil	war	6699.466138780527
3783. both secretary of war baker and secretary of navy	daniels devoted much time and effort to the problem of providing	reasonably normal and wholesome activities in camp for the millions of	men who had been removed from their home environment	4225.970764690066
3784. their policy	ran counter to the traditional idea that a good fighter was usually a	libertine and that in sex affairs god-given passion was a proof	of manliness	4451.303265131169
3785. baker moved first; six days after war was declared	he appointed raymond fosdick chairman of the commission on training	camp activities	2023.11482006144
3786. fosdick a brother of minister	harry emerson fosdick was a graduate of princeton and a member of	phi beta kappa and the american philosophical association	3898.6197084402106
3787. his	assignment was not a new one because baker had sent him to the mexican	border in 1916 to investigate lurid newspaper stories about lack	of discipline drunkenness and venereal disease in american military	camps	3758.212479714345
3788. fosdick had found the installations surrounded by a battery of	saloons and houses of prostitution with filles de joie from all	over the country flocking to san antonio laredo and el paso to	woman the cribs	5776.05183109122

3801. new orleans had a notorious red-light	district extending over twenty-eight city blocks and the business-minded	mayor of the city journeyed to washington to present the	case for the god-given right of men to be men	3741.656592185797

3815. in the imagination of the nineteenth century the greek tragedians and	shakespeare stand side by side their affinity transcending all the	immense contrarieties of historical circumstance religious belief and	poetic form	3339.3885607276875

3989. often the historian must consider the use of intuition or instinct	by those individuals or nations which he is studying	1881.4829534450353

4000. brooks adams was consistent in his admonishments	to historians about the necessary tools or insights they needed to possess	2596.058889699007
4001. however as a practicing historian he himself has left few clues	to the amount of professional scholarship that he used when writing	history	2308.0007339801728
4002. in fact if judgments are to be rendered upon the soundness	of his historicism they must be based on scanty evidence	3017.531310529285
4003. what evidence	is available would seem to indicate that brooks unlike his older	brother henry had most of the methodological vices usually found	in the amateur	2729.8648329261136
4004. a credulousness a distaste for documentation an uncritical	reliance on contemporary accounts and a proneness to assume	a theory as true before adequate proof was provided were all evidences	of his failure to comprehend the use of the scientific method or to evaluate	the responsibilities of the historian to his reading public	7632.677354106568
4005. this	is not to assume that his work was without merit but the validity	of his assumptions concerning the meaning of history must always be	considered against this background of an unprofessional approach	3537.2606012838683
4006. his credulity is perhaps best illustrated in his introduction to the	emancipation of massachusetts which purports to examine the	trials of moses and to draw a parallel between the leader of the israelite	exodus from egypt and the leadership of the puritan clergy in	colonial new england	7139.742584042966

4008. in light of the scholarly reappraisals engendered by the higher	criticism this is a most remarkable statement particularly coming	from one who was well known for his antifundamentalist views	4658.773589622897
4009. the desire	to substantiate a thesis at the expense of sound research technique	smacks more of	the propagandist than the historian	2032.538817240178
4010. a similar amateurish	characteristic is revealed in adams' failure to check the	accuracy and authenticity of his informational sources	2606.0316296445226
4011. if he found data	that fitted his general plan he used it and counted his sources trustworthy	1417.7479222167067
4012. conversely if statistics were uncovered which contradicted	a cherished theory the sources were denounced as faulty	1887.6472830784382
4013. such manipulations	are frequently encountered in his essay on the suppression	of the monasteries during the english reformation	1572.7585279804005
4014. adams depended largely	on the dispatches of foreign ambassadors and observers in england	claiming that the reports of such agents had to be accurate because	there were no newspapers	4636.284302000383
4015. this is certainly an irrational dogmatism	in which the modern mind attempts to understand the spirit of the sixteenth	century on twentieth-century terms	2330.766261729362

4293. on	the other hand the bright vision of the future has been directly stated	in science fiction concerned with projecting ideal societies- science	fiction of course is related if sometimes distantly to that	utopian literature optimistic about science literature whose period	of greatest vigor in the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries	produced edward bellamy's looking backward and h g	wells's a modern utopia	5712.7788096797085

4295. childhood's end- apparently indebted to kurd	lasswitz's utopian romance auf zwei planeten and	also to wells's histories of the future especially the world set	free-	describes	the bloodless conquest of earth by the overlords vastly superior	creatures who come to our world in order to prepare the human race for	its next stage of development an eventual merging with the composite	mind of the universe	5738.0770937207535
4296. arriving just in time to stop men from turning	their planet into a radioactive wasteland the overlords unite earth	into one world in which justice order and benevolence prevail and	ignorance poverty and fear have ceased to exist	6089.575054979604
4297. under their rule	earth becomes a technological utopia	168.2116195531729
4298. both abolition of war and new	techniques of production particularly robot factories greatly increase	the world's wealth a situation described in the following passage	which has the true utopian ring: everything was so cheap that	the necessities of life were free provided as a public service by	the community as roads water street lighting and drainage had once	been	8223.437765829049
4299. a man could travel anywhere he pleased eat whatever he fancied-	without handing over any money	1253.2346686204498
4300. with destructive tensions and	pressures removed men have the vigor and energy to construct a new human	life- rebuilding entire cities expanding facilities for entertainment	providing unlimited opportunities for education- indeed for	the first time giving everyone the chance to employ his talents to the	fullest	7020.822375252838
4301. mankind as a result attains previously undreamed of levels	of civilization and culture a golden age which the overlords a very	evident symbol of science have helped produce by introducing reason	and the scientific method into human activities	4052.809977163227
4302. thus science is the	savior of mankind and in this respect childhood's end only	blueprints in greater detail the vision of the future which though not	always so directly stated	has nevertheless been present in the minds	of most science-fiction writers	6441.543170444612
4303. considering then the optimism	which has permeated science fiction for so long what is really remarkable	is that during the last twelve years many science-fiction writers	have turned about and attacked their own cherished vision of the future	have attacked the childhood's end kind of faith that science	and technology will inevitably better the human condition	5294.675498409938
4304. and they	have done this on a very large scale with a veritable flood of novels	and stories which are either dystopias or narratives of adventure	with dystopian elements	4653.602026538951
4305. because of the means of publication- science-fiction	magazines and cheap paperbacks- and because dystopian science	fiction is still appearing in quantity the full range and extent	of this phenomenon can hardly be known though one fact is evident:	the science-fiction imagination has been immensely fertile in its extrapolations	4811.759381396234
4306. among the dystopias for example isaac asimov's the	caves of steel portrays the deadly effects on human life	of the super-city of the future; james blish's a case of conscience	describes a world hiding from its own weapons of destruction	in underground shelters; ray bradbury's fahrenheit	451 presents a book-burning society in which wall television	and hearing-aid radios enslave men's minds; walter m miller	jr's a canticle for leibowitz finds men after	the great atomic disaster stumbling back to their previous level of	civilization and another catastrophe; frederick pohl's the midas	touch predicts an economy of abundance which in order	to remain prosperous must set its robots to consuming surplus production;	clifford d simak's how-2 tells of a future	when robots have taken over leaving men nothing to do; and robert	sheckley's the status civilization describes a world	which frightened by the powers of destruction science has given it	becomes static and conformist	0.30166232349522504
4307. a more complete list would also include	bradbury's the pedestrian philip k	dick's	solar lottery wilson	tucker's the long loud silence jack vance's	to live forever	gore vidal's messiah and	bernard wolfe's limbo as well as the three perhaps most	outstanding dystopias frederik pohl and c m kornbluth's	the space merchants kurt vonnegut's player	piano works which	we will later examine in detail	5668.11859361769
4308. the novels and stories like pohl's	drunkard's walk with the focus on adventure and	with the dystopian elements only a dim background- in this case an	uneasy overpopulated world in which the mass of people do uninteresting	routine jobs while a carefully selected university-trained elite	runs everything- are in all likelihood as numerous as dystopias	7903.414830026576
4309. there is of course nothing new about dystopias for they belong	to a literary tradition which including also the closely related satiric	utopias stretches from at least as far back as the eighteenth century	and swift's gulliver's travels to the twentieth century	and zamiatin's we capek's war with the newts huxley's	brave new world e m forster's the machine	stops c s lewis's that hideous strength	and orwell's nineteen eighty-four and which in science fiction	is represented	before the present deluge as early as wells's trilogy the	time machine a story of the days to come and when	the sleeper wakes and as recently as jack williamson's with	folded hands the classic story of men replaced by their	own robots	0.20124717349522497
4310. what makes the current phenomenon unique is that so	many science-fiction writers have reversed a trend and turned to writing	works critical of the impact of science and technology on human life	5166.62244524354
4311. since the great flood of these dystopias has appeared only in the	last twelve years it seems fairly reasonable to assume that the chief	impetus was the 1949 publication of nineteen eighty-four an assumption	which is supported by the frequent echoes of such details as	room 101 along with education by conditioning from brave new world	a book to which science-fiction writers may well have returned	with new interest after reading the more powerful orwell dystopia	0.20124717349522497
