4314. nevertheless	with all these qualifications and exceptions the current dystopian	phenomenon remains impressive for its criticism that science and technology	instead of bringing utopia may well enslave dehumanize and even	destroy men	5182.4378184299585
4315. how effectively these warnings can be presented is seen	in pohl and kornbluth's the space merchants vonnegut's	player piano and wyndham's re-birth	2174.7547201630814
4316. easily	the best known of these three novels is the space merchants a	good example of a science-fiction dystopia which extrapolates much more	than the impact of science on human life though its most important	warning is in this area namely as to the use to which discoveries in	the behavioral sciences may be put	7862.798349774998
4317. the novel which is not merely dystopian	but also brilliantly satiric describes a future america where	one-sixteenth of the population the men who run advertising agencies	and big corporations control the rest of the people the submerged	fifteen-sixteenths who are the workers and consumers with the government	being no more than a clearing house for pressures	5325.417851509169
4318. like	ours the economy of the space merchants must constantly expand in order	to survive and like ours it is based on the principle of ever	increasing everybody's work and profits in the circle of consumption	5774.304886634885
4319. the consequences of course have been dreadful: reckless expansion	has led to overpopulation pollution of the earth and depletion	of its natural resources	2309.7584843784102
4320. for example even the most successful executive	lives in a two-room apartment while ordinary people rent space in	the stairwells of office buildings in which to sleep at night; soyaburgers	have replaced meat and wood has become so precious that it is	saved for expensive jewelry; and the atmosphere is so befouled that	no one dares walk in the open without respirators or soot plugs	8638.213483158046
4321. while the space merchants indicates as kingsley amis has	correctly observed some of the impending consequences of the growth	of industrial and commercial power and satirizes existing habits	in the advertising profession its warning and analysis penetrate	much deeper	4123.006490203128
4322. what is wrong with advertising is not only that it is	an outrage an assault on people's mental privacy or that it	is a major cause for a wasteful economy of abundance or that it contains	a coercive tendency	6202.102013739312
4323. rather what kornbluth	and pohl are really doing is warning against the dangers inherent	in perfecting a science of man and his motives	2330.589954182945
4324. the space	merchants like such humanist documents as joseph wood krutch's	the measure of man and c s lewis's the abolition	of man considers what may result from the scientific study	of human nature	5483.650460127931
4325. if man is actually the product of his environment	and if science can discover the laws of human nature and the ways in which	environment determines what people do then someone- a someone	probably standing outside traditional systems of values- can turn around	and develop completely efficient means for controlling people	5019.6286034160685
4326. thus	we will have a society consisting of the planners or conditioners	and the controlled	1651.7384900448815
4327. and this of course is exactly what madison avenue	has been accused of doing albeit in a primitive way with its hidden	persuaders and what the space merchants accomplish with much	greater sophistication and precision	3766.4874701146737
4328. pohl and kornbluth's	ad men have long since thrown out appeals to reason and developed techniques	of advertising which tie in with every basic trauma and neurosis	in american life which work on the libido of consumers which	are linked to the great prime motivations of the human spirit	7342.026598745928
4329. as the hero mitchell courtenay explains before his conversion	the job of advertising is to convince people without letting them	know that they're being convinced	2599.459839533222
4330. and to do this requires first	of all the kind of information about people which is provided by the	scientists in industrial anthropology and consumer research who for	example tell courtenay that three days is the optimum priming period	for a closed social circuit to be triggered with a catalytic cue-phrase-	which means that an effective propaganda technique is to send	an idea into circulation and then three days later reinforce or undermine	it	0.30166232349522504
4331. and the second requirement for convincing people without	their knowledge is artistic talent to prepare the words and pictures which	persuade by using the principles which the scientists have discovered	3235.4210513348526
4332. thus the copywriter in the world of the space merchants is the	person who in earlier ages might have been a lyric poet the person capable	of putting together words that stir and move and sing	5768.832337441345
4333. as	courtenay explains here in this profession we reach into the souls	of men and women	1259.464394182496

4335. now the basic question to be asked in this situation	is what motivates the manipulators that is what are their values	2013.8468816983998

4338. we often say of a person that he looks young for his age	or old for his age	2368.930000242162
4339. yet even in the more extreme of such cases	we seldom go very far astray in guessing what his age actually is	2179.758487941567

4341. young	for his age means only the presence of some minor characteristic	not quite usual	1100.9845312928935

4350. similarly the optimism of age	protests too much	250.33514190195075

4352. boy you ain't fooling	nobody but yourself	141.13380606760677
4353. we may say of some unfortunates	that they were never young	499.23591253461547

4367. i have known some	men and women who said that the selves they are told about or even remember	seem utter strangers to them now; that their remote past is as	discontinuous with their present selves as lacking in any conscious	likeness to their mature personality as the self of a butterfly may be	imagined discontinuous with that of the caterpillar it once was	5703.5148053154935

5145. there was a time some years ago when	local taxation by the cities and towns was sufficient to support their	own operations and a part of the cost of the state government as	well	3673.793098819669
5146. for many years a state tax on cities and towns was paid by the	several municipalities to the state from the proceeds of the general property	tax	4328.105872689201
5147. this tax was discontinued in 1936	43.619882224000044
5148. since that time	the demands of the citizens for new and expanded services have placed	financial burdens on the state which could not have been foreseen in	earlier years	4672.246502499242
5149. at the same time there has been an upgrading and expansion	of municipal services as well	1250.5854799456642
5150. thus there has come into being	a situation in which the state must raise all of its own revenues and	in addition must give assistance to its local governments	4651.023705123044
5151. this	financial assistance from the state has become necessary because	the local governments themselves found the property tax or at least at	the rates then existing insufficient for their requirements	3248.3798343177305

5154. this is being done both by the revaluation	of real property and by seeking out forms of personal property	hitherto neglected or ignored	3485.091961302494
5155. taxation of tangible movable	property in rhode island has been generally of a hands off nature	due possibly to several reasons: local assessors in the main	are not well paid and have inadequate office staffs the numerous	categories of this component of personal property make locating extremely	difficult and the inexperience of the majority of assessors	problems of taxing personal	property	5570.324945870407

5158. although the laws of the various	states in general specify the situs of property ie residence	or domicile of the owner or location of the property the exceptions	regarding boats airplanes mobile homes etc seem to add to	the uncertainty of the proper origination point for assessment	7119.8326040268585
5159. rhode island law specifies that all real estate is taxable in the	town in which it is situated	1574.0034543940124
5160. it also provides for the taxation of all	personal property belonging to inhabitants of the state both tangible	and intangible and the tangible personal property of non-residents	in this state	4829.916708241836
5161. in defining personal property it specifically mentions	all ships or vessels at home or abroad	1098.4569689602815

5163. although a similar situs for tangible property	is mentioned in the statute this is cancelled out by the provision	that definite kinds of property and all other tangible property	situated or being in any town is taxable where the property is situated	4393.1972904933
5164. this would seem to fix the tax situs of all movable personal property	at its location on december 31	2584.608994146324
5165. both boats and aircraft would	fall within this category as well as motor vehicles	946.9842101492164

5169. a recent example of this problem is the flying of six	airplanes on december 31 1960 from the newport airpark in middletown	to the north central airport in smithfield	3115.0682497485423

5171. middletown bases its claim on the general provision of the law that all	rateable property both tangible and intangible shall be taxed	to the owner thereof in the town in which such owner shall have had his	actual place of abode for the larger portion of the twelve months	next preceding the first day of april in each year	5464.035874269166

5173. this problem of fair and equitable assessment	of value is a difficult one to solve in that the determination of	fair valuation is dependent on local assessors who in general are	non-professional	and part-time personnel taking an individualistic approach	to the problem	4374.448515979951

5177. an adequately staffed and equipped state assessing	office could apply uniform methods and standards which would go far	toward producing equitable assessments on all properties throughout	the state	3013.0013612897665
5178. a single statewide assessing unit would eliminate the differences	and complications that are inherent in a system of 39 different	and independent assessing units	3697.426526859997
5179. the institute of public	administration in its report to the state fiscal study commission	in 1959 recommended consolidating and centralizing all aspects	of property tax administration in a single state agency professionally	organized and equipped for the job	4050.0641695370587
5180. the resulting setup it was	declared would be similar to that which is in successful operation	in a number of metropolitan counties as large or larger than rhode	island	4629.375943930788
5181. to determine the practice	and attitude of municipal governments concerning tangible movable property	a questionnaire was sent to all local government assessors or	boards of assessors in rhode island	3101.3084378037875
5182. the replies from each	individual town are not given in detail because the questions asked the	personal opinion of the several assessors and are not necessarily the	established policy of the town in each case	5626.611089873922
5183. there are legitimate reasons	for differences of opinion among the assessors as a whole and among	the public officials in each town	2189.665076527542
5184. these opinions of the assessors	are of significance in indicating what their thinking seems to be at	the present time	2807.5716685411835
5185. in reply to a question of whether they now	tax boats airplanes and other movable property excluding automobiles	nineteen said that they did and twenty that they did not	3083.5490774334785
5186. the wording	of the question was quite general and may have been subject to different	interpretations	1880.1141296832793
5187. one assessor checked boats only another trailers	and tractors one mentioned house trailers and two others referred	to trailers without specifying the type	2325.9141941265802
5188. in two cases airplanes only	were indicated	139.64042703810412
5189. it is difficult to tabulate exactly what was	meant in each individual situation but the conclusion may be drawn	that 21 towns do not assess movable personal property and of the remainder	only certain types are valued for tax purposes	4219.959084988413
5190. boats were indicated	specifically by only one of the five towns known to tax boats	1652.009909737992
5191. it would seem then that movable property and equipment is not taxed	as a whole but that certain types are taxed in towns where this is bound	to be expedient for that particular kind of personal property	3944.726709388318
5192. so few answered the question relating to their efforts to assess	movable property that the results are inconclusive	2367.613443764225
5193. only four towns indicated	that they made any more than a normal effort to list property	of this kind	1723.275105566577
5194. of greater interest is a question as to whether	movable property was assessed according to its location or ownership	2594.360217057935
5195. fifteen stated that it was according to location four by residence	of the owner and nineteen did not answer	1709.9927196019555
5196. twenty-seven assessors	stated that they were in favor of improved means for assessing movable	personal property and only five were opposed	3026.7795658775904
5197. seven others expressed	no opinion	14.953273608840712
5198. on this point there was fairly general agreement that	assessors would like to do more than they are doing now	2825.5469346851096
5199. it is not	clear however whether they are thinking of all movable property or	only of boats trailers aircraft or certain other types of personal	property whose assessment would be advantageous to their particular towns	3769.344956495027
5200. another question that was asked of the assessors was whether	they favored the assessment of movable property at its location or	at the residence of the owner	4265.125851444502
5201. eighteen voted for assessment by the	town in which it is located and eleven preferred assessment by the town	in which the owner resides	2455.2791903434318
5202. ten others made no reply	22.3801363950252
5203. of those who	have an opinion it seems that assessment by location is preferred	940.9018169786798
5204. there	was one vote for location being the place where the property is	situated for the greater portion of the twelve months preceding the assessment	date	4125.976158782663
5205. to summarize it may be said that there is no one	prevailing practice in rhode island with respect to the taxation	of movable property that assessors would like to see an improvement	and of those who have an opinion that assessment by the town of location	is preferred on the basis of their present knowledge	5255.150253191916
5206. the need for	greater knowledge is evident from their replies	564.8728353558583
5207. property	interest has been shown for a number	of years by local assessors in the possibility of taxing boats	1721.4743315353971
5208. assessors in rhode island are charged not only with placing a valuation	upon real and personal property but they also have the responsibility	to raise by a tax a sum not less than nor more than a specified	amount as ordered by a city council or financial town meeting	7340.99954549252
5209. it has been obvious to the assessors particularly those in shore	communities that boats comprise the largest category of tangible personal	property which they have been unable to reach	3089.5867107461327
5210. through their	professional organization the rhode island tax officials association	the question of taxing boats long has been debated and discussed	3053.1930752774947
5211. no satisfactory solution has been found but this is due more to the	difficulties inherent in the problem than to a lack of interest or diligence	on the part of the assessors	3452.5435379563773
5212. it has been estimated that	the value of boats in rhode island waters is something in excess	of fifty million dollars excluding commercial boats	3679.9553793058885
5213. it is obvious that	this is a potential and lucrative source of revenue for the assessors	of those towns where a substantial amount of such property would be	subject to taxation	3340.3030841177447
5214. it is known that at least five towns	place some	value on some boats for tax purposes	2127.4322971129786
5215. however few are taxed and	the owners and location of most boats are unknown to the assessors on	the date of assessment of town valuations	2601.871149832679
5216. no one really knows	how many boats there actually are or what their aggregate value may	be	2117.163815623345

5218. only a few	more than 10000 boats had been registered with the division of harbors	and rivers at the end of the 1960 boating season but many had	been taken out of the water early when the threat of a hurricane brought	the season to an early close	7231.858117200763

5270. division	stated in its simplest terms the main job of the	planning division is to plan for the future of the state of rhode	island	3887.3285169920528
5271. the activities of the planning division are defined in considerable	detail in the enabling act of the development council which	assigns to the agency both broad responsibilities and specific duties	in the field of planning	3765.4866483617543
5272. two years ago the institute of	public administration issued an extremely comprehensive report entitled	state-local relations in metropolitan rhode island	2833.2150815294144
5273. as	the result of an exhaustive review of the recommendations contained in	this report plus an analysis of our own enabling act the planning	division developed a number of basic planning objectives which caused	a reorientation of its work program	4212.906591942383
5274. these objectives are stated here	because of their importance in understanding the current activities	first priority will be given to	the preparation of a meaningful state guide plan to serve as a background	recognizing	the truth of the statement by the institute of public administration	that metropolian planning means or	should mean state planning the state guide plan will take into account	the metropolitan nature of many of rhode island's problems	0.30166232349522504
5275. it will continue to be an objective of this division to encourage	the acceptance of planning as a proper and continuing responsibility	of local government	2592.276765134944
5276. to this end the community assistance program	of the planning division will continue to be operated as a staff function	to make available on a shared cost basis technical planning	assistance to those communities in the state unable to maintain their	the planning division will take the initiative	in encouraging planning cooperation at all levels of government;	among the operating departments of the state; between the cities	and towns of the state; and on a regional basis between the six new	on the basis that all citizens of the state	are entitled to benefit equally in the development of its resources	plans for the provision of essential services will	be based on need regardless of arbitrary political boundaries within	the state development budget	will reflect the capital needs of all the state agencies and the priority	of the projects in the budget will be based on the state plan	0.30166232349522504
5277. particular attention will	be given means of strengthening the economy of the state through the	development of industry and recreation	1888.423476717174
5278. functionally the planning	division carries out four activities: long-range state planning	current state planning local planning assistance; and the preparation	of the state development budget	3887.633835853879
5279. the planning division has embarked on the most complete and comprehensive	state planning program in the nation	1428.4191495696934
5280. the long range aspects of	this program are divided into four distinct phases: basic mapping	inventory analysis and plan and policy formation	3259.7294395824924
5281. the work program	as it was originally proposed was to take five years to complete	1098.53768876438
5282. recent	events- particularly the necessity of providing planning information	for the statewide origindestination study of the department	of public works- indicate that this schedule will have to be accelerated	4659.497683605426
5283. the basic mapping phase of the program has been completed and	basic	since accurate base maps are necessary for any planning	program the first step taken by the planning division to implement the	long range state plan has been to prepare two series of base maps-	one at a scale of 1 inch to a mile and the second a series of 26 sheets	at a scale of 1 inch to 2000 feet covering the entire state	0.20124717349522497
5284. with	these maps completed the inventory phase of the plan has been started	1184.2304590229955
5285. with the aid of matching federal funds available	under section 701 of the housing act of 1954 as amended the planning	division began a one year program july 1 1960 to complete the inventory	phase of the state planning program	4227.969536356324
5286. this phase consists of four	items: urban land use rural land use physical features and public	utility service areas	2585.0223243472237
5287. since the validity of all subsequent planning	depends on the accuracy of the basic inventory information great care	is being taken that the inventory is as complete as possible	3114.581766914059
5288. the urban land use study carried out by the planning division staff	has consisted of identifying and mapping all urban land uses which are	of significance to statewide planning	4633.009454489707
5289. the rural land use study is	being carried out under contract by the university of rhode island	and identifies all agricultural land uses in the state by type of use	3230.8409592256803
5290. the mapping of important physical features such as slopes and types	of soil and the collection of all available information pertaining to	public utility service areas are being conducted as staff projects and	like the other two inventory projects are scheduled for completion	july 1 1961	7018.184684171077
5291. the collection of information is meaningless	unless it is understood and used for a definite purpose	1257.8159382335757
5292. it is not within the scope of	this report elaborate in any great detail upon special districts in	rhode island	2801.75585264529
5293. however a word should be mentioned in regard to them	as independent units of government	1098.4795437864645
5294. there are forty-seven special	district governments in rhode island	districts four housing authorities and the kent county water		1477.0859990503527
5295. these forty-seven special purpose governments have the	authority to levy taxes to borrow money own property sue and be sued	and in general to exercise normal corporate powers	2999.0266174813414
5296. unlike cities	and towns however they do not have to submit any financial statements	to the state bureau of audits	2806.0066368506605

5299. a	review of practices in other states regarding fiscal uniformity is pertinent	to this report	1089.7553861813713
5300. included in the findings are:  forty-six	states including rhode island end their fiscal year on june	30	2117.4402902291704
5301. the other four states end on varying dates: alabama	new york and texas		433.86627179659956
5302. in sixteen states the fiscal year ending of the	cities is the same as that of the state: alaska arizona	california delaware massachusetts montana nevada new mexico	north carolina north dakota oklahoma oregon vermont		4155.309500860818
5303. in eleven states	the fiscal year of the cities ends on december 31 while the state fiscal	year ends on june 30	hampshire new jersey ohio south dakota utah washington		2361.426802091185
5304. in eight states whose fiscal years close	on june 30 a majority of their cities close their fiscal year on december	31:		2192.508813235092
5305. one state alabama closes	its fiscal year on september 30 and all cities in the state with	one exception also close fiscal years on september 30	2748.3789607456156
5306. mississippi closes its fiscal year on june 30 while all of its cities	close their fiscal years on september 30	2823.111045029943
5307. pennsylvania closes	its fiscal year on may 31	165.88773191203182
5308. all of its cities close their fiscal	years on december 31	757.0873762434081
5309. the remaining twelve states have varying	fiscal years for the state city and local governments	1096.0190237635113
5310. however	only illinois oregon louisiana and rhode island have a situation	in which the sundry units of government vary widely in relation to fiscal	uniformity	3901.5156757132836
5311. an excellent summary of advantages concerning	the uniform fiscal year and coordinated fiscal calendars was contained	in a paper presented by a public finance authority recently	2745.6219267969236
5312. he listed	among the values of fiscal uniformity:  the uniform fiscal	year requires compliance with common sense administration of local	finances: adoption of the budget or financial plan in advance of spending	5157.346135838241
5313. the uniform fiscal year ensures conformance with another	common sense rule that of having cash in the bank before checks	are drawn	2173.4209767443217
5314. it enables towns to make more economical purchases and to	take advantage of cash discounts	1629.5792985867351
5315. the uniform fiscal year promotes	more careful budgeting and strengthens control over expenditures	790.8473959887726
5316. by fixing the tax rate in advance of spending upper limits are set	on expenditures	1639.7703635836501
5317. the uniform fiscal year brings the town's	fiscal year into line with that of the schools which expend the largest	share of local disbursements	2453.636000827422
5318. this greatly simplifies the town's	bookkeeping and financial reporting	391.39660530456024
5319. the uniform fiscal	year eliminates interest charges on money borrowed in the form of tax	anticipation notes	1417.338085672191
5320. furthermore tax collections not immediately needed	for current expenditures may be invested in short-term treasury notes	augmenting the town's miscellaneous revenues and reducing the tax	levy	4097.957639797461
5321. the uniform fiscal year facilitates inter-town comparison	of revenues and expenditures	500.66543666297696
5322. when towns have the same fiscal	year it is relatively easy to make meaningful comparisons; and as the	cost of local government increases the demand for such comparison also	increases	4828.524216507225
5323. towns having different fiscal years are difficult to compare	259.5829764832769
5324. of all advantages probably none is more important than	the elimination of tax anticipation notes	1654.8002861171117
5325. borrowing in anticipation	of current taxes and other revenues is a routine procedure of the majority	of municipalities at all times	2029.321914146599
5326. it may be by bank loans sale	of notes or warrants or by the somewhat casual method of issuance and	registration of warrants	3485.3411031334326
5327. in any event it is a form of borrowing which	could be and should be rendered unnecessary	1416.3555816235805
5328. its elimination would	result in the saving of interest costs heavy when short-term money rates	are high and in freedom from dependence on credit which is not always	available when needed most	5157.44755185319
5329. this type of borrowing can be reduced	to a minimum if quarterly installment payment of taxes is instituted	and the first payment placed near the opening of the fiscal year	3223.1553062843814
5330. any	approach	toward such a system looks toward saving and security	756.3040330555175
5331. it should be noted that there are other and equally important reasons	for establishing meaningful intergovernmental reporting bases on a uniform	fiscal year	2303.318065097876
5332. both the federal and state governments commence their	fiscal years on july 1	1192.1349447563994
5333. both units of government contribute increasingly	large sums of money to the several local governments in this	state as indicated below:    it has been said that when local	government revenues were mostly produced locally from the property	tax the lack of a uniform fiscal year was no great handicap; but with	the growth of state and federal fiscal aid the emphasis on equalization	and the state-local sharing of responsibility for certain important	functions this is no longer true	0.20124717349522497
5334. the haphazard fiscal year calendar	is an obstacle to the planning of clear and efficient state-local	revenue and expenditure relationships	2825.319797329382
5335. although	there are many sound reasons for adopting uniform and coordinated fiscal	years in rhode island there are also certain difficulties encountered	2189.5681343807532
5336. these involve more the mechanics employed in adjusting to fiscal	uniformity than they do actual actual disadvantages to the principle	2816.3534299587354
5337. one problem is a matter of shifting dates; the other is how to	finance the transition	1260.6458689848037
5338. little can be done about the changing	of dates	392.2372170422557
5339. this is an inherent part of adjusting fiscal calendars	259.3136685072351
5340. it	usually means a confused and disgruntled tax-paying public for a period	of time	1419.740054639635
5341. but cooperation and understanding between local officials	and the citizenry help lessen this problem	941.2336543038484
5342. the other problem	is the matter of financing the transition period in the several cities	and towns	2135.8252747510164
5343. this will be covered more fully later	93.6267133677476
5344. it should be kept	in mind that the ease or difficulty with which a town or city can	convert to the proposed plan is directly dependent upon the financial	condition of that town or city	5650.956112645458
5345. fortunately there are no cities or towns	in the state with one or two possible exceptions that are in too	difficult a position to finance the proposed change	2991.4664073326517
5346. sacrifice will	have to be made in some cases but it is to the municipality's advantage	to finance the change-over for a short period of time rather than	pay interest on tax anticipation notes indefinitely	5612.992527336834
5347. fiscal calendars	the advantages of a uniform fiscal year and well	synchronized fiscal and tax collection calendars are sufficiently great	for rhode island municipalities to exert effort to secure them	3229.648477623971
5348. the	type of program desired can be determined by the nature and extent	of the adjustments needed	2129.530394006622
5349. two features are immediately evident	14.818609920222944
5350. first	the present situation is too varied to be systematized by any single	formula	1402.249129580904
5351. second the shift to a uniform july 1-june 30 fiscal year	will of itself improve the tax collection calendars of the great	majority of cities and towns	2863.802843150427
5352. there are at least two problems to consider:	one is a matter of adjusting the fiscal calendar; the other	is how to finance the adjustments when necessary	4302.0461034335995
5353. the latter matter	is considered in detail in a later section	500.64166738303646
5354. twelve cities and	towns in rhode island presently indicate some plans to establish a	uniform andor coordinated fiscal-tax year calendar	2815.5333996856107
5355. plans vary from	the talking stage to establishing special committees to accomplish	this end	938.8374926160911
5356. what is important here is that many of the cities and towns	recognize the need for improved fiscal practices and are taking the	initiative to obtain them	4291.994463206573
5357. an analysis of the fiscal-tax collection	year calendars throughout the state indicates that transition	may not be as painful as is commonly thought	2318.964997604689
5358. however it must be stressed	that much depends upon the financial condition of the individual	cities and towns involved	2590.1405240341355
5359. the adjustments needed to establish	a uniform and coordinated fiscal-tax collection year calendar throughout	rhode island based on a july 1-june 30 year are shown below	2732.8605499928335
5360. six cities and towns are presently on a	july 1-june 30 fiscal year and have coordinated their tax collection	year with it	3268.853128443122
5361. no change is required for these towns	93.89059039364501

5544. another recent achievement was the successful development of a method	for the complete combustion in a bomb calorimeter of a metal in fluorine	when the product is relatively non-volatile	4666.151909457508
5545. this work gave a heat	of formation of aluminum fluoride which closely substantiates a value	which had been determined by a less direct method and raises this	property to 15 percent above that accepted a few years ago	4045.773549519165
5546. similar measurements	are being initiated to resolve a large discrepancy in the	heat of formation of another important combustion product beryllium fluoride	3242.499699002327
5547. the development and testing of new apparatus to measure	other properties is nearing completion	942.7469975423794
5548. in one of these an exploding-wire	device to study systems thermodynamically up to 6000 f and	100 atmospheres pressure a major goal was achieved	3698.0155120009013
5549. the accuracy of	measuring the total electrical energy entering an exploding wire during	a few microseconds was verified when two independent types of comparison	with the heat energy produced had an uncertainty of less than 2	percent	3941.618800689361
5550. this agreement is considered very good for such short time intervals	750.4298736776498
5551. the method of calibration employs a fixed resistance element	as a calorimeter	646.219334718815
5552. the element is inserted	in the discharge circuit in place of the exploding wire	and the calorimetric heating of the element is measured with high accuracy	4093.6966729645987
5553. this is used as a reference for comparing the ohmic heating and	the electrical energy obtained from the measured current through the	element and the measured voltage across the element	3249.0125576418295
5554. a high-speed	shutter has been developed in order to permit photographic observation	of any portion of the electrical wire explosion	2803.9569720648506
5555. the shutter consists	of two parts: a fast-opening part and a fast-closing part	789.9584198798772
5556. using	edgerton's method the fast-closing action is obtained from the	blackening of a window by exploding a series of parallel lead wires	3272.422420799666
5557. the fast-opening of the shutter consists of a piece of aluminum foil	placed directly in front of the camera lens so that	no light may pass into the camera	3107.933485848328
5558. the opening action is obtained	when a capacitor charged to high voltage is suddenly discharged through	the foil	2375.266639767375
5559. during the discharge the magnetic forces set up by the	passage of current cause the edges of the foil to roll inward toward	its center line thus allowing light to pass into the camera	3662.4526219999643
5560. experiments	have shown that the shutter is 75 percent open in about 60-80 microseconds	1412.7041921689167
5561. the shutter aperture may be made larger or smaller by changing	the foil area and adjusting the electrical energy input to the foil	2329.77376608996
5562. besides	the well-known hydrogen line at 21 cm wavelength the spectra of	extraterrestrial radio sources may contain sharp lines characteristic	of other atoms ions and small molecules	4286.496425307145
5563. the detection and study	of such line spectra would add considerably to present information on	interstellar gas clouds and perhaps planetary atmospheres	2168.2628297933556
5564. among the	most likely producers of detectable radio line spectra are the light	diatomic hydrides oh and ch; somewhat less likely sources	are the heavier hydrides sh sih and sch	4802.052407953387
5565. very small	concentrations of these hydrides should be detectable; in interstellar	gas concentrations as low as f moleculesf may be sufficient	as compared to the f hydrogen atoms f required for detection of	the 21-cm line	3853.2053657929528
5566. high sensitivity in radio telescopes is achieved	by reducing the bandwidth of the receiver; therefore only with	precise foreknowledge of the line frequencies is an astronomical	search for the radio spectra of these molecules feasible	5636.113205328423
5567. to secure precise	measurements of these frequencies a research program in free radical	microwave spectroscopy has been started	1581.0266534810876
5568. since conventional methods	are insensitive at the low frequencies of these molecular transitions	the paramagnetic resonance method is being used instead	3049.3847970681118
5569. this	involves the application of a strong magnetic field to the radical vapor	which shifts the low-frequency spectra to a conveniently high microwave	range where they may be measured with optimum sensitivity	3445.542455664002
5570. the first diatomic hydride investigated by the paramagnetic resonance	method was the oh radical	1408.731007714438
5571. results of this experiment include	the frequencies of the two strong spectral lines by which oh may	be identified in interstellar gas; the frequencies are 1665	2722.171222912587
5572. 36 f with an uncertainty of 0	140.99861455932154
5573. success in observing these	spectral lines has so far apparently been confined to the laboratory;	extraterrestrial observations have yet to be reported	2192.2893596010144
5574. preparations	are being made for similar experiments on ch and sh	radicals	958.3686928600252

5590. 2	f but increased to several millidegrees for bath temperatures slightly	greater than the |l point	1886.213085039008

5593. it has also been observed in helium	2 that large discrepancies can exist between surface vapor pressures	and those pressures measured by a vapor pressure thermometer	2735.469514333108
5594. this	has been attributed to helium film flow in the vapor pressure thermometer	1186.2149027170176
5595. in this case also the design of the thermometer can be modified	pressure transducer for pvt	precise pressure-volume-temperature measurements on	corrosive gases are dependent on a sensitive yet rugged pressure transducer	3336.501625275233
5596. a prototype which fulfills the requirements was developed and	thoroughly tested	752.4563516612329
5597. the transducer is a null-type instrument and employs	a stretched diaphragm 0	647.1860117476341
5598. 001 in thick and 1 in in diameter	250.20094280041204
5599. a small pressure unbalance displaces the diaphragm and changes the capacitance	between the diaphragm and an electrically insulated plate spaced	0	2049.940823119485
5600. spherical concave backing surfaces	support the diaphragm when excessive pressures are applied and prevent	the stresses within the diaphragm from exceeding the elastic limit	3718.6654053961297
5601. over a temperature range from 25 to 200 f and at pressures up to	250 atm an overload of 300 psi applied for a period of one day	results in an uncertainty in the pressure of at most one millimeter	of mercury	4383.3834175387265
5602. a 6-year study of the	transport properties of air at elevated temperatures has been completed	1644.6995093004402
5603. this project was carried out under sponsorship of the ballistic	missile division of the air research and development command us	air force and had as its goal the investigation of the transport	by diffusion of the heat energy of chemical binding	4297.352459450934

5653. mr speaker for several years now the commuter	railroads serving our large metropolitan areas have found it increasingly	difficult to render the kind of service our expanding population	wants and is entitled to have	3644.3445993643863
5654. the causes of the decline of the commuter	railroads are many and complex- high taxes losses of revenue to	government subsidized highway and air carriers to name but two	4653.188832747166
5655. and	the solutions to the problems of the commuter lines have been equally	varied ranging all the way from government ownership to complete	discontinuance of this important service	2975.634104359799
5656. there have been a number	of sound plans proposed	393.41099736883984
5657. but none of these has been implemented	94.59881686178586
5658. instead we have stood idly by watched our commuter railroad service	decline and have failed to offer a helping hand	2819.363466335993
5659. though the number	of people flowing in and out of our metropolitan areas each day has increased	tremendously since world war 2 total annual rail commutation	dropped 124 million from 1947 to 1957	3557.39894699428
5660. nowhere has this decline	been more painfully evident than in the new york city area	1646.6735837404728
5661. here the	new york central railroad one of the nation's most important	carriers has alone lost 47	1414.5914596370076
5662. 6 percent of its passengers since 1949	140.46052844132456
5663. at this time of crisis in our nation's commuter railroads	a new threat to the continued operations of the new york central has	appeared in the form of the chesapeake + ohio railroad's proposal	for control of the baltimore + ohio railroads	2626.7351662373667
5664. the new york	central has pointed out that this control if approved by the interstate	commerce commission would give the combined c + o-b	+ o railroad a total of 185 points served in common with the	new york central	3686.1893970752462
5665. not only is this kind of duplication wasteful	but it gives the combined system the ability to take freight traffic	away from the new york central and other railroads serving the area	3445.5534575010483
5666. the new york central notes:   the freight traffic	most susceptible to raiding by the c + o-b + o provides	the backbone of central's revenues	1649.2745854726084
5667. these revenues make it	possible to provide essential freight and passenger service over the entire	new york central system as well as the new york area commuter	and terminal freight services	3342.5095929280556
5668. if these services are to be maintained	the new york central must have the revenues to make them possible	2588.3180540189596
5669. the new york central today handles 60 percent of all	southbound commuter traffic coming into new york city	1566.821935922846
5670. this is a	$14 million operation involving 3500 employees who work on commuter	traffic exclusively	1639.4282116039005
5671. a blow to this phase of the central's operations	would have serious economic consequences not only to the railroad	itself but to the 40000 people per day who are provided with efficient	reasonably priced transportation in and out of the city	4293.624276783919
5672. there is a workable alternative to this potentially dangerous and harmful	c + o-b + o merger scheme-   the central	has pointed out	1365.1046243462977
5673. the logic of creating a strong balanced	competitive two-system railroad service in the east is so obvious	that b + o was publicly committed to the approach outlined here	2147.9426853188775
5674. detailed studies of the plan were well underway	250.2706794627351
5675. though	far from completion these studies indicated beyond a doubt that savings	would result which would be of unprecedented benefit to the railroads	concerned their investors their customers their users and to the	public at large	3851.5139925611256
5676. then abandoning the studies in the face of	their promising outlook for all concerned b + o entered on-again-off-again	negotiations with c + o which resulted in the present	situation	2356.1559048450736
5677. in the light of the facts at hand however	new york central intends to pursue the objective of helping to create	a healthy two-system eastern railroad structure in the public interest	3340.953349706604
5678. the interstate commerce commission will commence its	deliberations on the proposed c + o-b + o merger on	june 18	968.3057202561151
5679. obviously the interstate commerce commission will not force	the new york central to further curtail its commuter operations	by giving undue competitive advantages to the lines that wish to merge	3218.672137440392
5680. however there is a more profound consideration to this proposed	merger than profit and loss	1655.7380220818868
5681. that is will it serve the long-range	public interest	262.92377423849507
5682. for the past 40 years congress has advocated	a carefully planned balanced and competitive railway system	1895.0802832449203

5742. from its inception in 1920 with the passage of public law 236 66th	congress the purpose of the vocational rehabilitation program has been	to assist the states by means of grants-in-aid to return disabled	men and women to productive gainful employment	6438.180284886469
5743. the authority for	the program was renewed several times until the vocational rehabilitation	program was made permanent as title 5 of the social security	act in 1935	2865.4422814259037
5744. up to this time and for the next eight years the services	provided disabled persons consisted mainly of training counseling	and placement on a job	3913.7187235967745
5745. recognizing the limitations of such a program	the 78th congress in 1943 passed p l 113 which broadened	the concept of rehabilitation to include the provision of physical	restoration services to remove or reduce disabilities and which revised	the financing structure	4301.552749714312
5746. despite the successful	rehabilitation of over a half million disabled persons in the first	eleven years after 1943 the existing program was still seen to be	inadequate to cope with the nation's backlog of an estimated two million	disabled	6204.651927694658
5747. to assist the states therefore in rehabilitating handicapped	individuals so that they may prepare for and engage in remunerative	employment to the extent of their capabilities the 83rd	congress enacted the vocational rehabilitation amendments of 1954		2937.748071943981
5748. these amendments to the vocational rehabilitation	act were designed to help provide for more specialized rehabilitation	facilities for more sheltered and half-way workshops for	greater numbers of adequately trained personnel for more comprehensive	services to individuals	and for other administrative improvements to increase the program's	overall effectiveness	7135.411891403959
5749. under the law as it	existed until 1943 the federal government made grants to the states	on the basis of population matching state expenditures on a 50-50	basis	2991.838972434033
5750. under p l 113 78th congress the federal government	assumed responsibility for 100% of necessary state expenditures	in connection with administration and the counseling and placement of	the disabled and for 50% of the necessary costs of providing clients	with rehabilitation case services	6693.944874015551

5799. at the entrance side of the shelter each roof beam is rested	on the inside 4 inches of the block wall	2029.1437396311117

5808. the last roof boards are covered	with blocks from outside the shelter	961.1733187085995

5929. a former du pont official became a general motors vice president	and set about maximizing du pont's share of the general motors	market	2320.406387827546
5930. lines of communications were established between the two	companies and several du pont products were actively promoted	2115.1169477350004
5931. within	a few years various du pont manufactured items were filling the entire	requirements of from four to seven of general motors' eight operating	divisions	2592.1631891070438
5932. the fisher body division long controlled by the	fisher brothers under a voting trust even though general motors owned	a majority of its stock followed an independent course for many years	but by 1947 and 1948 resistance had collapsed and its purchases	from du pont compared favorably with purchases by other general	motors divisions	7802.293372692826
5933. competitors came to receive higher percentage	of general motors business in later years but it is likely	that this trend stemmed at least in part from the needs of general	motors outstripping du pont's capacity	3733.5273771090424
5934. the fact	that sticks out in this voluminous record is that the bulk of du pont's	production has always supplied the largest part of the requirements	of the one customer in the automobile industry connected to du pont	by a stock interest	6556.069161562411
5935. the inference is overwhelming that du pont's	commanding position was promoted by its stock interest and was not gained	solely on competitive merit	2312.5861304904515
5936. 353 u s at 605	22.068708972151658
5937. this court agreed with the trial court that considerations of price	quality and service were not overlooked by either du pont or general	motors	2456.7562197379834
5938. 353 u s at 606	22.2569310126372
5939. however it determined that	neither this factor nor the fact that all concerned in high executive	posts in both companies acted honorably and fairly each in the	honest conviction that his actions were in the best interests of his own	company and without any design to overreach anyone including du pont's	competitors 353 u s at 607 outweighed the government's	claim for relief	5645.707987185082
5940. this claim as submitted to the district	court and dismissed by it 126 fsupp235 alleged violation	not only of  7 of the clayton act but also of   1 and 2 of	the sherman act	5478.665879106253
5941. the latter provisions proscribe any contract combination	or conspiracy in restraint of interstate or foreign trade and	monopolization of or attempts combinations or conspiracies to monopolize	such trade	2991.980556056974
5942. however this court put to one side without consideration	the government's appeal from the dismissal of its sherman	act allegations	2828.144306422427
5943. it rested its decision solely on  7 which reads	in pertinent part:   no corporation engaged in commerce	shall acquire directly or indirectly the whole or any part of	the stock or other share capital of another corporation engaged also in	commerce where the effect of such acquisition may be to substantially	lessen competition between the corporation whose stock is so acquired	and the corporation making the acquisition or to restrain such commerce	in any section or community or tend to create a monopoly of any	line of commerce	0.20124717349522497
5944. this section shall not apply to corporations	purchasing such stock solely for investment and not using the same	by voting or otherwise to bring about or in attempting to bring about	the substantial lessening of competition h	5933.600002106485
5945. the purpose	of this provision was thus explained in the court's opinion:	section 7 is designed to arrest in its incipiency not only	the substantial lessening of competition from the acquisition by one corporation	of the whole or any part of the stock of a competing corporation	but also to arrest in their incipiency restraints or monopolies	in a relevant market which as a reasonable probability appear at the	time of suit likely to result from the acquisition by one corporation	of all or any part of the stock of any other corporation	0.20124717349522497
5946. the section	is violated whether or not actual restraints or monopolies or the substantial	lessening of competition have occurred or are intended h	3507.069311110692
5947. 353 u s at 589	14.870317089324084
5948. thus a finding of conspiracy to	restrain trade or attempt to monopolize was excluded from the court's	decision	2363.946470690706
5949. indeed as already noted the court proceeded on the assumption	that the executives involved in the dealings between du pont	and general motors acted honorably and fairly and exercised	their business judgment only to serve what they deemed the best interests	of their own companies	4616.309271814049
5950. this however did not bar finding that du	pont had become pre-eminent as a supplier of automotive fabrics and	finishes to general motors; that these products constituted a line	of commerce within the meaning of the clayton act; that general	motors' share of the market for these products was substantial;	and that competition for this share of the market was endangered	by the financial relationship between the two concerns:   the	statutory policy of fostering free competition is obviously furthered	when no supplier has an advantage over his competitors from an acquisition	of his customer's stock likely to have the effects condemned	by the statute	0.30166232349522504
5951. we repeat that the test of a violation of  7 is	whether at the time of suit there is a reasonable probability that	the acquisition is likely to result in the condemned restraints	3552.458996878892
5952. the	conclusion upon this record is inescapable that such likelihood was proved	as to this acquisition h	2122.8245889146874
5953. 353 u s at 607	14.761660468612964
5954. on	the basis of the findings which led to this conclusion the court remanded	the case to the district court to determine the appropriate	relief	3880.140125832161
5955. the sole guidance given the court for discharging the task committed	to it was this:   the judgment must therefore be reversed	and the cause remanded to the district court for a determination	after further hearing of the equitable relief necessary and appropriate	in the public interest to eliminate the effects of the acquisition	offensive to the statute	5384.0704246877085
5956. the district courts in the framing	of equitable decrees are clothed 'with large discretion to model	their judgments to fit the exigencies of the particular case'	4077.6544399185173

5972. christiana securities company	and delaware realty + investment company major stockholders	in du pont and the stockholders of delaware were dealt with specially	by provisions requiring the annual sale by a trustee again over	a ten-year period of du pont's general motors stock allocable to	them as well as any general motors stock which christiana and delaware	owned outright	6828.243310993434
5973. if in the trustee's judgment reasonable	market conditions did not prevail during any given year he was to	be allowed to petition the court for an extension of time within the	ten-year period	3554.3224929767775

5992. it is not a medieval mental quirk or an attitude unnourished by sense	to believe that husbands and wives should not be subjected to such	a risk or that such a possibility should not be permitted to endanger	the confidentiality of the marriage relationship	6808.131390539468
5993. while it is easy	enough to ridicule hawkins' pronouncement in pleas of the crown	from a metaphysical point of view the concept of the oneness	of a married couple may reflect an abiding belief that the communion between	husband and wife is such that their actions are not always to be	regarded by the criminal law as if there were no marriage	5599.815713447135
5994. by	making inroads in the name of law enforcement into the protection which	congress has afforded to the marriage relationship the court today	continues in the path charted by the recent decision in wyatt	v united states 362 us 525 where the court held that	under the circumstances of that case a wife could be compelled to	testify against her husband over her objection	8545.65817226311
5995. one need not waver in	his belief in virile law enforcement to insist that there are other	things in american life which are also of great importance and to which	even law enforcement must accommodate itself	3841.9157259032872
5996. one of these is the	solidarity and the confidential relationship of marriage	964.6238971690515
5997. the court's	opinion dogmatically asserts that the husband-wife conspiracy doctrine	does not in fact protect this relationship and that hence the doctrine	enthrones an unreality into a rule of law	3227.4927733706213
5998. i am not	easily persuaded that a rule accepted by so many people for so many centuries	can be so lightly dismissed	3267.6268901028425

6000. petitioner who claims to be a conscientious objector was convicted	of violating  12 of the universal military training and service	act by refusing to be inducted into the armed forces	4828.508341182918
6001. he claims	that he was denied due process of law in violation of the fifth amendment	because at a hearing before a hearing officer of the department	of justice he was not permitted to rebut statements attributed	to him by the local board and at the trial he was denied the right	to have the hearing officer's report and the original report of	the federal bureau of investigation as to his claim	0.20124717349522497
6002. held:	on the record in this case the administrative procedures prescribed	by the act were fully complied with; petitioner was not denied due	petitioner	was not denied due process in the administrative proceedings	because the statement in question was in his file to which he had access	and he had opportunities to rebut it both before the hearing officer	of the department of justice and before the appeal board	0.30166232349522504
6003. pp	petitioner was not entitled to have the hearing officer's	notes and report especially since he failed to show any particular	need for them and he did have a copy of the department of justice's	petitioner was not entitled either in the administrative hearing at	the department of justice or at his trial to inspect the original report	of the federal bureau of investigation since he was furnished	a resume of it did not challenge its accuracy and showed no particular	need for the original report	0.20124717349522497

6009. petitioner who claims to be a conscientious	objector contends that he was denied due process both in the proceedings	before a hearing officer of the department of justice and at	trial	3334.750493709088
6010. he says that he was not permitted to rebut before the hearing	officer statements attributed to him by the local board and further	that he was denied at trial the right to have the department of justice	hearing officer's report and the original report of the federal	bureau of investigation as to his claim- all in violation of the	fifth amendment	8356.602025638082
6011. the trial judge decided that the administrative procedures	of the act were fully complied with and refused to require	the production of such documents	2456.317085382505
6012. petitioner was found guilty and sentenced	to 15 months' imprisonment	561.4233523622952
6013. the court of appeals affirmed	14.787615474763609
6014. we granted certiorari in view of the importance of	the questions in the administration of the act	2121.8982725764104
6015. we have concluded that petitioner's claims are controlled by the rationale	of gonzales v united states 348 us 407		and united states v nugent 346 us 1	and therefore affirm the judgment	3440.386804965493
6016. petitioner registered with	local board no 9 boulder colorado on march 17 1952	1183.7864099946598
6017. his	answers to the classification questionnaire reflected that he was a	minister of jehovah's witnesses employed at night by a sugar producer	2167.7807389036207
6018. he claimed 4-d classification as a minister of religion	devoting a minimum of 100 hours a month to preaching	2595.636370696735
6019. on november	13 1952 he was classified in class 1-a	373.39585620005874
6020. on november 22	1952 he wrote the board protesting this classification	757.2388839369472
6021. he again stated	that he was a regular minister; that he was devoting	an average	of 100 hours a month to actual preaching publicly in addition to	50 to 75 hours in other ministerial duties and that he opposed war in	any form	4433.911328017072
6022. thereafter he was classified 1-o	22.415103378580106
6023. on april 1 1953	after some six months of full-time pioneering petitioner discontinued	devoting 100 hours a month to preaching but failed to so	notify his local board	2974.9372652094803
6024. in a periodic review the local board on july	30 1953 reclassified him 1-a and upheld this classification	after a personal appearance by petitioner because of his willingness	to kill in defense of his church and home	5923.060190916771
6025. upon administrative approval	of the reclassification he was ordered to report for induction on	june 11 1956 but failed to do so	2169.6013141172107
6026. he was not prosecuted however	and his case was subsequently reopened in the light of sicurella	v united states 348 us 385	3245.8685021333104
6027. he was again	reclassified 1-a by the local board	261.4294442357293
6028. there followed a customary	department of justice hearing at which petitioner appeared	958.2566945941877
6029. in	his report to the attorney general the hearing officer suggested that	the petitioner be exempt only from combatant training and service	2196.593793447826
6030. on march 21 1957 however the department recommended approval of	the 1-a classification	1178.145934781581
6031. its ground for this recommendation was	that while petitioner claimed before the local board august 17 1956	that he	was devoting 100 hours per month to actual preaching the headquarters	of the jehovah's witnesses reported that he was no longer doing so	and on the contrary had relinquished both his pioneer and bible	student servant positions	5312.817260800027
6032. it reported that he now devoted only some	6-12 hours per month to public preaching and from 20 to 25 hours per	month to church activities	4121.158799136791
6033. his claim was therefore so highly exaggerated	the department concluded that it cast doubt upon his	veracity and consequently upon his sincerity and good faith	2576.4280997232536
6034. the	appeal board furnished petitioner a copy of the recommendation	565.8407534754102
6035. in	his answer thereto he advised the board that he had made no such statement	in 1956 and asserted that his only claim to pioneering	was in 1952	2986.1911793149347
6036. the appeal board however unanimously concurred in the	department's recommendation	557.8587731800851
6037. upon return of the file to the local	board petitioner was again ordered to report for induction and this	prosecution followed his failure to do so	2731.924277929076
6038. petitioner first contends	that the department denied him procedural due process by not giving	him timely opportunity before its final recommendation to the appeal	board to answer the statement of the local board as to his claim	of devoting 100 hours to actual preaching	6777.757657618281
6039. but the statement of the	local board attributing this claim to petitioner was in his file	1251.247059500855
6040. he	admitted that he knew it was open to him at all times and he could have	rebutted it before the hearing officer	3481.1925267468555
6041. this he failed to do asserting	that he did not know it to be in his file	1406.656224055787
6042. apparently he never	took the trouble to find out	388.5221032927103
6043. nevertheless he had ample opportunity	to contest the statement before the appeal board	791.9201619593871
6044. after the recommendation	of the department is forwarded to the appeal board that is the	appropriate place for a registrant to lodge his denial	3694.9833915584654
6045. we found in gonzales v united states supra that this	was the controlling reason why copies of the recommendation should be	furnished a registrant	2453.6254959028
6046. we said there that it was necessary that	a registrant be given an opportunity to rebut the department's	recommendation when it comes to the appeal board the agency with the	ultimate responsibility for classification	5479.403601490629
6047. we fail to see how such procedure resulted in any prejudice to petitioner's	contention which was considered by the appeal board and	denied by it	2583.227479453345
6048. as was said in gonzales it is the appeal board	which renders the selective service determination considered 'final'	in the courts not to be overturned unless there is no basis in fact	5137.415311089005
6049. estep v united states 327 us 114	93.10461008175155
6050. 348	u	s at 412-413	22.164030567642193
6051. but there are other contentions which might	be considered more difficult	499.0752816981453
6052. at his trial petitioner sought to secure	through subpoena duces tecum the longhand notes of the department's	hearing officer evensen as well as his report thereon	4116.461678674078
6053. petitioner	also claimed at trial the right to inspect the original federal	bureau of investigation reports to the department of justice	2029.2505521558203
6054. he alleged no specific procedural errors or evidence withheld; nor	did he elaborate just what favorable evidence the federal bureau of	investigation reports might disclose	3885.109764230537
6055. section 6 of the	act	as we have held does require the department's recommendation to	be placed in a registrant's file	2038.4901891389359
6056. gonzales v united states	supra	22.02099490756003
6057. but there is nothing in the act requiring the hearing	officer's report to be likewise turned over to the registrant	1887.963413801237
6058. while	the regulations formerly required that the hearing officer's report	be placed in the registrant's file this requirement was eliminated	in 1952	3260.0805021215506
6059. moreover the hearing officer's report is but intradepartmental	is directed to the attorney general and of course is not	the recommendation of the department	2478.337364075128
6060. it is not essentially different	from a memorandum of an attorney in the department of justice of	which the attorney general receives many and to which he may give	his approval or rejection	5334.45807858864
6061. it is but part of the whole process within	the department that goes into the making of the final recommendation	to the appeal board	2467.341761158871
6062. it is also significant that neither this	report nor the hearing officer's notes were furnished to the appeal	board	2584.0052570629796
6063. hence the petitioner had full opportunity to traverse the only	conclusions of the department on file with the board	1731.4686767635462
6064. petitioner	knew that the department's recommendation was based not on the hearing	officer's report but on the statement of the local board in his	file	3892.362478731201
6065. having had every opportunity to rebut the finding of the local	board before both the hearing officer and the appeal board petitioner	cannot now claim that he was denied due process because he did not succeed	3866.882493901617
6066. it appears to us that the same reasoning applies to the	production of the hearing officer's report and notes at the trial	3266.4175790501276
6067. in addition petitioner has failed to show any particular need for the	report and notes	1098.2004414852331
6068. while there are now allegations of the withholding	of favorable evidence developed at the hearing and a denial of	a full and fair hearing no such claim was made by petitioner at	any stage of the administrative process	6042.9026133222405
6069. moreover his testimony at	trial never developed any such facts	373.1454891915946
6070. in the light of these circumstances	as well as the fact that the issue at trial in this respect centered	entirely on the department's recommendation which petitioner	repudiated but which both the appeal board and the courts below found	supported by the record we find no relevancy in the hearing officer's	report and notes	7807.8400316319185
6071. finally petitioner says that he was entitled	to inspect the fbi report during the proceedings before the	hearing officer as well as at the trial	2604.2977482272927
6072. he did receive a resume of	it- the same that was furnished the appeal board- and he made no	claim of its inaccuracy	3477.035034428702
6073. even now no such claim is asserted	94.06124979419465
6074. he bases	his present contention on the general right to explore indicating that	he hopes to find some discrepancy in the resume	3255.9122171980844
6075. but this is fully	answered by united states v nugent supra	500.74819476625
6076. there we held	that the statutory scheme for review within the selective service	system h entitles conscientious objectors to no guarantee	that	the fbi reports must be produced for their inspection	5002.621164482551
6077. even if we were not bound by nugent petitioner	here would not be entitled to the report	1409.1631129238026
6078. the recommendation of	the department- as well as the decision of the appeal board- was	based entirely on the local board file not on an fbi report	4282.7070548703505
6079. with this enlarged role in	mind i should like to make a few suggestions: what we in the united	states do or do not do will make a very large difference in what	happens in the rest of the world	4223.342963668888
6080. we in this department must think about	foreign policy in its total context	1175.4851424729072
6081. we cannot regard foreign policy	as something left over after defense policy or trade policy or fiscal	policy has been extracted	2036.458640330322
6082. foreign policy is the total involvement	of the american people with peoples and governments abroad	1641.2282681180882
6083. that	means that if we are to achieve a new standard of leadership we must	think in terms of the total context of our situation	2580.553719883471
6084. it is the concern	of the department of state that the american people are safe and	secure- defense is not a monopoly concern of the department of defense	4470.792245945779
6085. it is also the concern of the department of state that our	trading relationships with the rest of the world are vigorous profitable	and active- this is not just a passing interest or a matter of	concern only to the department of commerce	4471.663727275579
6086. we can no longer rely on	interdepartmental machinery somewhere upstairs to resolve differences	between this and other departments	2348.5162287616567
6087. assistant secretaries of	state will now carry an increased burden of active formulation and coordination	of policies	1415.2191002631919
6088. means must be found to enable us to keep in	touch as regularly and as efficiently as possible with our colleagues	in other departments concerned with foreign policy	4464.076313944998
6089. i think we	need to concern ourselves also with the timeliness of action	786.7317238516687
6090. every	policy officer cannot help but be a planning officer	563.632885064203
6091. unless we keep	our eyes on the horizon ahead we shall fail to bring ourselves on target	with the present	1873.6424788154593
6092. the movement of events is so fast the pace so	severe that an attempt to peer into the future is essential if we are	to think accurately about the present	4838.7803067622945
6093. if there is anything which we	can do in the executive branch of the government to speed up the processes	by which we come to decisions on matters on which we must act	promptly that in itself would be a major contribution to the conduct	of our affairs	4822.114270463621
6094. action taken today is often far more valuable than action	taken several months later in response to a situation then out of	control	3453.3901720160693
6095. there will of course be times for delay and inaction	373.065990921095
6096. what i am suggesting is that when we delay or when we fail to act	we do so intentionally and not through inadvertence or through bureaucratic	or procedural difficulties	4661.892642422419
6097. i also hope that we can	do something about reducing the infant mortality rate of ideas- an affliction	of all bureaucracies	2036.1372975848444
6098. we want to stimulate ideas from the bottom	to the top of the department	1417.3537670097448
6099. we want to make sure that our junior	colleagues realize that ideas are welcome that initiative goes right	down to the bottom and goes all the way to the top	3208.731244098383
6100. i hope no one	expects that only presidential appointees are looked upon as sources	of ideas	1897.2065280876236
6101. the responsibility for taking the initiative in generating	ideas is that of every officer in the department who has a policy function	regardless of rank	2603.3447563485206
6102. further i would hope that we could	pay attention to little things	957.2054380777117
6103. while observing the operations of	our government in various parts of the world i have felt that in many	situations where our policies were good we have tended to ignore minor	problems which spoiled our main effort	3926.2667309192366
6104. to cite only a few examples:	the wrong man in the wrong position perhaps even in a junior	position	abroad can be a source of great harm to our policy; the attitudes	of a un delegate who experiences difficulty in finding adequate	housing in new york city or of a foreign diplomat in similar	circumstances in our capital can be easily be directed against the united	states and all that it stands for	0.30166232349522504
6105. dozens of seemingly small	matters go wrong all over the world	507.43698093943874

6111. he is expected to supervise to encourage to direct	to assist in any way he can	1247.1668401863922

6113. it occurred to me that you might be interested in some thoughts	which i expressed privately in recent years in the hope of clearing	up a certain confusion in the public mind about what foreign policy	is all about and what it means and of developing a certain compassion	for those who are carrying such responsibilities inside government	5426.098828572917

6117. the senior policy officer may	be moved to think hard about a problem by any of an infinite variety of	stimuli: an idea in his own head the suggestions of a colleague	a question from the secretary or the president a proposal by another	department a communication from a foreign government or an american	ambassador abroad the filing of an item for the agenda of the united	nations or of any other of dozens of international bodies a news	item read at the breakfast table a question to the president or the	secretary at a news conference a speech by a senator or congressman	an article in a periodical a resolution from a national organization	a request for assistance from some private american interests abroad	et cetera ad infinitum	0.20124717349522497
6118. the policy officer lives with his antennae	alerted for the questions which fall within his range of responsibility	2352.7803135732993

6120. for he knows that the first and sometimes most difficult job	is to know what the question is- that when it is accurately identified	it sometimes answers itself and that the way in which it is posed	frequently shapes the answer	6429.861377655192
6121. chewing it over with his colleagues	and in his own mind he reaches a tentative identification of the	question- tentative because it may change as he explores it further	and because if no tolerable answer can be found it may have to be changed	into one which can be answered	4962.295233915869
6122. meanwhile he has been thinking	about the facts surrounding the problem facts which he knows can	never be complete and the general background much of which has already	been lost to history	5180.407065144985

6387. the	cost of developing a major weapon system is now so enormous that the	greatest care must be exercised in selecting new systems for development	in determining the most satisfactory rate of development and in	deciding the proper time at which either to place a system into production	or to abandon it	5069.156418751385
6388. the deterrent power	of our armed forces comes from both their nuclear retaliatory capability	and their capability to conduct other essential operations in any	form of war	4290.985318919759
6389. the first capability is represented by a combination	of manned bombers carrier-based aircraft and intercontinental and intermediate	range missiles	1732.7222597793552
6390. the second capability is represented by our	deployed ground naval and air forces in essential forward areas together	with ready reserves capable of effecting early emergency reinforcement	4275.238939269234
6391. the strategic air command is the principal element	of our long-range nuclear capability	795.077728039962
6392. one of the important and difficult	decisions which had to be made in this budget concerned the role	of the b-70 a long-range supersonic bomber	3903.8809851606356
6393. this aircraft which	was planned for initial operational use about 1965 would be complementary	to but likewise competitive with the four strategic ballistic missile	systems all of which are scheduled to become available earlier	3646.246484341848
6394. the first atlas icbm's are now operational the first two	polaris submarines are expected to be operational this calendar year	and the first titan icbm's next year	4285.641173191731
6395. the minuteman solid-fueled	icbm is planned to be operational about mid-1963	503.3955461627006
6396. by	1965 several or all of these systems will have been fully tested and	their reliability established	2120.8468946389767
6397. thus the need for the b-70	as a strategic weapon system is doubtful	797.6864358119021
6398. however i am recommending	that development work on the b-70 air-frame and engines be continued	1652.1959561556687
6399. it is expected that in 1963 two prototype aircraft will be available	for flight testing	1096.4340748394984
6400. by that time we should be in a much better	position to determine the value of that aircraft as a weapon system	3261.9340229660097
6401. i am recommending additional acquisitions of the improved version	of the b-52	and procurement of the b-58 supersonic medium bomber together with	the supporting refueling tankers in each case	3116.600591013509
6402. these additional modern	bombers will replace some of the older b-47 medium bombers;	one b-52 can do the work of several b-47's which it will replace	4114.802116918039
