6443. this broad delegation leaves within our discretion	both the determination	of what degree of interference shall be considered excessive and the	methods by which such excessive interference shall be avoided	3210.081426799296
6444. the present proceeding is concerned with the standard broadcast	band from 540 kc to 1600 kc	1877.4268982904177
6445. whenever two or more standard	broadcast stations operate simultaneously on the same or closely adjacent	frequencies each interferes to some extent with reception of	the other	2728.3109365241216
6446. the extent of such interference- which may be so slight	as to be undetectable at any point where either of the stations renders	a usable signal or may be so great as to virtually destroy the service	areas of both stations- depends on many factors among the principal	ones being the distance between the stations their respective	radiated power and of particular significance here the time of day	8817.728853154482
6447. other factors playing a part in the the extent of am service	and interference are the frequency involved the time of year the position	of the year in the sunspot cycle ground conductivity along	the	transmission path atmospheric and manmade noise and others	4464.599457737092
6448. with the	existence of these many factors some of them variable it obviously	has never been and is not now possible for the commission to make assignments	of am stations on a case-to-case basis which will insure	against any interference in any circumstances	6670.749597187963
6449. rather such assignments	are made as they must be on the basis of certain overall rules	and standards representing to some extent a statistical approach to	the problem taking into account for each situation some of the variables	and averaging out others	in order to achieve the balance which must be struck between protection	against destructive interference and the assignment of a number of	stations large enough to afford optimum radio service to the nation	0.20124717349522497
6450. an example of the overall standards applied is the 20-to-1 ratio established	for the determination of that degree of cochannel interference	which is regarded as objectionable	4091.697520856537
6451. by this standard it is determined	that where two stations operating on the same frequency are involved	objectionable interference from station a exists at any point within	the service area of station b where station a's signal	is of an intensity one-twentieth or more of the strength of station b's	signal at that point	5187.951431681049
6452. the 20-to-1 ratio for cochannel	interference embodies one of the fundamental limiting principles which	we must always take into account in am assignments and allocations-	that signals from a particular station are potential sources	of objectionable interference over an area much greater than that within	which they provide useful service	7406.70710940499
6453. a second fundamental principle	is that involved particularly in the present proceeding- the difference	between nighttime and daytime propagation conditions with respect	to the standard broadcast frequencies	2855.803551100141
6454. this is a phenomenon familiar	to all radio listeners resulting from reflection of skywave signals at	night from the ionized layer in the upper atmosphere known as the ionosphere	4684.204780393277
6455. all am stations radiate both skywave and groundwave signals	at all hours; but during the middle daytime hours these skywave	radiations are not reflected in any substantial quantity and during	this portion of the day both skywave service and skywave interference	are in general negligible	4628.30017932923
6456. but during nighttime hours the skywave	radiations are reflected from the ionosphere thereby creating the possibility	of one station's rendering service via skywave at a much	greater distance than it can through its groundwave signal and at the	same time vastly complicating the interference problem because of the	still greater distance over which these skywave signals may cause interference	to the signals of stations on the same and closely adjacent	frequencies	0.30166232349522504
6457. because of the difference between daytime and nighttime	propagation conditions it has been necessary to evolve different allocation	structures for daytime and nighttime broadcasting in the am	band with many more stations operating during the day than at night	4128.357786343236
6458. it was recognized years ago that the transition from daytime	to nighttime propagation conditions and vice versa is not an instantaneous	process but takes place over periods of time from roughly	2 hours before sunset until about 2 hours after sunset and again from	roughly 2 hours before sunrise until some 2 hours after sunrise	7898.558313305368
6459. during	the period of about 4 hours around sunset skywave transmission conditions	are building up until full nighttime conditions prevail; during	the same period around sunrise skywave transmission is declining	until at about 2 hours after sunrise it reaches a point where it becomes	of little practical significance	4819.821904719346
6460. however in this case as elsewhere	it was necessary to arrive at a single standard to be applied to	all situations representing an averaging of conditions and thus to	fix particular points in time which would be considered the dividing points	between daytime and nighttime conditions	7024.053965442717
6461. it was determined that	the hours of sunrise and sunset respectively should be used for this	purpose	1411.5797335506531
6462. accordingly the 1938-39 rules adopted these hours as limitations	upon the operation of daytime stations	1646.3014794373107
6463. class 2 stations	operating on clear channels are required to cease operation or operate	under nighttime restrictions beginning either at local sunset	or sunset at the location of the dominant	class 1 station where located west of the class 2 station		3394.6155894186404
6464. the same restrictions apply	after local sunset in the case of class 3 stations operating on	regional channels which after that time are required to operate under	nighttime restrictions in order to protect each other	5616.223623683311
6465. with respect	to nighttime assignments the degree of skywave service and interference	is determined by skywave curves	giving average skywave values	2030.3892241842564
6466. these curves were derived	by an analysis of extensive skywave measurement data	966.4749941286024
6467. it was recognized	that skywave signals because of their reflected nature are of great	variability and subject to wide fluctuations in strength	2171.314353773121
6468. for this	reason the more uncertain skywave service was denominated secondary	in our rules as compared to the steadier more reliable groundwave	primary service and for both skywave service and skywave	interference signal strength is expressed in terms of percentage of	time a particular signal-intensity level is exceeded- 50 percent of	the time for skywave service 10 percent of the time for skywave interference	8575.790550082438
6469. as mentioned the allocation	of am stations represents a balance between protection against	interference and the provision of opportunity for an adequate number	of stations	2579.8978876572755
6470. the rules and policies to be applied in this process of	course must be based on objectives which represent what is to be desired	if radio service is to be of maximum use to the nation	5733.107572287223
6471. our objectives	to provide some	to provide as many choices of	to provide service	of local origin to as many listeners as possible	2336.8606101655596
6472. since broadcast	frequencies are very limited in number these objectives are to some	extent inconsistent in that not all of them can be fully realized and	to the extent that each is realized there is a corresponding reduction	of the possibilities for fullest achievement of the others	7130.144744945637
6473. accordingly	the commission has recognized that an optimum allocation pattern	for one frequency does not necessarily represent the best pattern	for other frequencies and has assigned different frequencies for use	by different classes of stations	3740.6352130406026
6474. some 45 frequencies are assigned for	use primarily by dominant class 1- a or class 1-	b clear-channel stations designed to operate with adequate	power and to provide service- both groundwave and skywave-	over large areas and at great distances being protected against	interference to the degree necessary to achieve this objective	7627.981376892103
6475. in dealing	with these frequencies the objective listed first above- provision	of service to all listeners- was predominant; the other objectives	were subordinated to it	2586.1346998675667
6476. the class 1 stations on these clear	channels are protected to their 0	1184.6228829061704
6477. 1-mvm groundwave contours	against daytime cochannel interference	93.6985515238213
6478. with respect to skywave service	rendered at night class 1- a stations are the only stations	permitted to operate in the united states on clear channels specified	for class 1- a operation and so render skywave service	free	from cochannel interference whereever they may be received; class	1- b stations are protected at night to their 0	8076.561387634744
6479. 5-mvm	50-percent	time skywave contours against cochannel interference	167.45912222227287
6480. since	the provision of skywave service requires adequate freedom from interference	only class 1 stations are capable of rendering skywave service	3046.3029065324317
6481. but nighttime operation by stations of other classes of course	entails skywave interference to groundwave service interference which	is substantial unless steps are taken to minimize it	2841.8872507733204
6482. with	respect to other frequencies these are designated as regional or local	and assigned for use by class 3 and class 4 stations respectively	stations operating generally with lower power	4831.58484305484
6483. in the allocation	pattern worked out for these frequencies the provision of long-range	service has to some extent been subordinated to the other two objectives-	assignment of multiple facilities and assignment of stations	in as many communities as possible	4136.439020738116
6484. as mentioned the primary	allocation objective to be followed in the allocation of stations	on clear channels is the provision of widespread service free from	destructive interference	4280.974954763242
6485. during nighttime hours because of the intense	skywave propagation then prevailing no large number of stations can	be permitted to operate on one of these channels if the wide area	service for which these frequencies are assigned is to be rendered satisfactorily	by the dominant stations which must be relied upon to render	it	5197.37631087519
6486. therefore under our longstanding allocation rules on some of	these channels no station other than the dominant	station is permitted to operate at night so that the 1- a	station can render service interference free wherever it can be received	6346.121430474306
6487. on the remainder of the clear channels the dominant	stations are protected as described above and the relatively	small number of secondary stations permitted to operate	on these channels at night are required to operate directionally	andor with reduced power so as to protect the class 1 stations	4836.727874128651
6488. in the daytime on the other hand since skywave transmission is relatively	inefficient it is possible to assign a substantially larger number	of stations on these channels	4282.566880994947
6489. additional class 2 assignments	for daytime operation can be made without causing destructive interference	to the class 1 stations or to each other and by their operation	provide additional service on these channels and additional local	outlets for a large number of communities	4463.7589456067935
6490. such additional daytime	class 2 assignments are appropriate if optimum use is to be made	of these frequencies and the commission has over the years made a large	number of them	5006.459326163932
6491. similarly on the regional channels many class 3	stations have been assigned either to operate daytime only or to operate	nighttime with directional antennas andor lower power	2862.6159970046474
6492. essentially the question presented for decision in the present daytime	skywave proceeding is whether our decision in 1938-1939 to	assign stations on the basis of daytime conditions from sunrise to sunset	is sound as a basis for am allocations or whether in the light	of later developments and new understanding skywave transmission	is of such significance during the hours immediately before sunset and	after sunrise that this condition should be taken into account and	some stations required to afford protection to other stations during these	hours	0.30166232349522504
6493. the decision	reached in 1938-39 was made after the accumulation of a large amount	of data and thorough study thereof	1877.8495301662285
6494. since then there has been a notable	increase in the number of stations and also the accumulation of additional	data and the development of new techniques for using it leading	to a better understanding of propagation phenomena	5908.156368259867
6495. in 1947 affidavits	were filed with the commission by various clear-channel stations	alleging that extensive interference was being caused to the service	areas of these stations during daylight hours from class 2 stations	whose signals were being reflected from the ionosphere so as to	create skywave intereference	4749.817169790518

6580. the one- or two-season hunt of which there have been too many recently	may do more harm than good; for such programs raise hopes of assistance	toward achieving excellence in scholarship and the arts which	are dashed when the programs are discontinued; and they are dashed	no less by lack of skill in making selections of men and women for development	toward the highest reaches of the mind and spirit	0.30166232349522504
6581. for	the making of selections on the basis of excellence requires that any	foundation making the selections shall have available the judgments	of a corps of advisors whose judgments are known to be good: such judgments	can be known to be good only by the records of those selected	by records made subsequent to their selection over considerable periods	of time	5562.009583516479
6582. the central group of the foundation's advisors	are at any one period of time the members of our advisory board	consisting now of thirty-six men and women	4278.169925383129
6583. they are chosen by the	foundation's board of trustees on the bases of their own first-rate	accomplishments in their different fields of scholarship and the arts	2738.234972729106
6584. their locations in all parts of the united states and their locations	in the several kinds of educational and research institutions	that are the principal homes of our intellectual and artistic strengths	also are factors in the trustees' minds	6203.929071240111
6585. for this concept of an	advisory board ancillary to the board of trustees we are indebted	to the late president of harvard university a lawrence lowell	a master of the subject of the structure of cultural institutions	and their administration	4235.750429657606
6586. that we had the wit and wisdom to adopt mr	lowell's concept and make it the base for our processes of selection	is one reason why our selections have been it may be said truly	pretty uniformly good	6042.617691057037
6587. for in accordance with mr lowell's	concept of an advisory board our selections are made by experienced	selectors who give both constancy and consistency to our processes	and our choices	3225.9479261766537
6588. and lest we should become too consistent in the	sense of becoming heedless of new fields of scholarship and new points	of view in the arts the foundation's board of trustees maintains	a trickle- not a flow!- of new members through the advisory board	6801.452100600269
6589. two committees of members of the advisory board constitute	the committees of selection- one for the selection of fellows	from canada the united states and the english-speaking caribbean	area and one for the selection of fellows from the latin american	republics and the republic of the philippines	4770.260622089436

6591. we are as we know utterly dependent	on the quality of advice we get; and quality of advice added to	devotion to the foundation's purposes and ideals we do get from	our advisory board in measures so full that they can be appreciated	only by those of us who work here every day	5128.1130590211
6592. but the facts about	our advisory board and its members' duties are only one of several	sets of facts about the quest for advice both reliable and imaginative	on which to base our selections of fellows	5792.0889061418075
6593. for example the	interest of past members of the foundation's advisory board remains	such that they place their knowledge and judgments at our disposal	much as they had done when they were formally members of that board	3943.795654847991
6594. and besides there are a large number of scholars artists composers	of music novelists poets essayists choreographers lawyers servants	of government and men of affairs- hundreds indeed- who serve	the foundation well with the advice they give us freely and gratis	out of their experience	6869.405510333769

6596. it is a truism of business that no business can be better than	its board of directors and its top management	3036.8304060135515
6597. the same is true of	every foundation	93.7447085869965

6604. he is a historian	with the great merit of a historian's long view	1185.0151382214824

6606. mr smith like the present secretary	general is a lawyer; and lawyers- with the great virtues	that they are trained to read the fine print carefully and are	able out of professional experience to arrive at imaginative solutions	to difficult problems in many fields- are indispensable even in a foundation	office	7550.603387579575

6609. the effective recognition of excellence and	its nurture has to be learned and is not learned in a day nor even	in a year	2472.673264728305
6610. we are not given to lamentations neither personally	nor in these reports	963.0553228566808
6611. on the contrary if this be an apocalyptic	era as is commonly said we see it as an era of opportunity	2034.5725387796242
6612. for	granting that there are great present-day problems to be solved these	problems make great demands; and by their demanding tend to create	resources of men's minds and hearts which problems with easy answers	do not bring forth	6061.137771238326
6613. of this examples are legion: pericles speaking	his funeral oration in ancient greece's extremity after thermopylae	and making it a testament of freedom; jefferson writing the	declaration of independence amid the catastrophes of revolution;	christ preaching the sermon on the mount close to his ultimate sacrifice;	shakespeare speaking with the indescribable gusto of the	elizabethan voice- keats's words- in the days of the spanish	armada's threats; isaac newton at the age of twenty-three	industriously calculating logarithms to two and fifty places during	the great plague year in england 1665; winston churchill's	olympian optimistic and resolute sayings when britain stood alone	against the armed forces of tyranny less than twenty years ago; the	present-day explorations of outer space answering age-old questions	of science and philosophy in the face of possible wars of extinction	0.20124717349522497
6614. forsan et haec olim meminisse iuvabit as the roman poet	virgil declared with much more historical sense than most writers	of today	3283.3850136814704
6615. it gives indeed cause for rejoicing to remember what many	catastrophes of the past produced; and it is to be noted also that	confidence should grow from remembering that great men often appeared	in the past to turn local catastrophe into future good for all mankind	4666.576269346571
6616. for example out of the social evils of the english industrial	revolution came the novels of charles dickens; and his genius	moved his readers to seek solutions of those evils for all western men-	until today- in the industrialized west these social evils	substantially do not exist	7130.793752082929
6617. the solutions were not arrived at by any	theoreticians of the karl marx stripe but by men of government- lawyers	most of them- and men of business	2836.898303060038
6618. these were educated men	who as mr justice holmes was fond of saying formed their inductions	out of experience under the burden of responsibility	3645.0344100769457
6619. that is	to put it realistically they had to run their businesses at a profit	or they had to get the votes to get elected	2590.651415459584
6620. nevertheless they made	naught of marx's prophecy that capitalism would never pay the workers-	to use marx's word- more than a subsistence wage with	the consequence that increased productivity must inevitably find its	way into the capitalists' pockets with the result in turn that the	gap between the rich and the poor would irrevocably widen and the misery	of the poor increase	8423.051655463098
6621. but as all understand who have eyes	to see nothing of the kind has happened; indeed the contrary has	happened	1881.6975385785693
6622. the gulf between the rich and the poor has narrowed	in the industrialized western world to the point that the word	poor is hardly applicable	3903.4884150355647
6623. and the reason this could happen is	clear: men of government business men lawyers and all who concerned	themselves with the welfare of their fellow men did not let their	concern to run their businesses at a profit restrict the development of	freedom and opportunity	4600.26002606752
6624. some would say that they were not permitted	to run their businesses only for profit; and even putting it that	way would not prove that marx was anything but wrong	4806.516010152347
6625. sir henry	sumner maine a hundred years before communism was a force to be	reckoned with wrote his brilliant legal generalization that the	progress of society is from status to contract	3345.5910788644164
6626. the essence of contract	is that one is free to make a choice of what one will or will not	do	3063.9325158247475
6627. hence the condition of freedom is a necessary condition for choice	501.7560340629428
6628. the greater the range of freedom for individual men the greater	the range of choice; the greater the range of choice the greater	the rate of change	4260.543216572841
6629. for change is dependent on the possibilities that	individual men glimpse for the future	944.1216320650635
6630. but when there is not freedom	and opportunity to choose men- individual men- must remain in status	and society does not cannot progress	3481.238004083227
6631. the eternal truth	is that progress- due as it always is to individual creative genius-	is just as dependent on freedom as human life is dependent on the	beating of the heart	3458.758019287022
6632. and lest anybody think that considerations	such as these are not germane in a foundation report let me enlighten	them with the truths that under communism there would have been	no capital with which to endow the foundation and that there would	not be that individual freedom within which the fellows might proceed	untrammeled in every way toward their discoveries their creative	efforts for the good of mankind	8794.759583088497
6633. during the year 1959	we granted 354 fellowships; in 1960 we granted 334	787.5380624207938
6634. as heretofore	our fellowships are available to assist research in all fields of	knowledge and creative effort in all the arts	3028.4996955384217
6635. we do not favor one field	over another: we think that all inquiry all scholarly and artistic	creation is good- provided only that it contributes to a sense	and understanding of the true ends of life as all first-rate scholarship	and artistic creation does	4539.5779065129955
6636. indeed if pressed we would say what	the late robert henri american painter said to a pupil anything	will do for a subject: it's what you do with it that counts	5016.477288940421
6637. thus we have no part and want none in current discussions	of the relative importance of science the social studies the humanities	the creative arts	2581.7078024544403
6638. we want no part in such discussions because	we think them largely futile; and we think them largely futile because	for true excellence of accomplishment every scholar and every	artist must cross boundaries of knowledge and boundaries of points of	view	6447.429377954731
6639. when the brown + sharpe manufacturing company reached its	125th year as a going industrial concern during 1958 it became an almost	unique institution in the mechanical world	2023.6149174271873
6640. with its history	standing astride all but the very beginnings of the industrial revolution	brown + sharpe has become over the years a singular monument	to the mechanical foresight of its founder joseph r brown and	a world-renowned synonym for precision and progress in metalworking technology	5555.75564479979
6641. joseph r brown grew up in the bustle and enterprise	of new england between 1810 and 1830	1404.8128254208286
6642. he was early exposed to	the mechanical world and in his youth often helped his father david	brown master clock and watchmaker as he plied his trade	4277.163055194337
6643. at the	age of 17 he became an apprentice machinist at the shop of walcott +	harris in valley falls rhode island and following two or three	other jobs in quick succession after graduation he went into business	for himself in 1831 making lathes and small tools	3791.668826783088
6644. this enterprise	led to a father-and-son combination beginning in 1833 under the name	d brown + son a business which eventually grew into the modern	corporation we now call brown + sharpe	2647.9648213816477
6645. the years of joseph's	partnership with his father were numbered	370.6105101214128
6646. in 1838 a devastating	fire gutted their small shop and soon thereafter david brown moved	west to illinois settling on a land grant in his declining years	4285.780280286747
6647. joseph brown continued in business by himself quickly rebuilding	the establishment which had been lost in the fire and beginning those	first steps which were to establish him as a pioneer in raising the	standards of accuracy of machine shop practice throughout the world	4544.996188790872
6648. much of his genius of course sprang from his familiarity with	clock movements	1183.2198386231705
6649. during these early years the repair of watches and	clocks and the building of special clocks for church steeples formed	an important part of the young man's occupation	2990.5117189138755
6650. he became particularly	interested in graduating and precision measurement during the 1840's	and his thinking along these lines developed considerably during	this period	3479.9807555854013
6651. but his business also grew and we are told that mr	brown found it	increasingly difficult to devote as much time to his	creative thinking as his inclinations led him to desire	3433.8827967172974
6652. it must have	been with some pleasure and relief that on september 12 1848 joseph	brown made the momentous entry in his job book in his characteristically	cryptic style lucian sharpe came to work for me this day	as an apprentice	6447.750542993485
6653. the young apprentice apparently did well	by mr brown for in the third year of his apprenticeship lucian	was offered a full partnership in the firm; the company became j	r brown + sharpe and entered into a new and important	period of its development	3618.9017585572337
6654. mr sharpe's arrival in the business	did indeed provide what mr brown had most coveted- time for tinkering	and the opportunity of carrying out in the back room those	developments in precision graduation which most interested him at that	time	6312.769993400174
6655. by 1853 the new partnership announced the precision	vernier caliper as the first fruit of their joint efforts	1573.8893208994548
6656. the basic	significance of this invention helped them to follow it rapidly in 1855	by the development of a unique precision gear cutting and dividing	engine	4043.566158560746
6657. that development in turn formed the foundation of still more	significant expansions in later years- in gear cutting in circular	graduating in index drilling and in many other fields where accuracy	was a paramount requirement	3744.5600584178255
6658. throughout their careers both	mr brown and mr sharpe were interested in the problem of setting	up standards of measurement for the mechanical trades	3686.9280311373977
6659. several	efforts were made in this direction and though not all of them survive	to this day the brown + sharpe wire gage system was eventually adopted	as the american standard and is still in common use today	3022.993406214736
6660. as one development followed another the company's reputation for	precision in the graduating field brought it broader and broader opportunities	for expansion in precision manufacture	3871.438423720443
6661. in 1858 the partnership	began manufacturing the willcox + gibbs sewing machine	261.66916869023663
6662. as the story goes mr gibbs who originally came from the back	counties of the commonwealth of virginia saw an illustration in a	magazine of the famous howe sewing machine	4843.089986400924
6663. curious as to what made	it work he built a crude model of it in wood and filed a piece of steel	until he succeeded in making a metal pickup for the thread enabling	the crude machine to take stitches	4208.983211728131
6664. when he showed this model as his	solution as to how the howe sewing machine operated he was	told he was wrong and discovered to his amazement that the howe	machine which was unknown to him in detail used two threads while	the one that he had perfected used only one	7545.15819107712
6665. thus was invented the	single thread sewing machine which mr gibbs in partnership with	mr willcox decided to bring to brown + sharpe with the proposal	that the small company undertake its manufacture	2561.3439051837086
6666. the new work	was a boon to the partnership not only for its own value but particularly	for the stimulation it provided to the imagination of j r	brown toward yet further developments for production equipment	5779.442411323599
6667. the turret screw machine now known as the brown + sharpe hand	screw machine takes its ancestry directly from mr brown's efforts	to introduce equipment to simplify the manufacture of the sewing	machine	2579.010253241113
6668. mr brown made important additions to the arts in screw machine	design by drastically improving the means for revolving the turret	by introducing automatic feeding devices for the stock and reversible	tap and die holders	5627.471666955677
6669. in 1861 mr brown's attention	was called to yet another basic production problem- the manufacture	of twist drills	1570.8931751259631
6670. at that time during the civil war union muskets	were being manufactured in providence and the drills to drill them	were being hand-filed with rattail files	4080.394313863042
6671. this process neither satisfied	the urgent production schedules nor mr brown's imagination	of the possibilities in the situation	1581.1158842509126
6672. the child of this problem was	mr brown's famous serial no 1 universal milling machine	the archtype from which is descended today's universal knee-type	milling machine used throughout the world	4874.467833261004
6673. the original machine bearing	its famous serial number is still on exhibition at the brown + sharpe	precision center in providence	1209.394936939816
6674. during the civil war	period mr brown also invented the brown + sharpe formed tooth	gear cutter a basic invention which ultimately revolutionized the world's	gear manufacturing industry by changing its basic economics	3828.5884882964224
6675. up until that time it had been possible to make cutters for making gear	teeth but they were good for only one sharpening	2313.986202472646
6676. as soon as the	time came for re-sharpening the precise form of the gear tooth was lost	and a new cutter had to be made	3896.745783306074
6677. this process made the economical	manufacture of gears questionable until some way could be found to permit	the repeated re-sharpening of gear tooth cutters without the loss	of the precision form	3329.3591037804777
6678. mr brown's invention achieved this and	as a byproduct formed the cornerstone of brown + sharpe's position	of leadership in the gear making equipment field which lasted until	the 1920's when superceded by other methods	4133.226076522381
6679. the micrometer	caliper as a common workshop tool also owes much to j r brown	1102.5305297519956
6680. although mr brown was not himself its inventor	it is typical that his intuition first conceived the importance	of mass producing this basic tool for general use	4253.909550780762
6681. so it was	that when mr brown and mr sharpe first saw the french tool	on exhibition in paris in 1868 they brought a sample with them to the	united states and started brown + sharpe in yet another field where	it retains its leadership to this day	3841.9544619035087
6682. the final achievement	of mr brown's long and interesting mechanical career runs a	close second in importance to his development of the universal milling	machine	3894.0623193799997
6683. that achievement was his creation of the universal grinding	machine which made its appearance in 1876 at the philadelphia centennial	exposition	2025.0753098375178
6684. this machine like its milling counterpart was	the antecedent of a machine-family used to this very day in precision	metalworking shops throughout the world	3701.597943289803
6685. along with j r brown's	other major developments the universal grinding machine was profoundly	influential in setting the course of brown + sharpe for many	years to come	2033.353799546709
6686. following mr brown's death there came	forward in the brown + sharpe organization many other men who contributed	greatly to the development of the company	2522.53177450273
6687. one such man was samuel	darling	43.60755666566038
6688. as head of the firm darling + swartz mr	darling began by challenging brown + sharpe to its keenest competition	during the 1850's and early 60's	1792.8075597424152
6689. in 1868 however a truce	was called between the companies and the partnership of darling brown	+ sharpe was formed	1096.0881987996947
6690. between that year and the buying out of mr	darling's interest in 1892 a large portion of the company's precision	tool business was carried out under the name of darling brown	+ sharpe and to this day many old precision tools are in use still	bearing that famous trademark	5866.373138129829
6691. perhaps the outstanding standard	bearer of mr brown's tradition for accuracy was mr oscar	j beale whose mechanical genius closely paralleled that of	mr brown and whose particular forte was the development of the exceedingly	accurate measuring machinery that enabled brown + sharpe	to manufacture gages and therefore its products with an accuracy exceeding	anything then available elsewhere in the world	4666.771263445113
6692. also important	on the brown + sharpe scene at the turn of the century was	mr richmond viall works superintendent of the company from	1876 to 1910	2878.5384587981553
6693. mr viall possessed remarkable talents for the leadership	and development of men	641.0725029546109
6694. he was an ardent champion of the brown	+ sharpe apprentice program and personal counselor to countless able	men who first developed their industrial talents with the company	3039.603633762806
6695. in one sense it can be said that one of the most important brown + sharpe	products over the years has been the men who began work with the	company and subsequently came to places of industrial eminence throughout	the nation and even abroad	3559.6989739610717
6696. commencing with the death of	lucian sharpe in 1899 the name of henry d sharpe was for more	than 50 years closely interwoven with the destiny of the company	4654.592398932923
6697. during	his presidency the company's physical plant was enormously expanded	and the length and breadth of the brown + sharpe machine tool	line became the greatest in the world	2149.7837248361348
6698. during the early part of this	century the brown + sharpe works in providence were unchallenged	as the largest single manufacturing facility devoted exclusively to	precision machinery and tool manufacture anywhere in the world	3987.143108218444
6699. during these years the company's product line followed the basic tenets	laid down by mr brown	1260.5041355292444
6700. it expanded from hand screw machines	to automatic screw machines from simple formed-tooth gear cutting machines	to gear hobbing machines and a large contract gear manufacturing	business from rudimentary belt-driven universal milling machines to	a broad line of elaborately controlled knee-type and manufacturing type	milling machines	7003.276073276798
6701. in the grinding machine field expansion went far	from universal grinders alone and took in cylindrical grinders surface	grinders and a wide variety of special and semi-special models	2992.105339386496
6702. in 1951 henry d sharpe jr succeeded his father and	continued	the company's development as a major factor in the metal-working	equipment business	3476.3069484230014
6703. the company is still broadening its line and	is now active on four major fronts	1099.0640248628029
6704. the machine tool division	is currently producing brown + sharpe single spindle automatic screw	machines grinding machines of many types and knee and bed-type	milling machines	2705.195872852023
6705. recently added is the brown + sharpe turret drilling	machine which introduces the company to an entirely new field of tool	development	1333.288230666221
6706. in the industrial products division the company	manufactures and markets a wide line of precision gaging and inspection	equipment machinists' tools- including micrometers vernier	calipers and accessories	4265.481374164817

7069. no attempts to measure the radio emission of the remaining	planets have been reported and because of their distances small	diameters or low temperatures the thermal radiation at radio wave lengths	reaching the earth from these sources is expected to be of very	low intensity	4643.30661717656
7070. in spite of this the very large radio reflectors and	improved amplifying techniques which are now becoming available should	make it possible to observe the radio emission of most of the planets	in a few years	5777.27767432362
7071. the study of the radio emission of the moon	and planets began with the detection of the thermal radiation of the moon	at 1	2469.4176221988823
7072. 25-cm wave length by dicke and beringer	140.76923283194688
7073. this was	followed by a comprehensive series of observations of the 1	642.2460568400106
7074. 25-cm	emission of the moon over three lunar cycles by piddington and minnett		657.4251196436041
7075. they deduced from their measurements that the radio emission	from the whole disk of the moon varied during a lunation in a roughly	sinusoidal fashion; that the amplitude of the variation was considerably	less than the amplitude of the variation in the infrared emission	as measured by pettit and nicholson;	and that the maximum of the radio emission came about 3-12 days after	full	moon which is again in contrast to the infrared emission which reaches	its maximum at full moon	0.20124717349522497
7076. piddington and minnett explained	their observations by pointing out that rocklike materials which are likely	to make up the surface of the moon would be partially transparent	to radio waves although opaque to infrared radiation	5633.300431920121
7077. the infrared	emission could then be assumed to originate at the surface of the moon	while the radio emission originates at some depth beneath the surface	where the temperature variation due to solar radiation is reduced	in amplitude and shifted in phase	4393.596510316843
7078. since the absorption of radio waves	in rocklike material varies with wave length it should be possible	to sample the temperature variation at different depths beneath the surface	and possibly detect changes in the structure or composition of the	lunar surface material	6565.573457361401
7079. the radio emission of a planet was	first detected in 1955 when burke and franklin identified the	origin of interference-like radio noise on their records at about 15	meters wave length as emission from jupiter	3771.724436302308
7080. this sporadic type of	planetary radiation is discussed by burke and gallet		515.8005285725089
7081. steady radiation which was presumably of thermal origin was	observed from venus at 3	949.1433964858588
7082. 4 cm and from mars and jupiter	at 3	395.07502419092145
7083. 15 cm in 1956	and from saturn at 3	262.47676656144444
7084. 75 cm in 1957		2.595470947486615
7085. in the relatively short time since these early observations	venus has been observed at additional wave lengths in the range from	0	2184.7100493909793
7086. 2 cm and jupiter has been observed over the wave-length	range from 3	1189.2861878107
7087. the observable characteristics of	planetary radio radiation are the intensity the polarization and the	direction of arrival of the waves	1892.3171123965562
7088. the maximum angular diameter of	any planetary disk as observed from the earth is about 1 minute of arc	2596.0201988910567
7089. this is much smaller than the highest resolution of even the very	large reflectors now under construction and consequently the radio emission	of different regions of the disk cannot be resolved	3335.884428448803
7090. it should	be possible however to put useful limits on the diameters of the radio	sources by observing with large reflectors or with interferometers	3685.39427452175
7091. measurements of polarization are presently limited by apparatus sensitivity	and will remain difficult because of the low intensity of the	planetary radiation at the earth	2603.975240095858
7092. there have been few measurements specifically	for the determination of the polarization of planetary radiation	1646.6632298998193
7093. the measurements made with the nrl 50-foot reflector	which is altitude-azimuth-mounted would have shown a systematic change	with local hour angle in the measured intensities of venus and jupiter	if a substantial part of the radiation had been linearly polarized	4225.397776561453
7094. recent interferometer measurements	have shown the 960-mc emission of jupiter to be partially	polarized	and to originate in a region of larger diameter than the visible	disk	4282.765021424484
7095. other than this very significant result most of the information	now available about the radio emission of the planets is restricted	to the intensity of the radiation	2864.0254850437227
7096. the concept of apparent	black-body temperature is used to describe the radiation received from	the moon and the planets	2601.3633888852964
7097. the received radiation is compared with the	radiation from a hypothetical black body which subtends the same solid	angle as the visible disk of the planet	2752.281645225985
7098. the apparent black-body	disk temperature is the temperature which must be assumed for the	black body in order that the intensity of its radiation should equal that	of the observed radiation	4985.681288422117
7099. the use of this concept does not specify	the origin of the radiation and only if the planet really radiates	as a black body will the apparent black-body temperature correspond	to the physical temperature of the emitting material	4054.642210224972
7100. the radio	radiation of the sun which is reflected from the moon and planets should	be negligible compared with their thermal emission at centimeter	wave lengths except possibly at times of exceptional outbursts of solar	radio noise	5915.593415889186
7101. the quiescent level of centimeter wave-length solar radiation	would increase the average disk brightness temperature by less	than 1` k	1863.5813642036824
7102. at meter wave lengths and increase of the order of	10` k in the average disk temperatures of the nearer planets would	be expected	3672.039087769437
7103. therefore neglecting the extreme outbursts reflected	solar radiation is not expected to cause sizable errors in the measurements	of planetary radiation in the centimeter- and decimeter-wave-length	range	2859.5364161421558

7137. experiments were made on an electric arc applying a porous	graphite anode cooled by a transpiring gas	1426.7048859190454

7143. the high heat	fluxes existing at the electrode surfaces of electric arcs necessitate	extensive cooling to prevent electrode ablation	1740.345884892773
7144. the cooling requirements	are particularly severe at the anode	390.8337574797166
7145. in free burning electric	arcs for instance approximately 90% of the total arc power is transferred	to the anode giving rise to local heat fluxes in excess of	f as measured by the authors- the exact value depending on the arc	atmosphere	4380.427631244412
7146. in plasma generators as currently commercially available	for industrial use or as high temperature research tools often more than	50% of the total energy input is being transferred to the co0ling	medium of the anode	5641.287504640429
7147. the higher heat transfer rates at the anode	compared with those at the cathode can be explained by the physical	phenomena occurring in free burning arcs	2735.649388750542
7148. in plasma generators the	superimposed forced convection may modify the picture somewhat	955.9097273909483
7149. the heat	transfer to the anode is due to the following effects: 1	789.208926407154
7150. heat	of condensation plus kinetic energy of the electrons impinging	on the anode	1184.3017221247735
7151. this energy transfer depends on the current the	temperature in the arc column the anode material and the conditions	in the anode sheath	2325.2542348485895
7152. heat transfer by molecular conduction as well	as by radiation from the arc column	1415.3518539834456
7153. the heat transfer to	the anode in free burning arcs is enhanced by a hot gas jet flowing from	the cathode towards the anode with velocities up f	2995.2911494326263
7154. this phenomenon	has been experimentally investigated in detail by maecker		281.49753203893135
7155. the pressure gradient producing the jet is due to the nature of the	magnetic field in the arc		983.3897582145922
7156. hence the flow conditions at the anode of free	burning arcs resemble those near a stagnation point	2115.953278683275
7157. it is apparent	from the above and from experimental evidence that the cooling requirements	for the anode of free burning arcs are large compared with	those for the cathode	3096.605696627503
7158. the gas flow through a plasma generator will modify	these conditions; however the anode is still the part receiving	the largest heat flux	3484.2955283820156
7159. an attempt to improve the life of the anodes	or the efficiency of the plasma generators must therefore aim at	a reduction of the anode loss	2732.13068628936

7467. chemistry of washing	although there is no question	but that the process of washing fabrics involves a number of phenomena	which are related together in an extremely complicated way and that	these phenomena and their interrelations are not well understood at the	present this section attempts to present briefly an up-to-date picture	of the physical chemistry of washing either fabrics or hard surfaces	5662.155242132626
7468. the purpose of washing is obviously to remove soils which are arbitrarily	classed in the four major categories given below:	dirt which is here defined as particulate material which is usually	inorganic and is very often extremely finely divided so as to exhibit	colloidal properties	6943.094391423251
7469. greasy soils which are typified by	hydrocarbons and fats	261.30536441522725
7470. stains which include the wide variety of nonparticulate	materials which give color even when present in very low concentration	on the soiled object	3492.831125506981
7471. miscellaneous soils which primarily	include sticky substances and colorless liquids which evaporate to leave	a residue	1259.1833142403525
7472. the dirt on the soiled objects is mechanically	held by surface irregularities to some extent	1655.2364031355064
7473. however a major factor	in binding dirt is the attraction between surfaces that goes under	the name of van der waal's forces	2180.6370834955123
7474. this is a theoretically complicated	dipole interaction which causes any extremely small uncharged particle	to agglomerate with other small uncharged particles or to stick	to an uncharged surface	4478.17197692954
7475. obviously if colloidal particles bear charges	of opposite sign or if one kind is charged and the other kind is	not the attraction will be intensified and the tendency to agglomerate	will be greatly reinforced	3762.819805423887
7476. likewise a charged particle will tend	to stick to an uncharged surface and vice versa and a charged particle	will be very strongly attracted to a surface exhibiting an opposite	charge	5008.830667992699
7477. in addition dirt particles can be held onto a soiled surface	by sticky substances or by the surface tension of liquids including	liquid greases	2466.8714662228936
7478. greases stains and miscellaneous soils	are usually sorbed onto the soiled surface	963.988258399195
7479. in most cases these soils	are taken up as liquids through capillary action	790.2142391725174
7480. in an essentially	static system an oil cannot be replaced by water on a surface unless	the interfacial tensions of the water phase are reduced by a surface-active	agent	4654.515501417917
7481. the washing process whereby soils are removed consists	basically of applying mechanical action to loosen the dirt particles	and dried matter in the presence of water which helps to float off	the debris and acts to some extent as a dissolving and solvating	agent	4555.708633726479
7482. greasy soils are hardly removed by washing in plain water;	and	natural waters in addition often contain impurities such as calcium	salts which can react with soils to make them more difficult to remove	5460.317640943229
7483. the detergent active is that substance	which primarily acts to remove greasy soils	786.5331864093164
7484. the other constituents	in a built detergent assist in this and in the removal of dirty stains	and the hydrophilic sticky or dried soils	3704.0437243377246
7485. as is well known	detergent actives belong to the chemical class consisting of moderately	high molecular weight and highly polar molecules which exhibit the	property of forming micelles in solution	3225.4213853581064
7486. physicochemical investigations	of anionic surfactants including the soaps have shown that there	is little polymerization or agglomeration of the chain anions below	a certain region of concentration called the critical micelle concentration	5168.306809845267
7487. below the critical micelle concentration monomers and some	dimers are present	504.16397278586163
7488. in the critical micelle region there is	a rapid agglomeration or polymerization to give the micelles which have	a degree of polymerization averaging around 60-80	3899.8486161591927
7489. for anionics	these micelles appear to be roughly spherical assemblages in which	the hydrocarbon tails come together so that the polar groups	face outward towards the aqueous continuous phase	3099.762913144033
7490. obviously	hydrophobic	substances such as greases oils or particles having	a greasy or oily surface are more at home in the center of a micelle	than in the aqueous phase	4858.805442920145
7491. micelles can imbibe and hold a considerable	amount of oleophilic substances so that the micelle volume may be	increased as much as approximately two-fold	2464.8591691855972
7492. although the matter has	not been unequivocally demonstrated the available data show that micelles	in themselves do not contribute significantly to the detergency process	3690.620623066364
7493. related to micelle formation is the technologically important	ability of detergent actives to congregate at oil-water interfaces	in such a manner that the polar end of the molecule is directed	towards the aqueous phase and the hydrocarbon chain towards the	oily phase	4379.871304323265
7494. in the cleaning process sorbed greasy soils become coated	in this manner with an oriented film of surfactant	2354.810398105633
7495. then during washing	the greasy soil rolls back at the edges so that emulsified droplets	can disengage themselves from the sorbed oil mass with the aid of	mechanical action and enter the aqueous phase	3662.363541955805
7496. obviously a substance	which is permanently or temporarily sorbed on the surface in place of	the soil will tend to accelerate this process and effectively push off	the greasy soil	4846.4097474331875
7497. substances other than detergent actives also	tend to be strongly sorbed from aqueous media onto surfaces of other	contiguous condensed phases	2020.0747831763572
7498. this is particularly true of highly charged	ions especially those ions which fall into the class of polyelectrolytes	2354.263625536583
7499. whereas the usual organic surface-active agent is strongly	sorbed at oil-water interfaces the highly charged ions are most strongly	sorbed at interfaces between water and insoluble materials exhibiting	an ionic structure	3333.0705778310535
7500. thus for aqueous	media we can think of the idealized organic active as an oleophilic	or hydrophobic surface-active agent and of an idealized builder as	a oleophobic or hydrophilic surface-active agent	5015.80346333248
7501. from the equilibrium	sorption data which are available it seems logical to expect	that polyphosphate ions would be strongly sorbed on the surface of	the dirt so as to give it a greatly increased	negative charge	3852.8744301002384
7502. the charged particles then repel each other and are	also repelled from the charged surface which almost invariably bears	a negative charge under washing conditions	3918.7351210589754
7503. the negatively charged dirt	particles then leave the surface and go into the aqueous phase	1103.8906339137516
7504. this	hypothesis is evolved in analogy to the demonstrated action of organic	actives in detergency	1641.0252338000541
7505. it does not consider the kinetic effects	of the phosphate builders on sorption-desorption phenomena which will	be discussed later	1727.4139652125807
7506. the crude picture of	the detergency process thus far developed can be represented as: f	the influence of mechanical action on the particles of free soil may	be compared to that of kinetic energy on a molecular scale	6059.879581115293
7507. freed soil	must be dispersed and protected against flocculation	260.7188162489763
7508. cleaned cloth	must be protected against the redeposition of dispersed soil	749.2757073657937
7509. it is	evident that the requirements imposed by these effects upon any one	detergent constituent acting alone are severe	1727.559335015262
7510. upon consideration	of the variety of soils and fabrics normally encountered in the washing	process it is little wonder that the use of a number of detergent	constituents having synergistic properties has gained widespread	acceptance	5637.377919854631
7511. in the over-all process it is difficult to assign a	pure role to each constituent of a built-detergent formulation;	and indeed there is no more reason to separate the interrelated roles	of the active builder antiredeposition agent etc than there	is to assign individual actions to each of the numerous isomers making	up a given commercial organic active	5420.737036076343

7585. the poynting-robertson effect	which is a retardation of the orbital motion of particles	by the relativistic aberration of the repulsive force of the impinging	solar radiation causes the dust to spiral into the sun in times much	shorter than the age of the earth	4545.4756430704
7586. the radial velocity varies inversely	as the particle size- a 1000-|m-diameter particle near the	orbit of mars would reach the sun in about 60 million years	4127.376604554172
7587. whipple	extends the effects to include the solar-corpuscular-radiation	pressure which increases both the minimum particle size and the drag	1742.7507385420272
7588. further the corpuscular radiation ie the solar-wind protons	must sputter away the surface atoms of the dust and cause a slow	diminution in size with a resultant increase in both the poynting-robertson	effect and the ratio of the repulsive force to the gravitational	force	6823.6016354209305
7589. the poynting-robertson effect causes the semi-major	axis of orbits to diminish more rapidly than the semi-minor axis	with a consequent tendency toward circular orbits as the particles move	toward the sun	3347.349130098949
7590. also planetary gravitational attraction increases	the dust concentration near the plane of the ecliptic as the sun is	approached	2608.3376854092085
7591. at one astronomical unit from the sun	the dust orbits are probably nearly circular	951.1834466917624
7592. if such is the case	the particles within a distance of about f km of the earth	will	have relative to the earth a kinetic energy less than their potential	energy and they will be captured into orbits about the earth	6468.3889537605155
7593. de	jager has calculated the times required for these particles	to reach the atmosphere under the influence of the poynting-robertson	effect which in this case causes the orbits to become more and more	eccentric	without changing the semi-major axis	4138.216367553236
7594. this effect can give rise to	a blanket of micrometeorites around the earth	1183.70483481948
7595. since there is	a continual loss of micrometeoritic material in space because of the	radiation effects there must be a continual replenishment: otherwise	micrometeorites would have disappeared from interplanetary space	3230.2555468742735
7596. there	are several possible sources	22.18108435199721

7659. note that the mass	scale is one to two orders of magnitude greater than some previously	used; for example jacchia derived a scale of 0	2608.3319002199073
7660. 15 g for	a f zero-magnitude meteorite	140.060184349061
7661. the older scales were based on theoretical	estimates of the conversion efficiency of kinetic energy into	light	1417.8483305268942
7662. the mass scale used in table 5-1 was derived on the assumption	that the motion of the glowing trail is related to the momentum	transfer to the trail by the meteorite permitting the calculation of	the mass if the velocity is known	6573.880524645829
7663. a concentration distribution has been derived from radar observations	sensitive to the fifteenth magnitude	949.6833150027417
7664. extrapolation of this relationship through the thirtieth magnitude covers	the range of micrometeorites	1178.5992095187669

7671. the solar-electromagnetic- and	corpuscular-radiation	pressure and the associated poynting-robertson effect	increase in effectiveness as the particle size decreases and modify	the distribution and limit sizes to larger than a few microns	3337.4988862844484
7672. also	it has been suggested that the source of all or part of the dust may	not be the same as that for visual or radar meteorites	and the same distribution would not be expected	5619.9671633460775
7673. of micrometeorite flux	a measure of the total mass accretion	of meteoritic material by the earth is obtained from analyses of	deep-sea sediments and dust collected in remote regions		2252.346481942553

7678. biological warfare is the intentional use of	living microorganisms or their toxic products for the purpose of destroying	or reducing the military effectiveness of man	3895.367981652535
7679. it is the exploitation	of the inherent potential of infectious disease agents by scientific	research and development resulting in the production of bw	weapons systems	2585.9701916053446
7680. man may also be injured secondarily by damage to	his food crops or domestic animals	1647.288074522823
7681. biological warfare is considered	to be primarily a strategic weapon	375.97391772688405
7682. the major reason for this	is that it has no quick-kill effect	959.3510522426297
7683. the incubation period of infectious	disease plus a variable period of illness even before a lethal effect	render this weapon unsuitable for hand-to-hand encounter	2468.452418010643
7684. a man	can be an effective fighting machine throughout the incubation period	of most infectious diseases	1892.9400360858563
7685. thus an enemy would probably use this weapon	for attack on static population centers such as large cities	1569.9504813338224
7686. an important operational procedure in bw for an enemy would	be to create an areosol or cloud of agent over the target area	3492.4719828139714
7687. this	concept has stimulated much basic research concerning the behavior of	particulate biological materials the pathogenesis of respiratory infections	the medical management of such diseases and defense against their	occurrence	3227.915538271959
7688. the biological and physical properties of infectious	particles have been studied intensively during the past fifteen	years	2135.9030842736634
7689. much new equipment and many unique techniques have been developed	for the quantitative exposure of experimental animals to aerosols	of infectious agents contained in particles of specified dimensional	characteristics	3104.146706578963
7690. much information has been gathered relative to quantitative	sampling and assesment techniques	956.9488444889299
7691. much of the older experimental	work on respiratory infections was accomplished by very artificial	procedures	1092.7091366455927
7692. the intranasal instillation of a fluid suspension of infectious	agent in an anesthetized animal is far different from exposure	through natural respiration to aerosolized organisms	3878.864526783456
7693. the	importance of particle size in such aerosols has been thoroughly demonstrated	642.4026367084562
7694. the natural anatomical and physiological defensive features	of the upper respiratory tract such as the turbinates of the nose and	the cilia of the trachea and larger bronchi are capable of impinging	out the larger particles to which we are ordinarily exposed in our daily	existence	7002.956567367835
7695. very small particles however in a size range of 1 to	4 microns in diameter are capable of passing these impinging barriers	and entering the alveolar bed of the lungs	3203.4124809869004
7696. this area is highly susceptible	to infection	140.7132917514552
7697. the entrance and retention of infectious particles	in the alveoli amounts almost to an intratissue inoculation	1254.0033603410925
7698. the	relationship between particle size and infectious dose is illustrated	in table 1	1184.5020715536102
7699. in considering bw defense it must be recognized	that a number of critical meterological parameters must be met for	an aerosol to exhibit optimum effect	2577.156413835853
7700. for example bright sunlight	is rapidly destructive for living microorganisms suspended in air	1182.5959802810742
7701. there	are optimal humidity requirements for various agents when airborne	370.82000218447
7702. neutral or inversion meteorological conditions are necessary for a	cloud to travel along the surface	1655.8875118660712
7703. it will rise during lapse conditions	43.26438816649161
7704. there are of course certain times during the 24-hour daily cycle	when most of these conditions will be met	2590.7670179595925
7705. certain other properties	of small particles in addition to those already mentioned in	connection with penetration of the respiratory tract are noteworthy	in defense considerations	2584.573765879445
7706. the smaller the particle the further it will	travel downwind before settling out	1183.2907947278086
7707. an aerosol of such small particles	43.425972726477355
7708. moreover diffuses through structures in much the same manner as	a gas	962.5539285099433
7709. there may be a number of secondary effects resulting from diffusion	through buildings such as widespread contamination of kitchens	restaurants food stores hospitals etc	2470.3815579752245
7710. depending on the organism	there may be multiplication in some food or beverage products ie	in milk for example	2587.796416532043
7711. the secondary consequences from this could	be very serious and must be taken into consideration in planning for	defense	1725.8648796804657
7712. something of the behavior of clouds of small particles	can be illustrated by the following field trials:   in the	first trial an inert substance was disseminated from a boat travelling	some ten miles off shore under appropriately selected meteorological	conditions	6319.234158721067
7713. zinc cadmium sulfide in particles of 2 microns in size were	disseminated	634.038230876263
7714. this material fluoresces under ultraviolet light which	facilitates its sampling and assessment	961.7993464697581
7715. four hundred and fifty pounds	was disseminated while the ship was traveling a distance of 156	miles	1410.4087042939786
7716. figure 1 describes the results obtained in this trial	393.89615904704226
7717. the particles traveled a maximum detected distance of some 450 miles	502.8781065777619
7718. from these dosage isopleths it can be seen that an area of over 34000	square miles was covered	2348.259126182072
7719. these dosages could have been increased	by increasing the source strength which was small in this case	1409.3005270228064
7720. the behavior of a biological aerosol on a much smaller scale is illustrated	by a specific field trial conducted with a non-pathogenic organism	3509.0808253521473
7721. an aqueous suspension of the spores of b subtilis var	niger generally known as bacillus globigii was aerosolized	using commercially available nozzles	2172.867845942207
7722. a satisfactory cloud was produced	even though these nozzles were only about 5 per cent efficient in	producing an initial cloud in the size range of 1 to 5 microns	4829.444954516159
7723. in this	test 130 gallons of a suspension having a count of f organisms	per ml or a total of approximately f spores was aerosolized	2595.680666493029
7724. the	spraying operation was conducted from the rear deck of a small naval	vessel cruising two miles off-shore and vertical to an on-sure breeze	3698.2176325779415
7725. spraying continued along a two-mile course	43.57926574871292
7726. this operation	was started at 5:00 pm and lasted for 29 minutes	958.4875689610797
7727. there was	a slight lapse condition a moderate fog and 100 per cent relative	humidity	1095.353539693962
7728. a network of sampling stations had been set up on shore	750.8301528939919
7729. these	were located at the homes of government employees in government	offices buildings and reservations within the trial area	1731.8562925814063
7730. a rough	attempt was made to characterize the vertical profile of the cloud by	taking samples from outside the windows on the first ninth and fifteenth	floors of a government office building	5195.465087569535
7731. all samplers were	operated for a period of two hours except one which was operated	for four hours	1572.8644117434364
7732. in this instance there was a dosage of 562 during the	first two hours and a total dosage of 1980 for the four-hour period	a four-fold increase	4286.90033190726
7733. this suggests that the sampling period particularly	at the more distant locations should have been increased	1257.3618735560112

7735. the maximum distance sampled was 23 miles from the source	376.59735617034573

7737. it is quite likely that	an even greater area was covered particularly downwind	786.8549070372233
7738. the dosages	in the three levels of the vertical profile were: f   this was	not of course enough sampling to give a satisfactory description	of the vertical diffusion of the aerosol	4994.4278611572
7739. a number of unique medical	problems might be created when man is exposed to an infectious	agent through the respiratory route rather than by the natural portal	of entry	3088.5554764360086
7740. some agents have been shown to be much more toxic or infectious	to experimental animals when exposed to aerosols of optimum particle	size than by the natural portal	4477.636120322571
7741. botulinal toxin for example is several	thousand-fold more toxic by this route than when given per os	1423.3569107327726
7742. in some instances a different clinical disease picture may result from	this route of exposure making diagnosis difficult	2360.3101448212647
7743. in tularemia produced	by aerosol exposure one would not expect to find the classical	ulcer of rabbit fever on a finger	2032.5949540921022
7744. an enemy would obviously	choose an agent that is believed to be highly infectious	1414.4190215103044
7745. agents	that are known to cause frequent infections among laboratory workers	such as those causing q fever tularemia brucellosis glanders	coccidioidomycosis etc belong in this category	2727.465072875276
7746. an agent	would	likely be selected which would possess sufficient viability and virulence	stability to meet realistic minimal logistic requirements	2840.9595696940364
7747. it	is obviously a proper goal of research to improve on this property	788.093667036317
7748. in this connection it should be capable of being disseminated without	excessive destruction	1174.361502436132
7749. moreover it should not be so fastidious in	its growth requirements as to make production on a militarily significant	scale improbable	2028.6509594201223
7750. an aggressor would use an agent against	which there was a minimal naturally acquired or artificially induced	immunity in a target population	3262.615065858699
7751. a solid immunity is the one effective	circumstance whereby attack by a specific agent can be neutralized	1423.1093619234732
7752. it must be remembered however that there are many agents for which	there is no solid immunity and a partial or low-grade immunity may be	broken by an appropriate dose of agent	5164.263256412638
7753. there is a broad spectrum	of organisms from which selection for a specified military purpose	might be made	1570.8031767905393
7754. an enemy might choose an acutely debilitating microorganism	a chronic disease producer or one causing a high rate of lethality	2828.4649860281493
7755. it is possible that certain mutational forms may be produced	such as antibiotic resistant strains	1097.8771618959865
7756. mutants may also be developed	with changes in biochemical properties that are of importance in	identification	1871.9003223018292
7757. all of these considerations are of critical importance	in considering defense and medical management	941.8774955914596
7758. biological agents	are of course highly host-specific	140.41686582248082
7759. they do not destroy physical	structures as is true of high explosives	641.5572932339649
7760. this may be of overriding	importance in considering military objectives	558.0727610694312
7761. the question	of epidemic disease merits some discussion	168.75565789626253
7762. only a limited effort has	been devoted to this problem	560.7287870939883
7763. some of those who question the value	of bw have assumed that the only potential would be in the establishment	of epidemics	2173.5627765113186
7764. they then point out that with our present lack	of knowledge of all the factors concerned in the rise and fall	of epidemics it is unlikely that a planned episode could be initiated	5319.745171442793
7765. they argue further that our knowledge	and resources in preventive medicine would make it possible to control	such an outbreak of disease	2176.089220071882
7766. this is why this approach to bw	defense has not been given major attention	1407.165646734866
7767. our major problem	is what an enemy might accomplish in an initial attack on a target	1258.7641964110223
7768. this	of course does not eliminate from consideration for this purpose	agents that are associated naturally with epidemic disease	2588.8714860048435
7769. a hypothetical	example will illustrate this point	93.76278514388034
7770. let us assume that it would	be possible for an enemy to create an aerosol of the causative agent	of epidemic typhus over city a and	that a large number of cases of typhus fever resulted therefrom	5905.021187382843
7771. no epidemic	was initiated nor was one expected because the population in city	a was not lousy	1414.4376739325194
7772. lousiness is a prerequisite for epidemic typhus	140.78107992795876
7773. in this case then the military objective was accomplished with	an epidemic agent solely through the results secured in the initial	attack	2185.4027945705816
7774. this was done with full knowledge that there would be no epidemic	957.2573300774551
7775. on the other hand a similar attack might have been made on city	b whose population was known to be lousy	2025.629319497389
7776. one might expect some	spread of the disease in this case resulting in increased effectiveness	of the attack	2350.0031544385374
7777. the major defensive problems are concerned	with the possibility of overt military delivery of biological agents from	appropriate disseminating devices	1878.4076118092296
7778. it should be no more difficult	to deliver such devices than other weapons	1181.1588934250726
7779. the same delivery vehicles-	whether they be airplanes submarines or guided missiles- should	be usable	1097.800871190167
7780. if it is possible for an enemy to put an atomic bomb on	a city it should be equally possible to put a cloud of biological agent	over that city	4838.891609770503
7781. biological agents are moreover suitable	for delivery through enemy sabotage which imposes many problems in defense	1253.9278248717662
7782. a few obvious target areas of great importance might be mentioned	745.0157849091336
7783. the air conditioning and ventilating systems of large buildings are	subject to attack	783.8303132561061
7784. america is rapidly becoming a nation that uses	processed precooked and even predigested foods	1420.6506416024345
7785. this is an enormous	industry that is subject to sabotage	374.64510924261253
7786. one must include the preparation	of soft drinks and the processing of milk and milk products	1897.080538036101
7787. huge	industries are involved also in the production of biological products	drugs and cosmetics which are liable to this type of attack	2179.8700812929824
