7870. once again both anti-a and anti-b activities	were found in the insoluble material precipitated during dialysis	1885.1087914814484
7871. similarly both types of antibodies were found in three regions of the	chromatographic eluate having extremely low low and high anionic	binding capacity respectively	2455.0760938319363
7872. chromatography of	whole sera revealed that the areas of rh antibody activity were generally	continuous and wide	2115.901419525816
7873. the incomplete antibody activity appeared	in the early part of the chromatogram; the complete in the latter	part	1569.0565228575933
7874. the serum containing the mixed type of complete and incomplete	antibodies showed activity in both regions	1883.3440060009202
7875. in all cases	the activity against f cells was spread over a wider area than that	with f cells regardless of the type of test	used for comparison	2982.0444200965258
7876. the insoluble material resulting	from dialysis against starting buffer always showed strong activity	1178.1724938599816
7877. in	fact agglutination of f cells in saline could be produced by the	insoluble material from sera containing only incomplete antibody	activity	2180.373307553318
7878. this was later known to be the result of concentrating the	minute amount of complete antibody found in these sera; when the insoluble	fraction was suspended in a volume of saline equal to that of	the original serum sample no complete antibody activity could be detected	6996.964280524812
7879. apart from the honeybee practically all bees and bumblebees	hibernate in a state of torpor	1100.436507790058
7880. occasionally you may come across one	or two bumblebees in the cold season when you are turning over sods	in your garden but you have to be a really keen observer to see them	at all	5783.583550894615
7881. they keep their wings and feet pressed tightly against their	bodies and in spite of their often colorful attire you may very well	mistake them for lumps of dirt	3091.489343270705
7882. i must add at once that these animals	are what we call queens young females that have mated in the previous	summer or autumn	3699.473379704154
7883. it is on them alone that the future of their	race depends for all their relatives	have perished with the arrival of the cold weather	2582.990027281459
7884. even some of the queens will die before the winter is over falling	prey to enemies or disease	2372.372053431176
7885. the survivors emerge on some nice sunny	day in march or april when the temperature is close to 50` f	and there is not too much wind	2867.243167403193
7886. now the thing for us to do is to find	ourselves a couple of those wonderful flowering currants such as the	red ribes sanguineum of our pacific northwest or otherwise a	good sloe tree or perhaps some nice pussy willow in bloom preferably	one with male or staminate catkins	7345.057178405131
7887. the blooms of ribes and of	the willow and sloe are the places where large numbers of our early insects	will assemble: honeybees bumblebees and other wild bees and	also various kinds of flies	3655.385691745573
7888. it is a happy buzzing crowd	65.98906824524343
7889. each	male willow catkin is composed of a large number of small flowers	783.8223607100435
7890. it is not difficult to see that the stamens of the catkin are always	arranged in pairs and that each individual flower is nothing but one	such pair standing on a green black-tipped little scale	5631.065814523151
7891. by scrutinizing	the flowers one can also notice that the scale bears one or two	tiny warts	1421.8548732576214
7892. those are the nectaries or honey glands		65.5179024106029
7893. the staminate willow catkins then provide their visitors with	both nectar and pollen; a marvelous arrangement for it provides	exactly what the bee queens need to make their beebread a combination	of honey and pollen with which the young of all species are fed	4541.997277411943
7894. the	only exception to this is certain bees that have become parasites	957.0755577428699
7895. i	will deal with these later on	93.94529221790887
7896. quite often honeybees form a	majority on the willow catkins	567.7375914453855
7897. as we have already seen in the first	chapter bumblebees are bigger hairier and much more colorful than honeybees	exhibiting various combinations of black yellow white and	orange	2984.012754409767
7898. let us not try to key them out at this stage of the game and	let us just call them bombus; there must be several dozen species	in the	united states alone	5156.997361000538
7899. if you really insist on knowing their names	an excellent book on the north american species is bumblebees and	their ways by o e plath	2604.8222357625823
7900. if we manage to keep track	of a bombus queen after she has left her feeding place we may	discover the snug little hideout which she has fixed up for herself	when she woke up from her winter sleep	6180.568113818337
7901. as befits a queen a bumblebee	female is rather choosy and may spend considerable time searching for	a suitable nesting place	2022.428758900247
7902. most species seem to prefer a ready-made	hollow such as a deserted mouse nest a bird house or the hole made	by a woodpecker; some show a definite liking for making their nest in	moss	5668.341341446373
7903. once she has made up her mind the queen starts out by constructing	in her chosen abode a small floor of dried grass or some	woolly material	2860.4572030663107
7904. on this she builds an egg compartment or egg	cell which is filled with that famous pollen-and-nectar mixture	called beebread	2818.260687865529
7905. she also builds one or two waxen cups which she fills	with honey	793.9924117649994
7906. then a group of eggs is deposited in a cavity in the	beebread loaf and the egg compartment is closed	2833.8237578721264
7907. the queen afterward	keeps incubating and guarding her eggs like a mother hen taking a sip	from time to time from the rather liquid honey in her honey pots	3115.405134250965
7908. when	the larvae hatch they feed on the beebread although they also receive	extra honey meals from their mother	2597.006297968257
7909. she continues to add to the	pollen supply as needed	376.9406525491902
7910. the larvae kept warm by the queen	are full grown in about ten days	1400.3430216813097
7911. each now makes a tough papery cocoon	and pupates	264.26897164810697
7912. after another two weeks the first young emerge four	to eight small daughters that begin to play the role of worker bees	collecting pollen and nectar in the field and caring for the new young	generation while the queen retires to a life of egg laying	7028.326444232627
7913. the first	worker bees do not mate or lay eggs; males and mating females do not	emerge until later in the season	2184.4320689989217
7914. the broods of workers that appear	later tend to be bigger than the first ones probably because they are	better fed	3028.263937094508
7915. by the middle of the summer many of the larvae apparently	receive such a good diet that it is optimal and it is then	that young queens begin to appear	3223.962371802523
7916. simultaneously males or drones are	produced mostly from the unfertilized eggs of workers although a	few may be produced by the queen	3264.98708476871
7917. the young queens and drones leave the	nest and mate and after a short period of freedom the fertilized	young	queens will begin to dig in for the winter	3108.4085904039202
7918. it is an amazing fact that	in some species this will happen while the summer is still in full	swing for instance in august	3679.030880741023
7919. the temperature then is still very	high	94.24363074100907
7920. at the old nest the queen will in the early fall cease to lay	the fertilized eggs that will produce females	3051.814398309455
7921. as a result the proportion	of males increases and eventually the old	colony will die out completely	1419.8688319295843
7922. the nest itself the structure that	in some cases housed about 2000 individuals when the season was at its	peak is now rapidly destroyed by the scavenging larvae of certain	beetles and moths	5329.836116864342
7923. not always though does the development of	a bumblebee colony take place in the smooth fashion we have just described	1881.7140519877
7924. some members of the bee family have become idlers social parasites	that live at the expense of their hardworking relatives	2804.1388179476776
7925. bumblebees	can thus suffer severely from the onslaughts of psithyrus the	cuckoo-bumblebee as it is called in some european countries	1883.3317651023735
7926. female individuals of psithyrus look deceptively like the workers	and queens of the bumblebees they victimize	1891.536671479469
7927. the one sure way to tell	victim and villain apart is to examine the hind legs which in the	case of the idler psithyrus lack the pollen baskets- naturally!	the female parasite spends much time in her efforts to find a nest	of her host	4587.007677158502
7928. when she succeeds she usually manages to slip in unobtrusively	to deposit an egg on a completed loaf of beebread before the	bumblebees seal the egg compartment	4289.354267255285
7929. the hosts never seem to recognize	that something is amiss so that the compartment afterward is sealed	normally	1573.5898843613306
7930. thus the larvae of the intruder can develop at the expense	of the rightful inhabitants and the store of beebread	2825.9973569257954
7931. later on they	and the mother psithyrus are fed by the bombus workers	793.9757768649323
7932. worse still in a number of cases it has been claimed that the psithyrus	female kills off the bombus queen	2808.9847684972488
7933. but let us return	after this gruesome interlude to our willow catkins in the spring;	there are other wild bees that command our attention	2448.693331847332
7934. it	is almost certain that some of these usually a trifle smaller than the	honeybees are andrenas or mining bees	2832.8587731940734
7935. there are about 200 different	kinds of andrena in europe alone	498.5833439283626
7936. one of my favorites is a	armata a species very common in england where it is sometimes	referred to as the lawn bee	3494.355204685877
7937. the females like to burrow in the short	turf of well-kept lawns where their little mounds of earth often appear	by the hundreds	2318.1480434720015
7938. almost equal in size to a honeybee	141.25949759175995
7939. a armata	is much more beautiful in color at least in the female of the species:	a rich velvety rusty red	2033.31539421923
7940. the males are much duller	22.02994524779699
7941. after having mated an andrena female digs a hole straight down	into the ground forming a burrow about the size of a lead pencil	2478.2457583745263
7942. the bottom part of a burrow has a number of side tunnels or cells	each of which is provided with an egg plus a store of beebread	4291.906204293655
7943. the	development of the andrena larvae is very rapid so that by the	end of spring they have already pupated and become adults	2316.4321330761672
7944. but they	are still enclosed in their larval cells and remain there throughout	the summer fall and winter	2359.0893392335774
7945. their appearance next spring coincides	in an almost uncanny way with the flowering of their host plants	1412.1932781561165
7946. in the sacramento valley in california for instance it has been observed	that there was not one day's difference between the emergence	of the andrenas and the opening of the willow catkins	5172.588087606522
7947. this must be	due to a completely identical response to the weather in the plant and	the animal	1578.7761431422318
7948. after the male and female andrenas have mated	the cycle is repeated	966.3315980887694
7949. although andrena is gregarious so that we	may find hundreds and hundreds of burrows together we must still call	it a solitary bee	2299.987227580118
7950. its life history is much simpler than that of the	truly colonial bumblebees and can serve as an example of the life	cycle of many other species	4296.548192308411
7951. after all social life in the group of	the bees is by no means general although it certainly is a striking	feature	2192.32601283321
7952. on the basis of its life history we like to think that andrena	is more primitive than the bumblebees	2587.6367970475194
7953. the way in which it transports	its pollen is not so perfect either	785.4800745306468
7954. it lacks pollen baskets	and possesses only a large number of long branched hairs on its legs	on which the pollen grains will collect	3670.3434839567444
7955. still andrena will	do a reasonably good job so that an animal with a full pollen load looks	like a gay little piece of yellow down floating in the wind	3227.9831246072927
7956. closely related to the andrenas are the nomias or alkali bees	759.0915532462209
7957. nomia	melanderi can be found in tremendous numbers in certain parts of	the united states west of the great plains for example in utah	and central washington	2858.3495936429863
7958. in the united states department of agriculture's	yearbook of agriculture 1952 which is devoted entirely	to insects george e bohart mentions a site in utah which	was estimated to contain 200000 nesting females	5298.482180535348
7959. often the burrows	are only an inch or two apart and the bee cities cover several acres	1431.9372921556178
7960. the life history of the alkali bee is similar to that of andrena	but the first activity of the adults does not take place until summer	and the individuals hibernate in the prepupal stage	5458.460208330818
7961. in most places	there are two generations a year a second brood of adults appearing	late in the summer	1721.5916698667424
7962. i must plead guilty to a special sympathy	for nomias	561.6994952086344
7963. this may just be pride in my adopted state of washington	but certainly i love to visit their mound cities near yakima and	prosser in july or august when the bees are in their most active	period	3955.5192830729525
7964. the name alkali bee indicates that one has to look for	them in rather inhospitable places	1877.3318313099342
7965. sometimes although by no means	always these are indeed alkaline	376.73541933861947
7966. the thing is that these bees love	a fine-grained soil that is moist; yet the water in the ground should	not be stagnant either	3695.9222399674495
7967. where does	one find such conditions	43.358873823049564
7968. the best chance of course is offered by	gently sloping terrain where the water remains close to the surface and	where the air is dry so that a high evaporation leaves salty deposits	which permit only sparse plant growth	6226.003790590754
7969. many other snakes at maturity are already more	than half their final length	787.096496523331
7970. laurence m klauber put length at maturity	at two thirds the ultimate length for some rattlesnakes and charles	c carpenter's data on michigan garter and ribbon snakes	show that the smallest gravid females are more than	half as long as the biggest adults	6707.17995482988
7971. felix kopstein states that when	the snake reaches its maturity it has already reached about its maximal	length but goes on to cite the reticulate python as an exception	with maximum length approximately three times that at maturity	4024.8493672379846
7972. it is hard to understand how he concluded that most snakes do not grow	appreciably after attaining maturity; he was working with species	of java so perhaps some tropical snakes are unusual in this respect	5620.3829692001145
7973. certain individual giants recorded later did fail to show a reasonable	difference after maturity but it is impossible to know whether this	is due to captive conditions	2859.2315488848626
7974. additional records of slow growth have	been omitted	249.66093632889596
7975. it is possible to make a few generalizations about	the six giants themselves	789.6430426573269
7976. there seems to be a rough correlation	between the initial and ultimate lengths starting with the smallest	and ending with the largest	3281.7132835135644
7977. data on the	former are scanty but there can be little doubt that the latter is sometimes	born at a length greater than that of any of the others thereby	lending support to the belief that the anaconda does indeed attain	the greatest length	4530.789643182698
7978. for four of the six	there is also a correlation	between size at maturity and maximum length the boa constrictor	being the smallest and the indian python the next in size at the	former stage	5645.789529814444
7979. let us speculate a little on the maximum size	of the anaconda	640.2363405029048
7980. if in a certain part of the range it starts life 1	foot longer than do any of the other giants and reaches	maturity at let us guess 18 inches longer than the others a	quadrupling of the maturity length would result in a maximum of	40 feet	7214.100769681723
7981. when it comes to rate of early growth the indian	python leads with a figure of about 3 feet 6 inches per year for the	first two years more or less	3335.1138932633867
7982. the african rock python a close second	is followed in turn by the reticulate python	1645.060572294861
7983. there are few data	on the boa constrictor those for the anaconda are unconvincing and	there is nothing at all on the amethystine python	2465.2549138232775
7984. it seems likely that	the indian python comes out ahead because records of its growth have	been made more carefully and frequently; it responds exceptionally	well to captivity and does not reach proportions that make it hard to	keep	6154.920608517212
7985. i cannot make sense out of the figures for post maturity	growth; at best the annual increase appears to be a matter of inches	rather than feet	2847.2123112917707
7986. until better records have been kept over longer	periods of time and much more is known about the maximum dimensions	it will be wise to refrain from drawing conclusions	4639.558748263516
7987. it is often	stated	that the largest snakes require five years to attain maturity but	this apparently is an overestimation	1889.7928605720888
7988. the best way to determine the	correct figure is by direct observation of pairs isolated	from birth a method that produced surprising results: maturing of	a male indian python in less than two years his mate in less than three;	data on the boa constrictor about match this	7228.357581580031
7989. another approach	is to estimate from the rate of growth and the smallest size at	maturity	1254.376653658679
7990. results from this approach amply confirm the direct observations:	about three years are required there being a possible slight	difference between males and females in the time required	4475.787874669715
7991. only the	amethystine python and the anaconda must be excluded for lack or paucity	of data	1256.7273337067595
7992. the following information on snakes varying greatly	in size shows when considered	with the foregoing that there is probably no correlation between	the length of a snake and the time required for it to mature	5622.006740388318
7993. oliver	in his summary of the habits of the snakes of the united states	could supply data on the maturing period for only three species in addition	to the rattlers which i shall consider separately	3758.522870880395
7994. these three	were much alike: lined snake one year and	nine months; red-bellied snake two years; cottonmouth	two years	2604.281483244963
7995. klauber investigated the rattlesnakes	carefully himself and also summarized what others have found	789.4794095107663
7996. he	concluded that in the southern species which are rapidly growing types	females mate at the age of two and a half and bear the first young	when they are three	5009.186249418513
7997. other herpetologists have ascertained that in	the northern united states the prairie rattlesnake may not give first	birth until it is four or even five years old and that the young may	be born every other year rather than annually	4217.168093416342
7998. carpenter's study	showed that female common garter and ribbon snakes of michigan mature	at about the age of two	2575.6388873256797
7999. oversized monsters are	never brought home either alive or preserved and field measurements	are obviously open to doubt because of the universal tendency to exaggerate	dimensions	2727.80005156184
8000. measurements of skins are of little value; every	snake hide is noticeably longer than its carcass and intentional stretching	presents no difficulty to the unscrupulous explorer	4082.478042857798
8001. in	spite of all the pitfalls there is a certain amount of agreement on	some of the giants	1573.9965846946106
8002. the anaconda proves to be the fly in the ointment	but the reason for this is not clear; the relatively wild conditions	still found in tropical south america might be responsible	4987.673574219089
8003. there are three levels on which to treat the subject	376.68418629300356
8004. the first is	the strictly scientific which demands concrete proof and therefore may	err on the conservative side by waiting for evidence in the flesh	3897.012360258529
8005. this	approach rejects virtually all field measurements	93.63340954578594
8006. the next level	attempts to weigh varied evidence and come to a balanced sensible conclusion;	field measurements by experienced explorers are not rejected	and even reports of a less scientific nature are duly evaluated	5496.484185634387
8007. the third level leans on a belief that a lot of smoke means some fire	1103.142458433303
8008. the argument against this last approach is comparable to that which	rejects stories about hoop snakes about snakes that break themselves	into many pieces and join up again or even of ghosts that chase people	out of graveyards; the mere piling up of testimony does not prove	to the scientific mind the existence of hoop snakes joint snakes	or ghosts	8270.722579665215
8009. oliver has recently used the second-level approach	with the largest snakes and has come to these conclusions: the anaconda	reaches a length of at least 37 feet the reticulate python 33	the african rock python 25 the amethystine python at least 22 the indian	python 20 and the boa constrictor 18-12	5042.539819290656
8010. bernard heuvelmans	also treats of the largest snakes but on the third level and	is chiefly concerned with the anaconda	2832.164748721774
8011. he reasons that as anacondas	30 feet long are often found some might be 38 and occasional monstrous	freaks over 50	2040.491691035215
8012. he rejects dimensions of 70 feet and more	249.72982363609125
8013. his thirteenth chapter includes many exciting accounts of huge serpents	with prodigious strength but these seem to be given to complete his	picture not to be believed	2859.3949525909006
8014. detailed information on record	lengths of the giants is given in the section that follows	1649.548305699141
8015. of the six giants	discussions of the giants one by one will include	as far as possible data on these aspects of growth: size at which	life is started and at which sexual maturity is reached; time required	to reach maturity; rate of growth both before and after this crucial	stage; and maximum length with confirmation or amplification	of oliver's figures	5568.1552342414225
8016. definite information on the growth of senile	individuals is lacking	559.3950023587415
8017. at birth this species varies	considerably in size	166.4368348544677
8018. a brood of twenty-eight born at brookfield	zoo near chicago ranged in length from 22 to 33-12 inches and averaged	29 inches	3246.59106076893
8019. lawrence e griffin gives measurements of nineteen	young anacondas presumably members of a brood from south america;	the extreme measurements of these fall between the lower limit	of the brookfield brood and its average	3670.340632871231
8020. raymond l ditmars	had	two broods that averaged 27 inches	559.8329176165546
8021. r r mole and f w	urich give approximately 20 inches as the average length of a brood	of thirty from the region of the orinoco estuaries	2856.8402204412273
8022. william beebe	reports 26 inches and 2	140.82427144777347
8023. 4 ounces	for the length and the weight of a young anaconda from british guiana	1106.8640788695234
8024. in contrast ditmars recorded the average length of seventy-two	young of a 19-foot female as 38 inches and four young were born in london	at a length of 35 or 36 inches and a weight of from 14 to 16 ounces	6423.760392225102
8025. beebe had a 3-foot anaconda that weighed only 9	259.87958772014457
8026. a difference	between subspecies might explain the great range in size	748.208905564681
8027. i have little information on the anaconda's rate of growth	372.29031446962347
8028. hans	schweizer had one that increased from 19-12 inches to 5 feet 3 inches	in five years and j j quelch records a growth of from less	than 4 feet to nearly 10 in about six years	5920.813657145116
8029. it is very unlikely that	either of these anacondas was growing at a normal rate	1100.2565998363427
8030. in 1948	afranio do amaral the noted brazilian herpetologist wrote a	technical paper on the giant snakes	2147.2791613459317
8031. he concluded that the anaconda's	maximum length is 12 or 13 meters which would approximate	from 39 to 42 feet	1889.5720629986422
8032. thus	his estimate lies between oliver's suggestion of at least 37 feet	and the 50-foot monstrous freaks intimated by heuvelmans	2810.282867111399
8033. the most convincing recent measurement of an anaconda was made in	eastern colombia by roberto lamon a petroleum geologist of the richmond	oil company and reported in 1944 by emmett r dunn	3458.959085707588
8034. however	as a field measurement it is open to question	562.6477769786477
8035. oliver's 37-12	feet is partly based on this report and can be accepted as probable	1100.979846099898
8036. however many herpetologists remain skeptical and would prefer	a tentative maximum of about 30 feet	1650.7983152945822
8037. it is possible that especially	large anacondas will prove to belong to subspecies limited to	a small area	1569.4987371761677
8038. in snakes difference in size is a common characteristic	of subspecies	746.533703787419
8039. a colombian female's brood	of sixteen boa constrictors born in the staten island zoo averaged	20 inches	1413.3186799894181
8040. this birth length seems to be typical	139.80799211950085
8041. when some thirteen	records of newly and recently born individuals are collated little	or no correlation between length and distribution can be detected	2319.3520637988195
8042. the	range is from 14 to 25 inches; the former figure is based on a somewhat	unusual birth of four by a central american female	the latter on a normal	newly born individual	5325.737332823896
8043. however as so many of the records are	not certainly based on newborn snakes these data must be taken tentatively;	final conclusions will have to await the measurements of broods	from definite localities	3559.007951143456
8044. alphonse r hoge's measurements	of several very young specimens from brazil suggest that at birth the	female is slightly larger than the male	3488.864021615426
8045. i have surprisingly little	information on the size and age at maturity	642.419377463161
8046. carl kauffeld has	written to me of sexual activity in february 1943 of young born in march	1940	2350.8919185144364
8047. one female collected on an island off the coast of nicaragua	was gravid and measured 4 feet 8 inches from snout to vent		1575.4955437442964
8048. the female from central	america which gave birth to four was only 3 feet 11 inches long	2108.98394207396
8049. what data there are on growth indicate considerable variation	in rate; unfortunately no one has kept complete records of one individual	whereas many have been made for a very short period of time	3555.827271922808
8050. the results are too varied to allow generalization	251.52124158072752
8051. the bronchus and pulmonary artery in this lung type maintain a close	relationship throughout	943.6609888156714
8052. the pulmonary vein however without the limiting	supportive tissue septa as in type 1 follows a more direct	path	to the hilum and does not maintain this close relationship		3380.3668726045953
8053. another marked difference is noted here	43.553226928488066
8054. the pulmonary artery	in addition to supplying the distal portion of the respiratory bronchiole	the alveolar duct and the alveoli continues on and directly supplies	the thin pleura	4474.56087004696
8055. the bronchial artery except for a	small number of short branches in the hilum contributes none of the	pleural blood supply	2020.8036112180557
8056. it does as in type 1 supply the hilar lymph	nodes the pulmonary artery the pulmonary vein the bronchi and the	bronchioles- terminating in a common capillary bed with the pulmonary	artery at the level of the respiratory bronchiole	6205.1899967831
8057. no bronchial artery-pulmonary	artery anastomoses were noted in this group	371.91571514891245
8058. lung	type 3 is to some degree a composite of types 1	and 2	1422.2328258936327
8059. it is characterized by the presence of incompletely developed	secondary lobules; well defined but haphazardly arranged interlobular	septa and a thick remarkably vascular pleura	2466.694929985272
8060. the	most distal airways are similar to those found in type 1 being	composed of numerous apparently true terminal bronchioles and occasional	poorly developed respiratory bronchioles	4090.297651744775
8061. in this	instance because of incomplete septation the secondary lobule does	not constitute in itself what appears to be a small individual lung	as in type 1	2857.041062573072
8062. air-drifts from one area to another are therefore	conceivable	390.2193920545693
8063. distally the bronchus is situated between a pulmonary artery	on one side and a pulmonary vein on the other as in type 1		1587.3515442759292
8064. this relationship however is not maintained centrally	141.7575971535535
8065. here the pulmonary vein as in type 2 is noted to draw away from	the bronchus and to follow a more direct independent course to the	hilum	2867.948561068552
8066. the bronchial artery in its course and distribution	differs somewhat from that found in other mammals	1874.0561816671568
8067. as seen in	types 1 and 2 it supplies the hilar lymph nodes vasa vasorum	to the pulmonary artery and vein the bronchi and the terminal bronchioles	2869.429014838176
8068. as in type 1 it provides arterial blood to the interlobular	septa and an extremely rich anastomotic pleural supply is seen		2010.0754863691811
8069. this pleural supply is derived both from hilar and interlobular	bronchial artery branches	791.7225489503469
8070. such a dual derivation was strikingly	demonstrated during the injection process where initial filling	would be noted to occur in several isolated pleural vessels at once	4085.8570839943322
8071. some	of these were obviously filling from interlobular branches of the	bronchial arteries while others were filling from direct hilar branches	following along the pleural surface	2732.0680071055417
8072. with completion of filling net-like	anastomoses were noted to be present between these separately	derived branches	1878.9986397899374
8073. an unusual increase in the number of bronchial arteries	present within the substance of the lung was noted	1559.5083139264952
8074. this was accounted	for primarily by the presence of a bronchial artery closely following	the pulmonary artery	2132.706349335257
8075. the diameter of this bronchial artery was	much too large for it to be a mere vasa vasorum	1561.5867099030681
8076. in distal regions its diameter would be one-fourth to one-fifth that	of the pulmonary artery	1643.1286917404911
8077. this vessel could be followed to the parenchyma	where it directly provided bronchial arterial blood to the alveolar	capillary bed	1876.8874147602771
8078. also three other direct pathways	of alveolar bronchial arterial supply were noted: via the pleura;	through the interlobular septa; and along the terminal bronchiole		2531.0342580186402
8079. one bronchial arteriolar-pulmonary arteriolar	anastomosis was noted at the terminal bronchiolar level	640.5804289542461
8080. it is evident that many marked and striking differences	exist between lungs when an inter-species comparison is made	2360.231948051104
8081. the	significance of these differences has not been studied nor has the existence	of corresponding physiologic differences been determined	1728.686807721667
8082. however	the dynamics of airflow from morphologic considerations alone	may conceivably be different in the monkey than in the horse	2817.1754612338673
8083. the volume	and perhaps even the characteristics of bronchial arterial blood	flow might be different in the dog than in the horse	2173.7321376375858
8084. also interlobular	air drifts may be all but nonexistent in the cow; probably occur	in the horse much as in the human being; and in contrast are present	to a relatively immense degree on a segmental basis in the dog where	lobules are absent	6806.301365258599
8085. a reason	for such wide variation in the pulmonary morphology is entirely lacking	at present	1098.0323346264813
8086. within certain wide limits anatomy dictates function	and if one is permitted to speculate potential pathology should	be included in this statement as well	3685.935912700063
8087. for example the marked susceptibility	of the monkey to respiratory infection might be related to its	delicate long alveolar ducts and short large bronchioles situated	within a parenchyma entirely lacking in protective supportive tissue	barriers such as those found in types 1 and 3	4529.257523322662
8088. one might also	wonder if monkeys are capable of developing bronchiolitis as we know	it in man or the horse	2838.7584998357756
8089. in addition it would be difficult to imagine	chronic generalized emphysema occurring in a cow considering its marked	lobular development but conversely not difficult to imagine this	occurring in the horse or the dog	3654.4633342612724
8090. anatomically the horse lung	appears to be remarkably like that of man insofar as this can be ascertained	from comparison of our findings in the horse with those of	others in the human being	5461.01858469176
8091. the only area in which	one might find major disagreement in this matter is in regard to the alveolar	distribution of the bronchial arteries	2456.812483339108
8092. as early as 1858 le	fort claimed an alveolar distribution of the bronchial arteries in human	beings	2109.6747822409625
8093. in 1951 this was reaffirmed by cudkowicz	94.09400544115236
8094. the opposition	to this point of view has its staunchest support in the work of miller		1126.625244010321
8095. apparently however miller has relied heavily on the	anatomy in dogs and cats and he has been criticized for using pathologic	human material in his normal study	2871.8662330540956
8096. although miller	noted in 1907 that a difference in the pleural blood supply existed	between animals nowhere in his published works is it found that he	did a comparative study of the intrapulmonary features of various mammalian	lungs other than in the dog and cat	6897.690994967263
8097. the meaning of this variation in distribution of the bronchial	artery as found in the horse is not clear	1728.5613368984166
8098. however this artery is known	to be a nutrient vessel with a distribution primarily to the proximal	airways and supportive tissues of the lung	3694.0904351545614
8099. the alveoli and respiratory	bronchioles are primarily diffusing tissues	261.89956571441655
8100. theoretically they	are capable of extracting their required oxygen either from the surrounding	air or from pulmonary arterial	blood	2603.1870545243023
8101. therefore an explanation of this alveolar	bronchial artery supply might be the nutritive requirement of an increased	amount of supportive tissue not primarily diffusing in nature	in the region of the alveolus	3437.984119884228
8102. if this be true the possibility exists	that an occlusive lesion of the bronchial arteries might cause widespread	degeneration of supportive tissue similar to that seen in generalized	emphysema	4641.936620659127
8103. one would not expect such an event to occur in animals	possessing lungs of types 1 or 2	1574.8407924438184
8104. the presence of normally	occurring bronchial artery-pulmonary artery anastomoses was first	noted in 1721 by ruysch and thereafter by many others	3042.9436979682123
8105. nakamura	verloop von	hayek have all claimed their normal but	relatively nonfunctional existence in the human being	1405.9497165324965
8106. miller	is the principal antagonist of this viewpoint	250.56548678188247
8107. in criticism of the latter's	views his conclusions were based upon dog lung injection studies	in which all of the vascular channels were first filled with a solution	under pressure and then were injected with various sized colored	particles designed to stop at the arteriolar level	4661.485228462457
8108. as early as 1913	ghoreyeb and karsner demonstrated with perfusion studies in dogs	that bronchial artery flow would remain constant at a certain low level	when pressure was maintained in the pulmonary artery and vein but that	increases in bronchial artery flow would occur in response to a relative	drop in pulmonary artery pressure	7781.375682609573
8109. berry brailsford and daly	in 1931 and nakamura in 1958 reaffirmed this	641.7553114944942
8110. our own studies in which	bronchial artery-pulmonary artery anastomoses were demonstrated	were accomplished by injecting the bronchial artery first with no pressure	on the pulmonary artery or vein and then by injecting the pulmonary	artery and vein afterwards	6045.952906725787
8111. it is distinctly possible therefore	that simultaneous pressures in all three vessels would have rendered	the shunts inoperable and hence uninjectable	2027.3533740593134
8112. this viewpoint is further	supported by verloop's demonstration of thickened bronchial	artery and arteriolar muscular coats which are capable of acting	as valves	3474.7608007305985
8113. in other words the anastomoses between the bronchial artery	and pulmonary artery should be considered as functional or demand	shunts	1886.5394330043316
8114. in addition little work has been done on a comparative	basis in regard to the normal existence of bronchial artery-pulmonary	artery anastomoses	3275.807613198089
8115. verloop found these shunts	in the human being but was unable to find them in rats	1244.0202317474736
8116. ellis grindlay	and edwards also were unable to find them in rats	954.9687733298381
8117. nakamura	was unable to demonstrate their existence either by anatomic	or physiologic methods in dogs	1097.6094404873847
8118. the possibility that the absence	or presence of these shunts is species-dependent is therefore inferred	1655.9242618937071
8119. certainly the mere fact of failing to demonstrate them in one	or another species does not conclusively deny their existence in that	species	2310.5174261169786
8120. it is however highly suggestive and agrees well with our own	findings in which we also failed to demonstrate normally occurring	bronchial artery-pulmonary artery shunts in certain species especially	the dog	4997.846401805558
8121. in conclusion these findings suggest the need for	a comparative physiology pathology and histology of mammalian lungs	1406.4077978649307
8122. in addition a detailed interspecies survey of the incidence of generalized	pulmonary emphysema in mammals would be interesting and pertinent	2830.6502624179348
8123. also for the present great caution should be exercised in the	choice of an experimental animal for pulmonary studies if they are to	be applied to man	2849.2208537422057
8124. this is especially so if the dog cat or monkey are	to be used in view of their marked anatomical differences from man	3483.9729859446416
8125. finally it is suggested that in many respects the horse lung may be	anatomically more comparable to that of the human than any other presently	known species	2842.3600720857185
8126. the main subgross anatomical features	of the lungs of various mammals are presented	1174.3365118322893
8127. a tabulation of these	features permits the lungs to be grouped into three distinctive subgross	types	1258.067222597182
8128. type 1 is represented by the cow sheep and pig;	type 2 by the dog cat and monkey; type 3 by the horse	3484.45392236271
8129. lobularity is extremely well developed in type 1; absent in type	2; imperfectly developed in type 3	1412.6320090071215
8130. the pleura and interlobular	septa are thick in types 1 and 3	962.285109814866
8131. the pleura is extremely	thin in type 2 and septa are absent	641.42723108158
8132. arterial supply to the pleura	in types 1 and 3 is provided by the bronchial artery and	in type 2 by the pulmonary artery	3709.111103419098
8133. in types 1 2 and 3	the bronchial artery terminates in a capillary bed shared in common	with the pulmonary artery at the level of the distal bronchiole	2984.790938037909
8134. in	type 3 the bronchial artery also provides blood directly to the	alveolar capillary bed	1644.6059307610092
8135. true terminal bronchioles comprise the most frequent	form taken by the distal airways in types 1 and 3 although	small numbers of poorly developed respiratory bronchioles are present	2983.0893514429345
8136. well developed respiratory bronchioles on the other hand appear	to be the only form taken by the distal airways in type 2	3268.592773858648
8137. in	type 1 the pulmonary vein closely follows the course of the bronchus	and the pulmonary artery from the periphery to the hilum	2345.883677584475
8138. this maybe	due to the heavy interlobular connective tissue barriers present	748.2386392271436
8139. in	type 3 this general relationship is maintained peripherally but	not centrally where the pulmonary vein follows a more independent path	to the hilum as is the case throughout the lung in type 2	3681.7480630005034
8140. some of the features of the top portions of figure 1 and figure	2 were mentioned in discussing table 1	2803.527345714746
8141. first the onset profile	spreads across approximately 12 years for boys and 10 years for girls	1264.0682218739844
8142. in contrast 20 of the 21 lines in the completion profile	are bunched and extend over a	much shorter period approximately 30 months for boys and 40 months for	girls	4847.519964054583
8143. the maturity chart for each sex demonstrates clearly that	onset is a phenomenon of infancy and early childhood whereas completion	is a phenomenon of the later portion of adolescence	3113.8669965024847
8144. second for	both sexes the 21 transverse lines in the onset profile vary more	in individual spread than those in the completion profile	3494.0013196633545
8145. although	the standard deviation values on which spread of the lines are based	are relatively larger for those centers which begin to ossify early	there are considerable differences in this value between	centers having the closely timed onsets	4024.6192005230114
8146. third the process of calcification	is seen to begin later and to continue much longer for these	boys than for the girls a fact which confirms data for other groups of	children	5167.8018993782425
8147. the onset profile and completion profile are constructed	to serve as norms for children	945.2345678595968
8148. it is convenient to classify	a child's onset ages and completion ages as advanced moderate	or delayed according to whether the child's	age equivalent dots appeared to the left of upon or	to the right of the appropriate short transverse line	6423.347401223468
8149. when a dot	appears close to the end of the transverse line the moderate	rating may be further classified according to the position of the dot	with respect to the vertical marking denoting the mean age	3856.0700989244783
8150. such classifications	may be called somewhat advanced or somewhat delayed	as the case may be reserving moderate for dots upon or close	to the mean	3859.358331361167
8151. in the lower portion of each chart the skeletal	age of boy 34 and girl 2 may be similarly classified	1883.2192390252033
8152. there the middle one of the three curves denotes mean skeletal age	for the maturity series boys and girls	2610.373493598595
8153. the upper curve denotes	the mean plus one standard deviation and the lower curve represents	the mean minus one standard deviation	2046.1625520254613
8154. thus a child's skeletal	age dots may be classified as advanced when they appear above	the middle curve moderate when they appear immediately above	or below the middle curve and delayed when they appear below	the lower curve	6032.328381197556
8155. to summarize the purpose of the skeletal maturity	chart: each contains two kinds of skeletal maturity norms which	show two quite different methods of depicting developmental level	of growth centers	3206.931453682877
8156. first the upper portion requires series of films	for every child consisting of those from hand elbow shoulder knee	and foot	3039.803693180634
8157. the lower portion necessitates only films of hand	165.5028166855535
8158. second the upper portion permits comparison of maturity levels of an	equal number of growth centers from the long short and round bones	of the five regions	4283.4279584201995
8159. the lower portion permits comparison of maturity	levels of short and round bones predominantly since only two long bones	are included in hand and wrist as a region	2982.8972900708145
8160. third the upper portion	deals with only two indicators of developmental level onset and	completion	1650.7356597704588
8161. the lower portion utilizes the full complement of intermediate	maturity indicators of each hand center as well as their onset	and completion	2173.7125885295764
8162. fourth the two indicators are for the most part	widely separated chronologically with the extensive age gap occurring	during childhood for all but one growth center	4089.496398861328
8163. the lower portion provides	a rating at any stage between infancy and adulthood	789.9964489364888
8164. onsets	completions and skeletal ages of boy 34 and girl 2	may be directly compared and classified using only those skeletal ages	which appear immediately below the onset profile and the completion	profile	5353.148109798304
8165. it may be assumed that differences in ratings due to selection	of growth centers from specific regions of the body will be small	according to existing tables of onset age and completion age for	centers throughout the body	4038.2551730796245
8166. accordingly maturity level ratings by	means of the upper portion and lower portion of the chart respectively	should be somewhat similar since skeletal age assessments are dependent	upon onsets during infancy and upon completions during adolescence	5775.562092052213
8167. it is clear that there are some differences in the ratings but	there is substantial agreement	1256.8801115167084
8168. since a skeletal age rating can	be made at any age during growth from elbow shoulder knee or foot	as well as hand it seems to be the method of choice when one wishes	to study most aspects of skeletal developmental progress during childhood	6788.3243367308605
8169. as stated earlier in the paper onsets and completions-	particularly the former- provide a different tool or indicator of expectancy	in osseous development each within a limited age period	3120.7011942604886
8170. such	an indicator or indicators are needed as means of recognizing specific	periods of delay in skeletal developmental progress	2595.8644660413893
8171. it	was stated earlier that one purpose of this study was to extend the analysis	of variability of onset and completion in each of the 21 growth	centers somewhat beyond that provided by the data in tables 1 and	2	4195.951640662968
8172. as one approach to doing this figures 3 and 4 have been constructed	from the mean ages and the individual onset and completion ages for	boy 34 and girl 2	4841.06910431787

8177. the tip of the	arrow represents extent of difference between the child's completion	age and the corresponding mean age for the growth center	2324.878173089966

8216. interestingly enough the effect of the digitalis glycosides is inhibited	by a high concentration of potassium in the incubation medium and	b	3269.249063875167
8217. organification	the precise mechanism for organification of iodine	in the thyroid is not as yet completely understood	1418.6797680626282
8218. however the formation	of organically bound iodine mainly mono-iodotyrosine can be	accomplished in cell-free systems	1641.2261341967278
8219. in the absence of additions to the	homogenate the product formed is an iodinated particulate protein	and kirkwood 1953; taurog potter and chaikoff 1955;	taurog potter tong and chaikoff 1956; serif and kirkwood		2661.1159288669314
8220. this iodoprotein does not	appear	to be the same as what is normally present in the thyroid and there	is no evidence so far that thyroglobulin can be iodinated in vitro	by cell-free systems	5463.1329942776665
8221. in addition the iodoamino acid formed in largest	quantity in the intact thyroid is di-iodotyrosine	1103.9788375728915
8222. if tyrosine	and a system generating hydrogen peroxide are added to a cell-free homogenate	of the thyroid large quantities of free mono-iodotyrosine can	be formed	3898.842257223241
8223. it is not clear whether this system	bears any resemblance to the in vivo iodinating mechanism and a system	generating peroxide has not been identified in thyroid tissue	2985.5469922711954
8224. on chemical	grounds it seems most likely that iodide is first converted to	f and then to f as the active iodinating species	3471.921718331533
8225. in the thyroid	gland it appears that proteins are iodinated	and that free tyrosine and thyronine are not iodinated	1721.122120442539
8226. iodination of	tyrosine however is not enough for the synthesis of hormone	955.4962188940592
8227. the mono-	and di-iodotyrosine must be coupled to form tri-iodothyronine and	thyroxine	643.0942077173565
8228. the mechanism of this coupling has been studied in some detail	with non-enzymatic systems in vitro and can be simulated by certain	di-iodotyrosine analogues	3706.8269797647918
8229. there	is so far no evidence to indicate conclusively that this coupling is	under enzymatic control	1252.0044154557054
8230. the chemical nature of the iodocompounds	is discussed below	391.16082337724526
8231. little is known of the synthetic mechanisms for formation of	thyroglobulin	501.966626242972
8232. its synthesis has not been demonstrated in cell-free systems	nor has its synthesis by systems with intact thyroid cells in	vitro been unequivocally proven	3694.875986230615
8233. there is some reason to think that thyroglobulin	synthesis may proceed independently of iodination for in	certain transplantable tumours of the rat thyroid containing essentially	no iodinated thyroglobulin a protein that appears to be thyroglobulin	has been observed in ultracentrifuge experiments		3394.3172080767013
8234. similar findings have been noted in a patient with	congenital absence of the organification enzymes whose thyroid tissue	could only concentrate iodide	3254.101938394252
8235. in addition depending on availability	of dietary iodine thyroglobulin may contain varying quantities of	iodine	1094.7587146033015
8236. since the circulating thyroid hormones are	the amino acids thyroxine and tri-iodothyronine	it is clear that some mechanism must exist in the thyroid gland for their	release from proteins before secretion	5005.004487169685
8237. the presence of several proteases	and peptidases has been demonstrated in the thyroid	795.7187080164625
8238. one of	the proteases has ph optimum of about 3	560.7524120443098
8239. 7 and another of about 5	43.37021533596781
8240. the finding that the concentration of one of these proteases	is increased in thyroid glands from tsh-treated animals suggests	that this protease may be active in vivo	4304.8108339605515
8241. there is no conclusive	evidence yet that either of the proteases has been prepared in highly	purified form nor is their specificity known	2313.336294984935
8242. a study of their activity	on thyroglobulin has shown that thyroxine is not preferentially released	and that the degradation proceeds stepwise with the formation	of macromolecular intermediates	4282.0737547354975
8243. besides proteolytic enzymes the thyroid possesses de-iodinating enzymes	168.34651260073446
8244. a microsomal de-iodinase with a ph optimum of around 8 and requiring	reduced triphosphopyridine nucleotide for activity has been	identified in the thyroid	3494.0642982588724
8245. this de-iodinating enzyme	is effective against mono- and di-iodotyrosine but does not de-iodinate	thyroxine or tri-iodothyronine	1257.8394955367512
8246. it is assumed that the iodine released	from the iodotyrosines remains in the iodide pool of the thyroid	where it is oxidised and re-incorporated into thyroglobulin	4115.869151073069
8247. the thyroxine	and tri-iodothyronine released by proteolysis and so escaping	de-iodination presumably diffuse into the blood stream	1412.2673009407736
8248. it has been	shown that thyroglobulin binds thyroxine but the binding does not appear	to be particularly strong	2351.165001864664
8249. it has been suggested that the plasma	thyroxine-binding proteins which have an extremely high affinity for	thyroxine compete with thyroglobulin for thyroxine		1457.997598461196
8250. antithyroid drugs are of two	general types	141.2188955442063
8251. one type has a small univalent anion of the	thiocyanate-perchlorate-fluoroboride	type	505.2794541482516
8252. this ion inhibits thyroid hormone synthesis	by interfering with iodide concentration in the thyroid	1416.4754146102773
8253. it does	not appear to affect the iodinating mechanism as such	501.5429649172803
8254. the other	group of antithyroid agents or drugs is typified by thiouracil	960.6414234243896
8255. these	drugs have no effect on the iodide concentrating mechanism but they	inhibit organification	937.5461955124541
8256. the mechanism of action of these drugs has not	been completely worked out but certain of them appear to act by reducing	the oxidised form of iodine before it can iodinate thyroglobulin		3835.7778125466916
8257. on the other hand there are a few antithyroid drugs	of this same general type such as resorcinol possessing no reducing	activity and possibly acting through formation of a complex with molecular	iodine	3546.0719206575
8258. any of the antithyroid drugs of either type if given	in large enough doses for a long period of time will cause goitre owing	to inhibition of thyroid hormone synthesis with production of hypothyroidism	5460.750584248508
8259. the anterior lobe of the pituitary then responds by an increased	output of tsh causing the thyroid to enlarge	1737.9971558970053
8260. the effect	of drugs that act on the iodide-concentrating mechanism can be counteracted	by addition of relatively large amounts of iodine to the diet	3668.2695905510686
8261. the antithyroid drugs of the thiouracil type however are not antagonised	by such means	937.6846141327654
8262. besides those of the thiouracil and resorcinol	types certain antithyroid drugs have been found in naturally occurring	foods	2359.496292561317
8263. the most conclusively identified is l-5-vinyl-2-thio-oxazolidone	which was isolated from rutabaga	507.03206460677467
8264. it is presumed	to occur in other members of the brassica family	954.1930592349439
8265. there is some	evidence that naturally occurring goitrogens may play a role in the development	of goitre particularly in tasmania and australia		1443.3894980781713
8266. there it seems that the goitrogen ingested by	dairy	animals is itself inactive but is converted in the animal to an active	goitrogen which is then secreted in the milk	4831.483052959562
8267. besides the presence of goitrogens in the diet the level of	iodine itself in the diet plays a major role in governing the activity	of the thyroid gland	2977.124653018191
8268. in the experimental animal and in man gross	deficiency in dietary iodine causes thyroid hyperplasia hypertrophy and	increased thyroid activity		1836.0659326931077
8269. in man the normal level of iodine in the diet and the level necessary	to prevent development of goitre is about 100 |mg per day	2597.8407258546313
8270. with	lower levels thyroid hypertrophy and increased thyroid blood-flow	enable the thyroid to accumulate a larger proportion of the daily intake	of iodine	3483.4125912234076
8271. further the gland is able to re-use a larger fraction	of the thyroid hormone de-iodinated peripherally	1259.8932375271424
8272. in the presence of	a low iodine intake thyroglobulin labelled in vivo with f is found	to contain more mono-iodotyrosine than normal the amounts of di-iodotyrosine	and iodothyronines being correspondingly reduced	5017.470012563058
8273. this appears	to result from both a reduced amount of the iodine substrate and a more	rapid secretion of newly iodinated thyroglobulin	2181.615251945178
8274. if the deficiency	persists long enough it is reasonable to suppose that the f label	will reflect the f distribution in the thyroglobulin	3472.899918868357
8275. similar results	might be expected from the influence of drugs or pathological conditions	that limit iodide trapping or organification or accelerate thyroglobulin	proteolysis	2323.242593087875
8276. the	name thyroid-stimulating hormone has been given to a substance	found in the anterior pituitary gland of all species of animal so	far	tested for its presence	4265.921563153255
8277. the hormone has also been called thyrotrophin	or thyrotrophic hormone	373.1000223330448
8278. at the present time we do not know by what	biochemical mechanism tsh acts on the thyroid but for bio-assay	of the hormone there are a number of properties by which its activity	may be estimated including release of iodine from the thyroid increase	in thyroid weight increase in mean height of the follicular cells	and increase in the thyroidal uptake of f	8476.28420475536
8279. here we shall restrict	discussion to those methods that appear sufficiently sensitive and precise	for determining the concentration of tsh in blood	2168.773579170337
8280. brown	has reviewed generally the various methods of assaying tsh	and the reader is referred to her paper for further information on	the subject	3698.1646565185933
8281. tsh	as long ago as 1851 it was pointed out by niepce	that there is a connection between the pituitary and the thyroid	2319.951913680966
8282. this connection was clarified by smith and smith who showed	that saline extracts of fresh bovine pituitary glands could re-activate	the atrophied thyroids of hypophysectomised tadpoles	4087.2079966586252
8283. the first attempts	to isolate tsh came a decade later when janssen and loeser	used trichloroacetic acid to separate the soluble tsh	from insoluble impurities	2607.6622110195576
8284. after their work other investigators applied	salt-fractionation techniques to the problem as well as fractionation	with organic solvents such as acetone	3050.772247423455
8285. albert has concluded	that the most active preparations of tsh made during this period	from 1931 to 1945 were probably about 100 to 300 times as potent	as the starting material	3334.1450606412095
8286. much of this work has been reviewed by	white	392.9421661222971
8287. developments up to about 1957 have	been discussed by sonenberg	374.8660066716447
8288. in the last few years	the application of chromatographic and other modern techniques to the	problem of isolating tsh has led to further purification		2537.618011459152
8289. the most	active preparations obtained by these two groups of investigators	appear to be similar in potency composition and physical properties	2037.7663103347063
8290. two problems present themselves in considering any hormone in	blood	556.2626214136831
8291. first is the circulating form of the hormone the same as that	found in the gland where it is synthesised and stored	2189.046507673382
8292. second what	is its concentration in normal circumstances and in what circumstances	will this concentration depart from the normal level and in which direction	3706.6333461141285
8293. it is therefore necessary to consider the properties of pituitary	tsh if the fragmentary chemical information about blood	tsh is to be discussed rationally	2472.2925533164
8294. the importance of knowing in	what chemical forms the hormone may exist is accentuated by the recent	observation that there exists an abnormally long-acting tsh in	blood drawn from many thyrotoxic patients	5135.395768026337
8295. whether this	abnormal tsh differs chemically from pituitary tsh or	is alternatively normal tsh with its period of effectiveness	modified	by some other blood constituent cannot be decided without chemical	study of the activity in the blood of these patients and a comparison	of the substance responsible for the blood activity with pituitary	tsh	5201.854262455563
8296. in evaluating data on the concentration of tsh	in blood one must examine critically the bio-assay methods used	to obtain them	3043.025448701758
8297. the introduction of the united states pharmacopoeia	reference standard in 1952 and the redefinition and equating of the	usp and international units of thyroid-stimulating activity have	made it possible to compare results published by different investigators	since that time	4107.746975405219
8298. we should like to re-emphasise the importance of	stating results solely in terms of international units of tsh activity	and of avoiding the re-introduction of biological units	4268.176701049003
8299. for	the most part this discussion will be confined to results obtained since	a	944.0508717310937
8300. standard preparations	the international	unit	adopted to make possible the comparison of results from different	laboratories has been defined as the	amount of activity present in 13	4284.033403040356
8301. 5 mg of the international standard	preparation	93.91028971868018
8302. the international unit is equipotent with the usp	unit adopted in 1952 which was defined as the amount of activity	present in 20 mg of the usp reference substance	4633.942888178583

8494. since emotional reactions in the higher vertebrates depend on	individual experience and are aroused in man in addition by complex	symbols one would expect that the hypothalamus could be excited from	the cortex	5320.831347883802
8495. in experiments with topical application of strychnine on	the cerebral cortex the transmission of impulses from the cortex to the	hypothalamus was demonstrated	2329.097150512364
8496. moreover the responsiveness of the	hypothalamus to nociceptive stimulation is greatly increased under these	conditions	1659.1387905515046
8497. even more complex and obviously cortically induced forms	of emotional arousal could be elicited in monkey a on seeing	monkey b in emotional stress	2457.5539389307082
8498. a previously	extinguished conditioned reaction was restored in monkey a	and was associated	with typical signs of emotional excitement including sympathetic	discharges	3248.8661931938814
8499. it seems to follow that by and large an antagonism	exists between the paleo- and the neocortex as far as emotional reactivity	is concerned and that the balance between the two systems determines	the emotional responsiveness of the organism	4149.483070862389
8500. in addition the	neocortical-hypothalamic relations play a great role in primates as	mirsky's interesting experiment on the communication of affect	demonstrates	3061.197466648533
8501. but even in relatively primitive laboratory animals	such as the rat sex activity closely identified with the hypothalamus	and the visceral brain is enhanced by the neocortex	2879.2278734532597
8502. maclean stressed	correctly the importance of the visceral brain for preservation of	the individual and the species as evidenced by the influence of the	limbic brain on emotions related to fight	and flight and also on sexual functions	6055.002115124955
8503. it should be added that in	man	neocortical-hypothalamic interrelations probably play a role in the fusion	of emotional processes with those underlying perception memory	imagination and creativity	2845.076747187119
8504. previous experiences are obviously	of great importance for the qualitative and quantitative emotional	response	1408.3390910977141
8505. the visceral brain as well as the neocortex is known to contribute	to memory but this topic is beyond the scope of this	paper	2461.019953828345
8506. after	this brief discussion of neo- paleocortical and cortico-hypothalamic	relations let us return once more to the problem of hypothalamic balance	and its physiological and pathological significance	4296.902281916405
8507. facilitatory	processes take place between neocortex and hypothalamus via ascending	and descending pathways	793.9215005806425
8508. thus cortico-fugal discharges induced by topical	application of strychnine to a minute area in the neocortex summate	with spikes present in the hypothalamus and cause increased convulsive	discharges	4469.700336454494
8509. on the other hand the temporary reduction in hypothalamic	excitability through the injection of a barbiturate into the posterior	hypothalamus causes a lessening in frequency and amplitude of	cortical strychnine spikes until the hypothalamic excitability is restored	3957.2592034542663
8510. apparently a positive feedback exists between the posterior hypothalamus	and the cerebral cortex	1188.7607928767152
8511. consequently if for any reason	the hypothalamic excitability falls below the physiological level the	lessened hypothalamic-cortical discharges lead to a diminished state	of activity in the cortex with consequent reduction in the cortico-fugal	discharges	3667.8967201914907
8512. obviously a vicious cycle develops	22.100699325696233
8513. this tendency can	be broken either by restoring hypothalamic excitability directly or	via cortico-hypothalamic pathways	1102.7185213028802
8514. it is believed that drug therapy	and electroshock involve the former and psychotherapy the latter mechanism	1889.8156855519615
8515. before we comment further on these pathological conditions	we should remember that changes in the state of the hypothalamus within	physiological limits distinguish sleep from wakefulness	2751.9381145843713
8516. thus	a low intensity of hypothalamic-cortical discharges prevails in sleep	and a high one during wakefulness resulting in synchronous eeg	potentials in the former and asynchrony in the latter condition	4832.877075314036
8517. moreover	the dominance in parasympathetic action	at the hypothalamic level induces by its peripheral	action the autonomic symptoms of sleep and by its action on the	cortex a lessening in the reactivity of the sensory and motor apparatus	of the somatic nervous system	4472.8335764592075
8518. with the dominance of the sympathetic	division of the hypothalamus the opposite changes occur	1405.921055237954
8519. since	electrical stimulation of the posterior hypothalamus produces the effects	of wakefulness while stimulation of the anterior hypothalamus induces	sleep it may be said that the reactivity of the whole organism is	altered by a change in the autonomic reactivity of the hypothalamus	4440.806166773962
8520. similar effects can be induced reflexly via the baroreceptor reflexes	in man and animals	1422.9193862973311
8521. of particular importance is the study of	the actions of drugs in this respect	941.0722531418772
8522. although no drugs act exclusively	on the hypothalamus or a part of it there is sufficient specificity	to distinguish drugs which shift the hypothalamic balance to the sympathetic	side from those which produce a parasympathetic dominance	5800.05984057234
8523. the	former comprise analeptic and psychoactive drugs the latter the tranquilizers	503.2874922688813
8524. specific differences exist in the action of different drugs	belonging to the same group as for instance between reserpine and	chlorpromazine	3046.685045028693
8525. important as these differences are they should not	obscure the basic fact that by shifting the hypothalamic balance sufficiently	to the parasympathetic side we produce depressions whereas	a shift in the opposite direction causes excitatory effects and eventually	maniclike changes	4229.144874882257
8526. the emotional states produced by drugs influence	the cortical potentials in a characteristic manner; synchrony	prevails in the eeg of the experimental animal after administration	of tranquilizers but asynchrony after application of analeptic and	psychoactive drugs	5771.240043235169
8527. the shock therapies act likewise on the	hypothalamic balance	264.1768950967268
8528. physiological experiments and clinical observations	have shown that these procedures influence the hypothalamically controlled	hypophyseal secretions and increase sympathetic discharges	2825.839147590324
8529. they shift the hypothalamic balance to the sympathetic side	261.90407449762574
8530. this explains	the beneficial effect of electroshock therapy in certain depressions	and a shift in the reaction from hypo- to normal reactivity of the	sympathetic system as shown by the mecholyl test	5185.697732320648
8531. some investigators	have found a parallelism between remissions and return of the sympathetic	reactivity of the hypothalamus to the normal level as indicated	by the mecholyl test and conversely between clinical impairment and	increasing deviation of this test from the norm	4313.858520474835
8532. nevertheless the	theory that the determining influence of the hypothalamic balance has	a profound influence on the clinical behavior of neuropsychiatric patients	has not yet been tested on an adequate number of patients	5324.486310598472
8533. the	mecholyl and noradrenalin tests applied with certain precautions are	reliable indicators of this central autonomic balance but for the sake	of correlating autonomic and clinical states and of studying the effect	of certain therapeutic procedures on central autonomic reactions	additional tests seem to be desirable	4670.659285451109
8534. it was assumed that the	shift in autonomic hypothalamic balance occurring spontaneously in	neuropsychiatric	patients from the application of certain therapeutic procedures	follows the pattern known from the sleep-wakefulness cycle	4852.52575449494
8535. a change in the balance to the parasympathetic side leads in the normal	individual to sleep or in special circumstances to cardiovascular	collapse or nausea and vomiting	2874.332941886783
8536. in both conditions the emotional and	perceptual sensitivity is diminished but no depression occurs such	as is seen clinically or may be produced in normal persons by drugs	4486.893158459496
8537. the	fundamental differences between physiological and pathological states	of parasympathetic dominance remain to be	elucidated	1088.8813474943865
8538. perhaps a clue to these and related problems lies	in the fact that changes in the intensity of hypothalamic discharges	which are associated with changes in its balance lead also to qualitative	alterations in reactivity	5624.074457340243
8539. a state of parasympathetic tuning	of the hypothalamus induced experimentally causes not only an increase	in the parsympathetic reactivity of this structure to direct and	reflexly induced stimuli but leads also to an autonomic reversal:	a stimulus acting sympathetically under control conditions elicits in	this state of tuning a parasympathetic response! furthermore conditioned	reactions are fundamentally altered when the hypothalamic sympathetic	reactivity is augmented beyond a critical level and several types	of behavioral changes probably related to the degree of central autonomic	tuning are observed	0.20124717349522497
8540. if for instance such a change is	produced by one or a few insulin comas or electroshocks previously	inhibited conditioned reactions reappear	3277.820114487912
8541. however if these procedures	are applied more often conditioned emotional responses are temporarily	abolished	946.7146884656297
8542. in other studies loss of differentiation in previously	established conditioned reflexes resulted from repeated convulsive	treatments suggesting a fundamental disturbance in the balance	between excitatory and inhibitory cerebral processes	4652.055322905689
8543. it has	further been shown that: an experimental neurosis in its initial	stages is associated with a reversible shift in the central autonomic	balance; drugs altering the hypothalamic balance alter conditioned	reactions; in a state of depression the positive conditioned	stimulus may fail to elicit a conditioned reaction but cause an increased	synchrony instead of the excitatory desynchronizing	effect on the eeg	5623.639985122836
8544. these are few and seemingly disjointed data	but they illustrate the important fact that fundamental alterations	in conditioned reactions occur in a variety of states in which the hypothalamic	balance has been altered by physiological experimentation	pharmacological action or clinical processes	6451.26227989868
8545. basis of some form of psychotherapy	the foregoing remarks	imply	that the hypothalamic balance plays a crucial role at the crossroads	between physiological and pathological forms of emotion	2995.112060920179
8546. if this is	the case one would expect that not only the various procedures just	mentioned which alter the hypothalamic balance would influence emotional	state and behavior but that emotion itself would act likewise	5507.452567995043
8547. we	pointed out that emotional excitement may lead to psychosomatic disorders	and neurotic symptoms particularly in certain types of personality	but it is also known that the reliving of a strong emotion	may cure a battle neurosis	3937.7036256344063
8548. this phenomenon raises the question	whether the guidance of the emotions for therapeutic ends may not	have an even wider application in the area of the neuroses	4267.420809219189
8549. being	a strictly	physiological procedure one may expect from such a study additional	information on the nature of the emotional process itself	2187.1650497876904
8550. wolpe's experiments and therapeutic work lie in this area	391.18375028851545
8551. he showed	convincingly that anxiety is a learned reaction and	is the basis of experimental and clinical neuroses and assumed therefore	that the neuronal changes which underlie the neuroses are functional	and reversible	3554.864979435494
8552. an important observation of pavlov served as a	guide post to achieve such a reversibility by physiological means	2370.2056067733147
8553. in	a conditioning experiment he demonstrated the antagonism between feeding	and pain	643.2810516289054
8554. a mild electrical shock served as a conditioned stimulus	and was followed by feeding	1420.284695179578
8555. the pain became thus the symbol for food	and elicited salivary secretion	644.090258255942
8556. even when the	intensity of the shocks was increased gradually it failed to evoke	any signs of pain	2338.8805669876974
8557. since strong nociceptive stimuli produce an experimental	neurosis during which the animals fail to eat in the experimental	situation wolpe thought that he could utilize the feeding-pain antagonism	to inhibit the neurotic symptoms through feeding	3753.777256176937
8558. appropriate	experiments showed that this is indeed possible	249.68843582266078
8559. he then applied	this	principle of reciprocal inhibition to human neuroses	493.82655254507983
8560. he took advantage	of the antagonism between aggressive assertiveness and anxiety	and found a relatively rapid disappearance of anxiety when the former	attitude was established	3884.850810741972
8561. for the interpretation of these significant	investigations it should be remembered that reciprocal relations	exist in the hypothalamus with respect to autonomic and somatic functions	which are closely associated with the emotions	3445.5571337164633
8562. the feeding-pain	antagonism seems to be based on this reciprocal relation between the	tropho- and ergotropic systems	2101.230742701527
8563. furthermore a functional antagonism	exists between an aggressive attitude and a state of anxiety	947.6842216083608
8564. although	in both emotions sympathetic symptoms are present different autonomic-somatic	patterns underlie aggression and anxiety respectively	as indicated by the rate of the excretion of the catecholamines the state	of the muscle tone and the mecholyl test	5919.977833570018
8565. the psychological incompatibility	of these emotional states seems to be reflected in or based	on this marked difference	1561.516992353714
8566. in	our attempt to interpret the emotions in their physiological and pathological	range we emphasized the importance of the degree of activity	of the parasympathetic and sympathetic divisions of the hypothalamic system	and their influence on the inhibitory and excitatory systems respectively	6558.438813922415
8567. we stressed the reciprocal relation of these systems with	respect to the autonomic-somatic downward discharge as well as regarding	the hypothalamic-cortical discharge	2173.165363756238
8568. although we are still far from	a complete understanding of these problems as a first approximation	it is suggested that alterations in the hypothalamic balance with consequent	changes in the hypothalamic-cortical discharges account for	major changes in behavior seen in various moods and states of emotions	in man and beast under physiological circumstances in experimental and	clinical neurosis and as the result of psychopharmacological agents	8611.471128626119
8569. in view of the important role which emotional disturbances play in	the genesis of neurotic and psychotic disorders and the parallelism	observed between autonomic states and psychological behavior in several	instances it is further suggested that a hypothalamic imbalance may	play an important role in initiating mental changes	4824.0165589078615

8936. these societies can expect to face difficult times	247.89956685292864
8937. as the historic	processes of modernization gradually gain momentum their cohesion	will be threatened by divisive forces the gaps between rulers and	subjects town and country will widen; new aspirants for power will	emerge whose ambitions far exceed their competence; old rulers may	lose their nerve and their sense of direction	5011.606605089996
