9599. roleplaying was offered as a solution-	and the procedure worked as follows: all candidates were invited	to a hotel conference room where the president explained the difficulty	he had and how unnecessary it seemed to him to hire people who	just did not work out	4628.567564896086
9600. in place of asking salesmen to fill questionnaires	checking their references interviewing them asking them to	be tried out he told them he would prefer to test them	4452.90588962395
9601. each person	was to enter the testing room carrying a suitcase of samples	789.4931784043376
9602. each salesman	was to read a sheet containing a description of the product	1184.4998158107232
9603. in	the testing room he was to make successively three presentations	to three different people	1088.1048657722765
9604. in the testing room three of the veteran	salesmen served as antagonists	969.3138779954086
9605. one handled the salesman in a	friendly manner another in a rough manner and the third in a hesitating	manner	1882.9086276285282
9606. each was told to purchase material if he felt like it	750.1348039481032
9607. the	antagonists came in one at a time and did not see or hear the other	presentations	1419.0212724527387
9608. after each presentation the antagonist wrote his judgment	of the salesmen; and so did the observers consisting of the	president three of his salesmen and a psychologist	4303.030318338784
9609. ten salesmen	were tested in the morning and ten more in the afternoon	789.2701997829374
9610. this procedure	was repeated one day a month for four months	755.7878511757897
9611. the batting average	of one success out of seven increased to one out of three	1089.0756802417645
9612. the president	of the firm calculating expenses alone felt his costs had dropped	one-half while success in selection had improved over one hundred	per cent	3896.43180970588
9613. the reason for the value of this procedure was simply	that the applicants were tested at work in different situations	by the judgment of a number of experts who could see how the salesmen	conducted themselves with different but typical restaurant owners	and managers	4514.87684335549
9614. they were in a sense tried out in realistic situations	563.3984332396936
9615. from the point of view of the applicants less time	was wasted in being evaluated- and they got a meal out of it as well	as some insights into their performances	3321.4008941252555
9616. another use of roleplaying	for evaluation illustrates how this procedure can be used in	real life situations without special equipment or special assistants during	the daily course of work	4640.515737157507
9617. the position of receptionist was	opened in a large office and an announcement was made to the other	girls already working that they could apply for this job which had higher	prestige and slightly higher salary than typing and clerking positions	4296.616640090212
9618. all applicants were generally familiar with the work of the receptionist	758.0914410702296
9619. at the end of work one day the personnel man took the applicants	one at a time asked them to sit behind the receptionist's desk	and he then played the role of a number of people who might come to	the receptionist with a number of queries and for a number of purposes	5126.317769842956
9620. each girl was independently tested by the personnel man and	he served not only as the director but as the antagonist and the observer	3725.848839738642
9621. somewhat to his surprise he found that one girl whom	he would never have considered for the job since she had appeared somewhat	mousy and also had been in the office a relatively short time did	the most outstanding job of playing the role of receptionist showing	wit sparkle and aplomb	5025.413444862083
9622. she was hired and was found to be entirely	satisfactory when she played the role eight hours a day	2594.7182939629483
9623. in considering roleplaying for analysis we enter a more complex area	since we are now no longer dealing with a simple over-all decision	but rather with the examination and evaluation of many elements seen	in dynamic functioning	3942.177542880863
9624. some cases in evidence of the use of roleplaying	for analysis may help explain the procedure	1872.0214182308114
9625. an engineer	had been made the works manager of a firm supplanting a retired employee	who had been considered outstandingly successful	2041.6981389684483
9626. the engineer had	more than seven years of experience in the firm was well trained was	considered a hard worker was respected by his fellow engineers for	his technical competence and was regarded as a comer	5772.186305645872
9627. however	he turned out to be a complete failure in his new position	784.5602932696529
9628. he seemed	to antagonize everyone	22.232430212281308
9629. turnover rates of personnel went up production	dropped and morale was visibly reduced	788.5066222836635
9630. despite the fact that he	was regarded as an outstanding engineer he seemed to be a very poor	administrator although no one quite knew what was wrong with him	4660.508456501272
9631. at	the insistence of his own supervisor- the president of the firm he	enrolled in a course designed to develop leaders	2031.019157539164
9632. he played	a number of typical situations before observers other supervisors who	kept notes and then explained to him in detail what he did they thought	was wrong	4444.996777866539
9633. entirely concerned with efficiency he was merciless in	criticizing people who made mistakes condemning them to too great an	extent	1878.5728689007615
9634. he did not really listen to others had little interest in their	ideas and wanted to have his own way- which was the only right	way	4104.6634585573165
9635. the entire group of managers explained in great detail a number	of human relations errors that he made	1562.6098533846284
9636. one by one these	errors were discussed and one by one he rejected accepting them as errors	2120.3209607391045
9637. he admitted his behavior and defended it	93.5089291310588
9638. he refused to change	his approach and instead he attacked high and low- the officials for	their not backing him and subordinates for their laxness stupidity	and stubbornness	4484.802869057201
9639. after the diagnosing he left the course convinced	that it could do him no good	1102.752111488227
9640. we may say that his problem	was diagnosed but that he refused treatment	1175.3556444966723
9641. the engineer turned works	manager had a particular view of life- and refused to change it	1261.7108176006973
9642. we	may say that his attitude was foolish since he may have been a success	had he learned some human relations skills; or we may say that	his attitude was commendable showing his independence of mind in his	refusal to adjust to the opinions of others	7014.367950249734
9643. in any case he refused	to accept the implications of the analysis that he needed to be made	over	1731.5888577240596
9644. another case may be given in illustration of a successful	use of analysis and also of the employment of a procedure for intensive	analysis	3666.5087345729175
9645. in a course for supermarket operators a district manager	who had been recently appointed to his position after being outstandingly	successful as a store manager found that in supervising other	managers he was having a difficult time	3940.692542911969
9646. on playing some typical situations	before a jury of his peers he showed some characteristics rated	as unsatisfactory	2378.576948366769
9647. he was told he displayed for example a sense	of superiority- and he answered: well i am supposed to know	all the answers aren't i	2596.9185736868053
9648. he was criticized for his curtness	and abruptness- and he answered: i am not working to become	popular	2344.9603076875437
9649. on being criticized for his arbitrary behavior- he answered:	i have to make decisions	937.010026771222
9650. in short	as frequently happens in analyses the individual feels threatened and	defends himself	1415.9211061128203
9651. however in this case the district manager was led	to see the errors of his ways	1246.3752818324763
9652. the necessary step between diagnosis and	training is acceptance of the validity of the criticisms	1647.6365826967788
9653. how this	was accomplished may be described since this sometimes is a crucial	problem	942.0356126251654
9654. the director helped tailor-make a check list of the district	manager's errors by asking various observers to write out sentences	commenting on the mistakes they felt he made	4468.793069839223
9655. these errors were	then collected and written on a blackboard condensing similar ideas	794.0565457209551
9656. eighteen errors were located and then the director asked each individual	to vote whether or not they felt that this manager had made the	particular errors	4080.1432386907713
9657. they were asked to vote true if they thought	they had seen him make the error false if they thought he had	not; and cannot say if they were not certain	3333.1844428125414
9658. the manager	sat behind the group so he could see and count the hands that went	up and the director wrote the numbers on the blackboard	4119.158086210053
9659. no comments	were made during the voting	94.33403421573001
9660. the results looked as follows: f	65.67682294395854
9661. the first eight of these eighteen statements which received	at least one-half of the votes were duplicated to form an analysis	checklist for the particular manager and when this particular manager	roleplayed in other situations the members checked any items that appeared	4380.84522558808
9662. to prevent the manager from deliberately controlling himself	only during the sessions they were rather lengthy	the situations were imperfectly described to the manager so that	he would not know what to expect new antagonists were brought on the	scene unexpectedly and the antagonists were instructed to deliberately	behave in such ways as to upset the manager and get him to operate in	a manner for which he had been previously criticized	0.30166232349522504
9663. after	every session the check marks were totaled up and graphed and in this	way the supervisor's progress was charted	1872.5298510449666
9664. in life	we learn to play our roles and we freeze into patterns which become	so habitual that we are not really aware of what we do	4276.7251468322365
9665. we can see	others more clearly than we can see ourselves and others can see us	better than we see ourselves	2034.2857949572804
9666. to learn what we do is the first step	for improvement	759.5207560815046
9667. to accept the validity of the judgments of others is	the second step	789.6603744101127
9668. to want to change is the third step	252.5443876340069
9669. to practice new	procedures under guided supervision and with constant feedback is the	fourth step	1100.4132485183463
9670. to use these new ways in daily life is the last step	961.3961794244012
9671. roleplaying used for analysis follows these general steps leading to	training	505.9356113785806
9672. when an evaluative situation is set up and no concern	is with the details that lead to an over-all estimate we say that	roleplaying is used for evaluation	4467.109638765383
9673. observers can see a person engaged	in spontaneous behavior and watch him operating in a totalistic fashion	1420.0127567970678
9674. this behavior is more veridical- or true than other	testing behavior for some types of evaluation and so can give quick and	accurate estimates of complex functioning	4289.651543497772
9675. while roleplaying	for testing is not too well understood at the present time it represents	one of the major uses of this procedure	2323.2835044573794
9676. training	the objective of this chapter is to clarify	the distinctions between spontaneity theory and other training concepts	2370.153431981803
9677. in addition the basic approach utilized in applying roleplaying will	be reviewed	643.7164936536846
9678. the goal will be to provide the reader with an integrated	rationale to aid him in applying roleplaying techniques in this	unique training area	3702.504450247997
9679. the reasons for extracting this particular roleplaying	application from the previous discussion of training are twofold:	spontaneity training theory is unique and relatively new	2476.3716403017984
9680. it is not easy for the therapist to discern when in the patient's	communicating an introject has appeared and is holding sway	3259.109673812351
9681. one	learns to become alert to changes in his vocal tone- to his voice's	suddenly shifting to a quality not like his usual one a quality	which sounds somehow artificial or in some instances parrotlike	3764.153380617866
9682. the	content of his words may lapse back into monotonous repetition as	if a phonograph needle were stuck in one groove; only seldom is it so	simple as to be a matter of his obviously parroting some timeworn axiom	common to our culture which he has evidently heard over and over	from a parent until he experiences it as part of him	8448.83785106585
9683. one hebephrenic	woman often became submerged in what felt to me like a somehow	phony experience of pseudo-emotion during which despite her wracking	sobs and streaming cheeks i felt only a cold annoyance with her	3745.804884627494
9684. eventually such incidents became more sporadic and more sharply demarcated	from her day-after-day behavior and in one particular session	after several minutes of such behavior- which as usual went on	without any accompanying words from her- she asked eagerly did	you see granny	6664.704139017847
9685. at first i did not know what she meant; i	thought she must be seeing me as some one who had just come from	seeing	her grandmother in their distant home-city	3327.426450254942
9686. then i realized that	she had been deliberately showing me this time what granny was like;	and when i replied in this spirit she corroborated my hunch	4259.867066738243
9687. at another phase in the therapy when a pathogenic mother-introject	began to emerge more and more upon the investigative scene she muttered	in a low but intense voice to herself i hate that woman inside	me! i could evoke no further elaboration from her about this;	but a few seconds later she was standing directly across the room	from me looking me in the eyes and saying in a scathingly condemnatory	tone your	father despises you! again i at first misconstrued	this disconcertingly intense communication and i quickly cast	through my mind to account for her being able to speak with such utter	conviction of an opinion held by my father now several years deceased	0.20124717349522497
9688. then i replied coldly if you despise me why don't you	say so directly	1414.9190832002414
9689. she looked confused at this and i felt sure	it had been a wrong response for me to make	1718.375688073997
9690. it then occurred to me to	ask is that what that woman told you	1397.7991384378274
9691. she clearly agreed	that this had been the case	260.80472930245753
9692. i realized now that she had been showing	me in what impressed me as being a very accurate way something her	mother had once said to her; it was as if she was showing me one of	the reasons why she hated that woman inside her	6988.540057809371
9693. what had been an unmanageably	powerful introject was now despite its continuing charge	of energy disconcerting to me sufficiently within control of her ego	that she could use it to show me what this introjected mother was like	4006.7648417594073
9694. earlier this woman had been so filled with a chaotic variety	of introjects that at times when she was in her room alone it would	sound to a passerby as though there were several different persons in	the room as she would vocalize in various kinds of voice	7232.675085739216
9695. a somewhat	less fragmented hebephrenic patient of mine who used to often seclude	herself in her room often sounded through the closed door- as i	would find on passing by between our sessions- for all the world	like two persons a scolding mother and a defensive child	4749.672668364873
9696. particularly	hard for the therapist to grasp are those instances in which	the patient is manifesting an introject traceable to something in the	therapist some aspect of the therapist of which the latter is himself	only poorly aware and the recognition of which as a part of himself	he finds distinctly unwelcome	7609.106557157347
9697. i have found time and again that	some bit of particularly annoying and intractable behavior on the part	of a patient rests in the final analysis on this basis; and only	when i can acknowledge this to myself as being indeed an aspect of	my personality does it cease to be a prominently troublesome aspect of	the patient's behavior	5467.328808363806
9698. for example one hebephrenic man used to	annoy me month after month by saying whenever i got up to leave and	made my fairly steoreotyped comment that i would be seeing him on the	following day or whenever you're welcome in a notably condescending	fashion- as though it were his due for me to thank him	for the privilege of spending the hour with him and he were thus pointing	up my failure to utter a humbly grateful thank you to him	at the end of each session	0.30166232349522504
9699. eventually it became clear to me partly	with the aid of another schizophrenic patient who could point out my	condescension to me somewhat more directly that this man with his	condescending	you're welcome was very accurately personifying	an element of obnoxious condescension which had been present in my own	demeanor over these months on each of these occasions when i had	bid him good-bye with the consoling note each time that the healing	christ would be stooping to dispense this succor to the poor suffered	again on the morrow	0.20124717349522497
9700. another patient a paranoid woman for many	months infuriated not only me but the ward-personnel and her fellow	patients by arrogantly behaving as though she owned the whole building	as though she were the only person in it whose needs were to be met	6782.031348094686
9701. this behavior on her part subsided only after i had come to see the	uncomfortably close similarity between on the one hand her arranging	the ventilation of the common living room to her own liking or turning	the television off or on without regard to the wishes of the others	and on the other hand my own coming stolidly into her room despite	her persistent and vociferous objections bringing my big easy chair	with me usually shutting the windows of her room which she preferred	to keep in a very cold state and plunking myself down in my chair-	in short behaving as if i owned her room	0.20124717349522497
9702. here a variety of meanings and emotions are concentrated or reduced	in their communicative expression to some comparatively simple-seeming	verbal or nonverbal statement	3475.198241892233
9703. one finds for example	that a terse and stereotyped	verbal expression seeming at first to be	a mere hollow convention reveals itself over the months of therapy	as the vehicle for expressing the most varied and intense feelings and	the most unconventional of meanings	4551.246940888996
9704. more than anything it is the	therapist's intuitive sensing of these latent meanings in the stereotype	which helps these meanings to become revealed something like a spread-out	deck of cards on sporadic occasions over the passage of the	patient's and his months of work together	6921.152766621961
9705. one cannot assume of course	that all these accumulated meanings were inherent in the stereotype	at the beginning of the therapy or at any one time later on when	the stereotype was uttered; probably it is correct to think of it as	a matter of a well-grooved stereotyped mode of expression- and no	or but a few other communicational grooves as yet- being there	available for the patient's use as newly-emerging emotions and	ideas well up in him over the course of months	0.20124717349522497
9706. but it is true that the	therapist can sense when he hears this stereotype that there are	at this moment many emotional determinants at work in it a blurred babel	of indistinct voices which have yet to become clearly delineated from	one another	6669.230167330863
9707. sometimes it is not a verbal stereotype- a	how are you now	643.6361955630626
9708. or an i want to go home or whatever-	but a nonverbal one which reveals itself gradually as the condensed	expression of more than one latent meaning	4308.651584487539
9709. a hebephrenic man used	to give a repetitious wave of his hand a number of times during his	largely-silent	hours with his therapist	2307.513850837598
9710. when the therapist came to feel	on sufficiently sure ground with him to ask him what is that	bill- hello or farewell	3259.70306231515
9711. the patient replied both dearie-	two in one	168.16942689417067
9712. of all the possible forms of nonverbal expression	that which seems best to give release and communicational expression	to complex and undifferentiated feelings is laughter	3876.0100099662695
9713. it is	no coincidence that the hebephrenic patient the most severely dedifferentiated	of all schizophrenic patients shows as one of his characteristic	symptoms laughter- laughter which now makes one feel scorned	or hated which now makes one feel like weeping or which now gives	one a glimpse of the bleak and empty expanse of man's despair; and	which more often than all these conveys a welter of feelings which	could in no way be	conveyed by any number of words words which are so	unlike this welter in being formed and discrete from one another	0.20124717349522497
9714. to	a much less full extent the hebephrenic person's belching or flatus	has a comparable communicative function; in working with these patients	the therapist eventually gets to do some at least private mulling	over of the possible meaning of a belch or the passage of flatus	not only because he is reduced to this for lack of anything else to analyze	but also because he learns that even these animal-like sounds constitute	forms of communication in which from time to time quite different	things are being said long before the patient can become sufficiently	aware of these as distinct feelings and concepts to say them	in words	0.30166232349522504
9715. as i have been intimating in the schizophrenic-	and perhaps also in the dreams of the neurotic; this is a question	which i have no wish to take up- condensation is a phenomenon in which	one finds not a condensed expression of various feelings and ideas	which are at an unconscious level well sorted out but rather a condensed	expression of feelings and ideas which even in the unconscious	have yet to become well differentiated from one another	0.20124717349522497
9716. freeman	cameron and mcghie in their description of the disturbances of thinking	found in chronic schizophrenic patients say in regard to condensation	that h the lack of adequate discrimination between the	self and the environment and the objects contained therein h in itself	is the prototypical condensation	7153.455494403131
9717. in my experience a	great many of the patient's more puzzling verbal communications are	so for the reason that concrete meanings have not become differentiated	from figurative meanings in his subjective experience	3432.7691283984705
9718. thus he may	be referring to some concrete thing or incident in his immediate environment	by some symbolic-sounding hyperbolic reference to transcendental	events on the global scene	4271.181622366335
9719. recently for example a paranoid woman's	large-scale philosophizing in the session about the intrusive	curiosity which has become in her opinion a deplorable characteristic	of mid-twentieth-century human culture developed itself before the	end of the session into a suspicion that i was surreptitiously peeking	at her partially exposed breast as indeed i was	5138.891078708997
9720. or equally	often a concretistic-seeming particularistic-seeming statement may consist	with its mundane exterior in a form of poetry- may be full	of meaning and emotion when interpreted as a figurative expression:	a metaphor a smile an allegory or some other symbolic mode of speaking	6797.17850315582
9721. of such hidden meanings the patient himself is more often	than not entirely unaware	935.6027043759893
9722. his subjective experience may be a remarkably	concretistic one	394.11479992449586
9723. one hebephrenic women confided to me i	live in a world of words as if to her words were fully concrete	objects; burnham in his excellent article concerning schizophrenic	communication includes mention of similar clinical material	3853.4617639220987
9724. a borderline schizophrenic young man told me that to him the various	theoretical concepts about which he had been expounding in a most articulate	fashion during session after session with me were like great	cubes of almost tangibly solid matter up in the air above him; as he	spoke i was reminded of the great bales of cargo which are swung high	in the air from a docked steamship	0.30166232349522504
9725. the many linguistic techniques for reducing the amount of dictionary	information that have been proposed all organize the dictionary's	contents around prefixes stems suffixes etc	2596.4508348215973
9726. a significant	reduction	in the voume of store information is thus realized especially	for a highly inflected language such as russian	3059.8576024626386
9727. for english the reduction	in size is less striking	260.3244571033444
9728. this approach requires that:	each text word be separated into smaller elements to establish a correspondence	between the occurrence and dictionary entries and the information	retrieved from several entries in the dictionary be synthesized	into a description of the particular word	6480.973050941654
9729. the logical scheme used	to accomplish the former influences the placement of information in	the dictionary file	1419.820219986141
9730. implementation of the latter requires storage of	information needed only for synthesis	962.869335626941
9731. we suggest the application	of certain data-processing techniques as a solution to the problem	951.0661664114426
9732. but first we must define two terms so that their meaning will be	clearly understood:  form- any unique sequence of alphabetic	characters that can appear in a language preceded and followed	by a space	5472.159407869699
9733. occurrence- an instance of a form in text	167.71273641148434
9734. we propose a method for selecting only dictionary information	required by the text being translated and a means for passing the information	directly to the occurrences in text	4496.418103252118
9735. we accomplish this by compiling	a list of text forms as text is read by the computer	1415.8746320827086
9736. a random-storage	scheme based on the spelling of forms provides an economical	way to compile this text-form list	2340.2406921309184
9737. dictionary forms found to match	forms in the text list are marked	642.0022636040119
9738. a location in the computer store	is also named for each marked form; dictionary information about the	form stored at this location can be retrieved directly by occurrences	of the form in text	5352.357862236922
9739. finally information is retrieved from the dictionary	as required by stages of the translation process- the grammatic	description for sentence-structure determination equivalent-choice	information for semantic analysis and target-language equivalents	for output construction	3457.030512502342
9740. the dictionary is a form dictionary	at least in the sense that complete forms are used as the basis for matching	text occurrences with dictionary entries	4117.736550252643
9741. also the dictionary	is divided into at least two parts: the list of dictionary forms and	the file of information that pertains to these forms	2601.911245628816
9742. a more detailed	description of dictionary operations- text lookup and dictionary	modification- give a clearer picture	1893.1850604958406
9743. text lookup as we will	describe it consists of three steps	498.3878330319038
9744. the first is compiling a list	of text forms assigning an information cell to each and replacing text	occurrences with the information cell assigned to the form of each	occurrence	4832.643765948278
9745. for this step the computer memory is separated into three	regions: cells in the w-region are used for storage of the forms	in the text-form list; cells in the x-region and y region	are reserved as information cells for text forms	4306.842612073572
9746. when an occurrence	f is isolated during text reading a random memory address f	the address of a cell in the x-region is computed from the form	of f	4658.3216246969605
9747. let f denote the form of f	93.91508357040652
9748. if cell f has not previously	been assigned as the information cell of a form in the text-form	list it is now assigned as the information cell of f	4664.076824864723
9749. the form itself	is stored in the next available cells of the w-region beginning	in cell f	1414.1729963551918
9750. the address f and the number of cells required to	store the form are written in f; the information cell f is saved	to represent the text occurrence	4469.376731303301
9751. text reading continues with the next	occurrence	94.08361397932448
9752. let us assume that f is identical to the form	of an occurrence f which preceded f in the text	2816.530134056708
9753. when this situation	exists the address f will equal f which was produced from f	1097.01856587142
9754. if f was assigned as the information cell for f the routine can	detect that f is identical to f by comparing f with the form	stored at location f	4831.350112657419
9755. the address f is stored in the cell f	261.7521031119119
9756. when	as in this case the two forms match the address f is saved to	represent the occurrence f	2582.554624966487
9757. text reading continues with the next	occurrence	94.08361397932448
9758. a third situation is possible	22.31359518685028
9759. the formula for computing	random addresses from the form of each occurrence will not give a	distinct address for each distinct form	2191.525551189735
9760. thus when more than one distinct	form leads to a particular cell in the x-region a chain of	information cells must be created to accommodate the forms one cell	in the chain for each form	5632.084808754846
9761. if f leads to an address f that is equal	to the address computed from f even though f does not match f	the chain of information cells is extended from f by storing the	address of the next available cell in the y-region f in f	4748.922626341557
9762. the	cell f becomes the second information cell in the chain and is assigned	as the information cell of f	2809.1487637010096
9763. a third cell can be added by storing	the address of another y-cell in f; similarly as many cells	are added as are required	2467.8424683466064
9764. each information cell in the chain contains	the address of the y-cell where the form to which it is assigned	is stored	3277.781771083906
9765. each cell except the last in the chain also contains	the address of the y-cell that is the next element of the chain;	the absence of such a link in the last cell indicates the end of the	chain	4107.31022608628
9766. hence when the address f is computed from f the cell f	and	all y-cells in its chain must be inspected to determine whether	f is already in the form list or whether it should be added to the form	list and the chain	6809.638286563662
9767. when the information cell for f has been determined	it is saved as a representation of f	1412.4299156741604
9768. text reading continues	with the next occurrence	141.0279762090883
9769. text reading is terminated when	a pre-determined number of forms have been stored in the text-form list	1412.5917885318065
9770. this initiates the second step of glossary lookup- connecting the	information cell of forms in the text-form list to dictionary forms	3027.1354791617405
9771. each form represented by the dictionary is looked up in the text-form	list	792.9603787851564
9772. each time a dictionary form matches a text form the information	cell of the matching text form is saved	2609.8931325052804
9773. the number of dictionary	forms skipped since the last one matched is also saved	949.7715855278508
9774. these two pieces	of information for each dictionary form that is matched by a text	form constitute the table of dictionary usage	3282.8036441007594
9775. if each text form is	marked when matched with a dictionary form the text forms not contained	in the dictionary can be identified when all dictionary forms have	been read	3237.888666687876
9776. the appropriate action for handling these forms can be taken	at that time	1175.0705965629877
9777. each dictionary form is looked up in the text-form	list by the same method used to look up a new text occurrence in	the form list during text reading	3124.0088773135967
9778. a random address f that lies within	the x-region of memory mentioned earlier is computed from the	i-th dictionary form	2828.113605468066
9779. if cell f is an information cell it and	any information cells in the y-region that have been linked to f	each contain an address in the w-region where a potentially matching	form is stored	3764.8964745893268
9780. the dictionary form is compared with each of these	text forms	753.2114374132508
9781. when a match is found an entry is made in the table of	dictionary usage	1102.0981008802091
9782. if cell f is not an information cell we conclude	that the i-th dictionary form is not in the text list	3051.028682245288
9783. these	two steps essentially complete the lookup operation	167.79486125312107
9784. the final step	merely uses the table of dictionary usage to select the dictionary information	that pertains to each form matched in the text-form list and	uses the list of information cells recorded in text order to attach	the appropriate information to each occurrence in text	7040.271970399981
9785. the list of	text forms in the w-region of memory and the contents of the information	cells in the x and y-regions are no longer required	2731.4796646596988
9786. only	the assignment of the information cells is important	391.79351340378884
9787. the	first stage of translation after glossary lookup is structural analysis	of the input text	1102.0536598054973
9788. the grammatical description of each occurrence in	the text must be retrieved from the dictionary to permit such an analysis	2827.8715484096024
9789. a description of this process will serve to illustrate how any	type of information can be retrieved from the dictionary and attached	to each text occurrence	2733.1388330726286
9790. the grammatic descriptions of all forms	in the dictionary are recorded in a separate part of the dictionary	file	2589.516221436465
9791. the order is identical to the ordering of the forms they describe	637.5575452425967
9792. when entries are being retrieved from this file the table of dictionary	usage indicates which entries to skip and which entries to store	in the computer	4074.386055392036
9793. this selection-rejection process takes place as the	file is read	377.61564756402356
9794. each entry that is selected for storage is written into	the next available cells of the w-region	2132.5851507773177
9795. the address of the	first cell and the number of cells used is written in the information	cell for the form	2035.0777099231207
9796. when the complete file has been	read the grammatic descriptions for all text forms found in the dictionary	have been stored in the w-region; the information cell assigned	to each text form contains the address of the grammatic description	of the form it represents	6817.818832709997
9797. hence the description of each text	occurrence can be retrieved by reading the list of text-ordered information-cell	addresses and outputting the description indicated by the information	cell for each occurrence	3222.2363426317793
9798. the only requirements on	dictionary information made by the text-lookup operation are that each	form represented by the dictionary be available for lookup in the text-form	list and that information for each form be available in a sequence	identical with the sequence of the forms	6913.326438698937
9799. this leaves the ordering	of entries variable	93.57800766602864
9800. two very useful ways for modifying a form-dictionary	are the addition to the dictionary of complete paradigms	rather than single forms and the application of a single change to more	than one dictionary form	5489.580868388514
9801. the former is intended to decrease the amount	of work necessary to extend dictionary coverage	1102.8337046219822
9802. the latter is useful	for modifying information about some or all forms of a word hence	reducing the work required to improve dictionary contents	3698.1394229388998
9803. applying	the techniques developed at harvard for generating a paradigm from	a representative form and its classification we can add all forms of	a word to the dictionary at once	3230.1411623327867
9804. an extension of the principle would	permit entering a grammatic description of each form	1419.7601816794584
9805. equivalents could	be assigned to the paradigm either at the time it is added to the	dictionary or after the word has been studied in context	2744.804789263103
9806. thus one can	think of a dictionary entry as a word rather than a form	1660.7069070687776
9807. if	all forms of a paradigm are grouped together within the dictionary	a considerable reduction in the amount of information required is possible	2316.936384328983
9808. for example the inflected forms of a word can be represented	insofar as regular inflection allows by a stem and a set of endings to	be attached	4282.155647132169
9809. the full forms can be derived from such information	just prior to the lookup of the form in the text-form list	2033.9837010378571
9810. similarly if the equivalents for the forms of a word do not vary the	equivalents need be entered only once with an indication that they	apply	to each form	4661.54031911074
9811. the dictionary system is in no way dependent upon	such summarization or designed around it	1097.3911862390382
9812. when irregularity and variation	prevent summarizing information is written in complete detail	958.1561173248263
9813. entries	are summarized only when by doing so the amount of information	retained in the dictionary is reduced and the time required for dictionary	operations is decreased	2871.593605320515
9814. in sentences patterns of stress are determined by complex combinations	of influences that can only be suggested here	2351.2137955442204
9815. the tendency is toward	putting dominant stress at the end	374.3489388444225
9816. there is a parallel to this tendency	in the assignment of time in long-known hymn tunes	1872.0876248245
9817. thus the	first lines of one of charles wesley's hymns are as follows	789.8238530663663
9818. a charge to keep i have a god to glorify	561.0814717216444
9819. in the	tune to which this hymn is most often sung boylston the syllables	have and fy ending their lines have twice the time any	other syllables have	2980.0324859400216
9820. dominant stress is of course more than extended	duration and normally centers on syllables that would have primary stress	or phrase stress if the words or longer units they are parts of	were spoken alone: a dominant stress given to glorify would normally	center on its first syllable rather than its last	7628.035591625814
9821. but the parallel	is significant	14.831639804871614
9822. when the answer to what's wrong now	140.72665284585116
9823. is bill's	broken a chair dominant stress will usually be on the complement	a chair	1098.5985725944715
9824. from the point of view of syntactic analysis the	head word in the statement is the predicator has broken and from	the point of view of meaning it would seem that the trouble centers	in the breaking; but dominant stress will be assigned to broken	only in rather exceptional versions of the sentence	7698.476597988338
9825. in i know one	thing dominant stress will usually be on the complement one thing;	in one thing i know it will usually be on the predicator know	2990.5407320045288
9826. in small-town people are very friendly dominant stress will	generally be on the complement very friendly; in the double sentence	the smaller the town the friendlier the people it will generally	be on the subjects the town and the people	6348.9774090231185
9827. in what's	a linguist	2.9730204726025073
9828. dominant stress will generally be on the subject	a linguist; in who's a linguist	1429.5317811736102
9829. it will generally be on	the complement a linguist	263.0360410087796
9830. dominant stress is on her luggage	both in that's her luggage where her luggage is the complement	and in there's her luggage where it is the subject	4294.590629629833
9831. adverbial	second complements however are likely not to have dominant stress	when they terminate sentences	1090.7358215984575
9832. if the answer to what was that noise	248.06667914973508
9833. is george put the cat out dominant stress will ordinarily	be on the first complement the cat not the second complement	out	2166.8146949571938
9834. final adjuncts may or may not have dominant stress	391.553897107868
9835. if the	answer to what was that noise	165.49205561635634
9836. is george reads the news emotionally	dominant stress may or may not be on the adjunct emotionally	2121.4891486479873
9837. when prepositional complements are divided as in what are you	looking for	642.1767460905819
9838. they are likely to lose dominant stress	140.9519051761399
9839. context	is of extreme importance	14.772820517422275
9840. what is new in the context is likely	to be made more prominent than what is not	2122.012240316597
9841. thus in a context in which	there has been discussion of snow but mention of local conditions is	new dominant stress will probably be on here in it rarely snows	here but in a context in which there has been discussion of local	weather but no mention of snow dominant stress will probably be on snows	5297.045854171669
9842. the personal pronouns and substitute one are normally unstressed	because they refer to what is prominent in the immediate context	2821.711907502926
9843. in i'll go with george dominant stress is probably on george;	but if george has just been mentioned prominently	what is said is probably	i'll go with him and dominant stress is probably on the preposition	with	3967.8988748200163
9844. when a gesture accompanies who's he	65.90775865517563
9845. the personal	pronoun has dominant stress because he has not been mentioned	previously	790.9687469125104
9846. if both george and a piece of information george	does not have are prominent in the context but the idea of telling george	is new then dominant stress will probably be on tell in why	not tell george	6037.5717984580315
9847. but when what is new in a particular context	is also fairly obvious there is normally only light stress or no stress	at all	2479.4747302647474
9848. thus the unstressed it of it rarely snows here gets	its significance from its use with snows: nothing can snow snow	but it	3473.7080726336635
9849. in there aren't many young people in the neighborhood	the modifier young takes dominant stress away from its head	people: the fact that the young creatures of interest are people	seems rather obvious	3559.991303873286
9850. if women replaced people it would normally	have dominant stress	562.4980520367819
9851. in i have things to do the word things	makes little real contribution to meaning and has weaker stress	than do	2043.8814179687877
9852. if work is substituted for things	it will have dominant stress	749.3165152963695
9853. in i	know one thing dominant stress is likely to go to one rather than	to semantically pale thing	1734.9180492978182
9854. in i knew you when you were a child	and you were pretty then dominant stress on then implies that	the young woman spoken to is still pretty	4478.723074085994
9855. dominant stress on pretty	would be almost insulting here	262.19536087003473
9856. in the written language then	can be underlined or italicized to guide the reader here but much	of the time the written language simply depends on the reader's alertness	and a careless reader will have to back up and reread	6328.343382412383
9857. often dominant stress simply indicates a centering of attention or emotion	501.8738527926369
9858. thus in it's incredible what that boy can eat dominant stress	is likely to be on incredible and eat will have strong	stress also	3672.9397942041423
9859. in she has it in for george dominant stress will ordinarily	be on in where the notion of stored-up antipathy seems to	center	2312.680328973575
9860. in we're painting at our garage strong stress on at	indicates that the job being done is not real painting but simply an	effort at painting	4092.960839996963
9861. where there is comparison or contrast dominant	stresses normally operate to center attention	792.7341498611084
9862. thus in his friends	are stranger than his sisters' strong stresses are normal for his	and sisters' but in his friends are stranger than his sisters	strong stresses are normal for friends and sisters	5522.699490051546
9863. in	he's hurting himself more than he's hurting you both himself	and you have stronger stress than they would ordinarily have if	there were no contrast	2734.532348867022
9864. in is she chinese or japanese	65.9313046386311
9865. the	desire to contrast the first parts of words which are alike in their last	components produces an exceptional disregard of the normal patterns	of stress of chinese and japanese	3223.7621165545997
9866. sometimes strong stress	serves to focus an important secondary relationship	559.141484636292
9867. thus in mary	wrote an account of the trip first strong stress on mary marks	mary as the first in a series of people who wrote accounts of the trip	strong stress on wrote marks the writing as the first of a series	of actions of mary's concerned with an account of her trip	and strong stress	on trip makes the trip the first of a series of subjects about	which mary wrote accounts	0.20124717349522497
9868. in hunger stimulates man too the situation	is very similar	561.9800472993527
9869. strong stress on hunger treats hunger as	an additional stimulus strong stress on stimulates treats stimulation	as an additional effect of hunger strong stress on man treats	man as an additional creature who responds to the stimulation of hunger	4115.068948974855
9870. here again in the written language it is possible to help the	reader get his stresses right by using underlining or italics but much	of the time there is simply reliance on his understanding in the light	of context	6191.74627961505
9871. when a word represents a larger construction of	which it is the only expressed part it normally has more stress than	it would have in fully expressed construction	2996.9307266913465
9872. thus when yes i	have is the response to have you finished reading the paper	1656.9910885009845
9873. the stress on have which here represents have finished reading	the paper is quite strong	1103.2740658725854
9874. in mack's the leader at camp but	jack is here the is of the second main declarative represents	is the leader and therefore has stress	3914.445758371384
9875. mack's the leader at	camp but jack's here with this is deprived of stress makes	here the complement in the clause	2032.9397972371146
9876. in of all the suggestions that	were made his was the silliest the possessive his represents	his suggestion and is stressed	3040.0118902336458
9877. when go represents itself and	a complement in which	boat did jack go on	941.5524435476358
9878. it has strong stress; when it represents	only itself and on which is its complement	on has stronger stress	than go does	3278.7259823783584
9879. omission of a subordinator pronoun however does	not result in an increase in stress on a prepositional adverb for which	the subordinator pronoun would be object	2729.1182686626057
9880. thus to has light stress	both in that was the conclusion that i came to and in that	was the conclusion i came to	3679.0076759993754
9881. but when to represents to consciousness	in that was the moment that i came to and similarly	in that was the moment i came to there is much stronger stress	on to	3427.218512202527
9882. in i wanted to tell him but i was afraid to the final	to is lightly stressed because it represents to tell him	3476.1862062878217
9883. in	to tell him of course to is normally unstressed	375.32282981231225
9884. when i	have instructions to leave is equivalent in meaning to i	have instructions that i am to leave this place dominant stress	is ordinarily on leave	4247.399169984556
9885. when the same sequence is equivalent in	meaning to i have instructions which i am to leave dominant stress	is ordinarily on instructions	2309.409608772322
9886. it is clear that patterns	of stress sometimes	show construction unambiguously in the spoken language where	without the help of context it would be ambiguous in the written	4460.272888437147
9887. i'll come by tuesday	2.9622146216296623
9888. i	can't be happy long without drinking water	249.29122937251896
9889. in the first of these	sentences if by is the complement of come and tuesday is	an adjunct of time equivalent to on tuesday there will be strong	stress on by in the spoken language; but if a complement for	come is implied and by tuesday is a prepositional unit used as	an adjunct by will be unstressed or lightly stressed at most	5682.390519244174
9890. in	the second sentence if drinking water is a gerundial clause and	without drinking water is roughly equivalent in meaning to unless	i drink water there will be stronger stress on water than on	drinking; but if drinking is a gerundial noun modifying water	and without drinking water is equivalent to without water	for drinking there will be stronger stress on drinking than on	water	8577.589136776953
9891. but the use of stress in comparison and contrast for example	can undermine distinctions such as these	1420.3494942263626
9892. and patterns of stress	are not always unambiguous by any means	747.9081377783564
9893. in the steiners have	busy	lives without visiting relatives only context can indicate whether visiting	relatives is equivalent in meaning to paying visits to relatives	or to relatives who are visiting them and in i looked	up the number and i looked up the chimney only the meanings	of number and chimney make it clear that up is syntactically	a second complement in the first sentence and a preposition followed	by its object in the second	0.20124717349522497
9894. syllables are	linguistic units centering in peaks which are usually vocalic but as	has been noted are consonantal under certain circumstances and which	may or may not be combined with preceding andor following consonants	or combinations of consonants	6058.113575108772
9895. syllables are genuine units but division	of words and sentences into them presents great difficulties	1105.9563583307004
9896. sometimes	even the number of syllables is not clear	389.1353759278013
9897. doubt on this point	is strongest before l and  or r	503.9704014423729
9898. from the point of view	of	word formation real might be expected to have two syllables	1875.8490592327325
9899. historically	re is the formative that is employed also in republic	and al is the common suffix	1410.8511138586769
9900. when ity is added	real clearly has two syllables	393.82324024277426
9901. but there is every reason to regard	deal as a monosyllable and because of the fact that l commonly	has the quality of  when it follows vowel sounds deal seems	to be a perfectly satisfactory rhyme with real	4040.874938860946
9902. it is obvious enough that linguists in general have been less	successful in coping with tone systems than with consonants or vowels	3245.138173206399
9903. no single explanation is adequate to account for this	260.4521780287625
9904. improvement	however is urgent and at least three things will be needed	964.7889977913012
9905. the first is a wide-ranging sample of successful tonal analyses	374.42783774340467
9906. even	beginning students in linguistics are made familiar with an appreciable	variety of consonant systems both in their general outlines and in	many specific details	3902.7454743686276
9907. an advanced student has read a considerable	number of descriptions of consonantal systems including some of the more	unusual types	1869.5247632513704
9908. by contrast even experienced linguists commonly know	no more of the range of possibilities in tone systems than the over-simple	distinction between register and contour languages	4085.490099777902
9909. this limited	familiarity with the possible phenomena has severely hampered work	with tone	794.7887664088355
9910. tone analysis will continue to be difficult and unsatisfactory	until a more representative selection of systems is familar to	every practicing field linguist	3488.8820051178236
9911. papers like these four if widely read	will contribute importantly to improvement of our analytic work	1257.7556880439731
9912. the second need is better field techniques	141.9964566348337
9913. the great majority	of present-day linguists fall into one or more of a number of overlapping	types: those who are convinced that tone cannot be analysed those who	are personally scared of tone and tone languages generally those who	are convinced that tone is merely an unnecessary marginal feature in	those languages where it occurs those who have no idea how to proceed	with tone analysis those who take a simplistic view of the whole	matter	0.20124717349522497
9914. the result has been neglect fumbling efforts or superficial	treatment	564.5811907275386
9915. as these maladies overlap so must the cure	168.10170361235146
9916. analyses such	as these four will simultaneously combat the assumptions that tone	is impossible and that it is simple	2594.59836103308
9917. they will give suggestions that	can be worked up into field procedures	639.134766009017
9918. good field techniques will not	only equip linguists for better work but also help them overcome negative	attitudes	2364.1426304038546
9919. actually none of these papers says much directly about	field techniques	504.92350466067927
9920. but it is worth pondering that very little has	been published on any phase of field techniques in linguistics	2584.9047494183305
9921. these	things have been disseminated by other means but always in the wake	of extensive publication of analytic results	1717.9622816536764
9922. the third need	is for better theory	141.52759978483826
9923. we should expect that general phonologic theory	should be as adequate for tone as for consonants and vowels but it has	not been	2328.4331945033227
9924. this can only be for one of two reasons: either the two	are quite different and will require totally different theory	or our existing theories are insufficiently general	4496.132478694801
9925. if as i suspect the problem is largely of the second sort then development	of a theory better able to handle tone will result automatically	in better theory for all phonologic subsystems	3452.937782928373
9926. one issue	that must be faced is the relative difficulty of analysis of different	phonologic subsystems	1869.8374099382079
9927. since tone systems typically comprise fewer	units than either consonant or vowel systems we might expect that they	would be the easiest part of a phonologic analysis	2859.6122595008296
9928. actual practice	does not often work out this way	389.5392098314161
9929. tone systems are certainly more complex	than the number of units would suggest and often analytically	more difficult than much larger consonantal systems	2305.495423499792
9930. welmers has	suggested one explanation	22.508108818472785
9931. tone languages use for linguistic contrasts	speech parameters which also function heavily in nonlinguistic use	1092.9377954521105
9932. this may both divert the attention of the uninitiate and cause confusion	for the more knowledgeable	1886.491400351132
9933. the problem is to disentangle the	linguistic features of pitch from the co-occurring nonlinguistic	features	1100.48793500822
9934. of course something of the same sort occurs with other sectors of	the phonology: consonantal articulations have both a linguistic and	an individual component	3684.2774575275334
9935. but in general the individual variation is	a small thing added onto basic linguistic features of greater magnitude	1580.2527790735999
9936. with tone individual differences may be greater than the linguistic	contrasts which are superimposed on them	1882.3184361370543
9937. pitch differences from	one speaker to another or from one emotional state to another may far	exceed the small differences between tones	2181.0443651807955
9938. however any such suggestion	accounts for only some of the difficulties in hearing tone or in	developing a realistic attitude about tone but not for the analytic	difficulties that occur even when tone is meticulously recorded	5815.888540617949
9939. a second explanation is suggested by the material described in rowlands'	paper	642.4336159456313
9940. tone and intonation often become seriously intermeshed	139.47381043608206
9941. neither can be adequately systematized until we are able to separate	the two and assign the observed phenomena individually to one or the	other	2482.676685145386
9942. other pairs of phonologic subsystems also interact or overlap	in this way; for example duration sometimes figures in both the	vowel system and the intonation	3912.2822945744424
9943. some phonetic features for example	glottal catch or murmur are sometimes to be assigned to segmental phonemics	and sometimes to accentual systems	2177.5222682381177
9944. but no other two phonologic	systems are as difficult to disentangle as are tone and intonation in	some languages	2593.213303722367
9945. this explanation of tone difficulties however does	not apply in all languages	640.5517889587378
9946. in some	interaction of tone and intonation is restricted to the ends of intonation	spans	1650.7375763494213
9947. in many of the syllables intonation can be safely ignored	and much of the tonal analysis can be done without any study of intonation	2459.80999479524
9948. still even in such languages tone analysis has not been as	simple as one might expect	1886.270471955321
9949. a third explanation is suggested	by richardson's analysis of sukuma tone	497.3846643733938
9950. there we see a basically	simple phonemic system enmeshed in a very complex and puzzling morphophonemic	system	2115.1692880510986
9951. while the phonemes can be very easily stated no one	is likely to be satisfied with the statement until phonemic occurrences	can be related in some way to morphemic units ie until the morphophonemics	is worked out or at least far enough that it seems reasonable	to expect success	4881.328351984071
9952. in the typical tone language	tonal morphophonemics is of the same order of complexity as consonantal	morphophonemics	2122.4407389723324
9953. the phonemic systems which must support these morphophonemic	systems however are very different	789.0716718119154
9954. the inventory of tones	is much smaller and commonly the contrasts range along one single	dimension pitch level	2366.1321543109966
9955. consonantal systems are not merely larger they	are multidimensional	260.2062854229522
9956. morphophonemic rules may be thought of as joining	certain points in the system	1180.6063183738634
9957. the possibilities in the consonantal	system are very numerous and only a small portion of them are actually	used	1729.9377893356655
9958. phonemes connected by a morphophonemic rule commonly show	a good bit of phonetic similarity possible because of the several dimensions	of contrast in the system	3888.7727104531027
9959. tonal morphophonemics in a common	case can do nothing but either raise or lower the tone	1262.708167726434
9960. the possibilities	are few and the total number of rules may be considerably greater	1400.1786306993042
9961. often therefore there are a number of rules having the same	effect and commonly other sets of rules as well having the opposite	effect	2457.5838456576116
9962. tonal morphophonemics is much more confusing to the beginning	analyst than consonantal morphophonemics even when the total number	of rules is no greater	3482.677103972945
9963. the difficulty of analysis of any subsystem	in the phonology is an inverse function of the size- smaller systems	are more troublesome- for any given degree of morphophonemic	complexity	3095.602474402639
9964. this hypothesis will account for a large part of the difficulties	of tonal analysis as well as the fact that vowel systems are	often more puzzling than consonantal systems	4633.425229200952
9965. the statement of the system	is a different matter	262.75117848735874
9966. smaller systems can of course be stated	much more succinctly	561.9808521545946
9967. a phonemic system can be stated without reference	to morphophonemics but it cannot always be found without morphophonemics	1566.8034269763534
9968. and the more complex the morphophonemic system is in relation	to the phonemic base the less easily a phonemic system will be analysed	without close attention to the morphophonemics- at least the less	satisfying will a phonemic statement be if it cannot be related through	morphophonemic rules to grammatically meaningful structures	7496.833630960947
9969. the design of orthographies has received much less attention from	linguists than the problem deserves	1099.3816689534299
9970. there has been a tendency on the	part of many american linguists to assume that a phonemic transcription	will automatically be the best possible orthography and that the only	real problem will then be the social one of securing acceptance	6336.114609063459
9971. most others have been content to give only the most	general attention to the broadest and most obvious features of the phonology	when designing orthographies	2598.1004420841646
9972. apparently the feeling is that	anything more would be involvement in technical abstrusenesses of possible	pedantic interest but of no visible significance in practical affairs	3883.049084481354
9973. the result of this attitude has been the domination of many orthography	conferences by such considerations as typographic 'esthetics'	which usually turns out to be nothing more than certain prejudices	carried over from european languages	3758.6509219468526
9974. many of the suggested systems	seem to have only the most tenuous relationship to the language structures	that they purport to represent	3231.8399404886977
9975. linguists have not always been	more enlightened than practical people and sometimes have insisted	on incredibly trivial points while neglecting things of much greater	significance	2588.7761198383614
9976. as a result many people have been confirmed in their	conviction that orthography design is not an activity to which experts	can contribute anything but confusion	4078.8010298062472
9977. a e sharp	in vowel-length and syllabicity in kikuyu examines one set of related	orthographic questions and its phonologic background in detail	2180.512631605129
9978. his	objective is merely to determine what distinctions of length and	syllabicity it may be desirable to make explicit in a kikuyu orthography		2350.440721505188
9979. to do so he finds it necessary to examine the relevant	parts of the phonology thoroughly and in detail	1731.3051282086285
9980. in the process he	develops some very significant observations about problems of a sort	that are often difficult	2360.060014106452
9981. a few of his examples are of very great interest	and the whole discussion of some importance for theory	1737.4708722674045
9982. his orthographic	recommendations are no simplistic acceptance of phonemics on	the one hand or of superficiality on the other	2604.424315496101
9983. rather he weighs each	phonologic fact in the light of its orthographic usefulness	786.9974093053609
9984. he concludes	that some changes can made in the current orthography which will	appreciably improve its usefulness but hesitates to suggest precise	graphic devices to effect these changes	4475.630673012035
9985. i hope his suggestions are	given the consideration they deserve in kikuyu circles	788.8466586971988
9986. this however	will not exhaust their practical usefulness as they rather clearly	indicate what thorough phonologic investigation can contribute to orthography	design	3258.833515198508
9987. we need many more studies of this sort if the design	of written languages is to be put on a sound basis	2184.55027613145
9988. one other	paper deals with a phonologic problem: vowel harmony in igbo by	j carnochan	1649.8789375891101
9989. this restates the already widely known facts in terms	of prosodies	499.289914665845
9990. as a restatement it makes only a small contribution	to knowledge of igbo	1182.2536301577225
9991. but it would seem more intended as a tract advocating	the prosodic theory than a paper directed to the specific problems	of igbo phonology	2480.443963887384
9992. the paper has a certain value as a comparatively	easy introduction to this approach particularly since it treats	a fairly simple and straightforward phenomenon where it is possible	to compare it with a more traditional statement	5803.83973459545
9993. it does show one feature of the system that has not been previously	described	942.1176764991527
9994. but it does not as it claims demonstrate that this could	not be treated by traditional methods	2104.5797802895577
